name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, thank you for giving me the floor. My point of order is based on article 118 of the latter relating to the hearing, which took place yesterday in committee, of candidates for the Executive Committee. Indeed, in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, by a discriminatory measure that I believe to be contrary to the rules, the floor was refused to non-attached Members. However, article 118 of the regulation which regulates this question refers to Annex XVI. Annex XVI of the rules provides that although the group coordinators have the competence to organize the discussion, on the other hand, speaking times are allocated in accordance with Article 162. Article 162 (4) provides on several occasions for a speaking time for non-members. This is therefore a completely discriminatory measure which I hope does not augur the rest of the work of this Parliament.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the declaration by the candidate for President of the Commission. According to the agenda, this debate is about to start. There is no catch-the-eye procedure in this debate, ladies and gentlemen, and I will not accept blue cards either. Ladies and gentlemen! At its meeting, the Council nominated a candidate for the office of Commission President in a combat vote, which was the first time in this form in the Council, and with the active assistance of the European Parliament - one would have to say: with a little tutoring from the European Parliament - Mr Jean-Claude Juncker named as this candidate. Mr Juncker, I warmly welcome you to the European Parliament. You now have the opportunity to deliver your speech, your inaugural speech, your application speech in front of Parliament. I warmly welcome you to the European Parliament, where you are not a newcomer, but have already been present in a variety of functions. I would first of all like to congratulate you on this nomination by the Council and give you the floor.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: candidate for the office of President of the Commission - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 25 May, the citizens of Europe spoke to us. They sent us strong, if sometimes contradictory, messages. Today and in the years to come, we must respond to them. To meet their expectations, their anxieties, their hopes with dreams, because in Europe there is a place for the dream. It is here in the European Parliament, the centre of European democracy, that I want to present the general guidelines that will preside over the work and action of the next Commission. I am saying general guidelines. The summary guidance that I have sent you in writing in all official languages, because all languages have the same dignity. I would like to thank the translators who spent a sleepless night on a text that I finalized late last night.  The Commission's detailed programme will be the College of Commissioners, which will be yours to legitimise not to vote in the autumn. The Parliament that has just begun its mandate as a legislature is a parliament that is different from its predecessors. You are the first parliament to really elect, in every sense of the word, the President of the Commission. You will elect him in a new spirit. The day after the election, you insisted on the requirement that the results of universal suffrage be taken into account. In doing so, you have given its true meaning, its true democratic and political significance to Article 17, paragraph 7, of the Lisbon Treaty. Without your insistence and advocacy, this article would have remained a dead letter forever. You defended the democratic principle and you were right to do so. A parliament that imposes the observance of the democratic principle does a noble job and deserves neither acerbic and unjustified criticism nor trial of ill-inspired intent.  I want to pay tribute here to the other leading candidates who have added a strong dose of vivacity, another democratic debate. If the political family of one of them had won the election, I would have been the first to ask this House to invest it with the mandate to compose the next Commission.  Parliament and the Commission are two of the most community institutions. Therefore, it is only normal for the President of Parliament and the President of the Commission, on the one hand, and for Parliament and the Commission, on the other, to have a privileged working and design relationship. We will be community actors, not against the European Council or against the Council of Ministers; Europe is not built against states or nations, which are not a temporary invention of history, but which are settled in the long term. We, Parliament and the Commission, will act in the public interest and I would like us to do so together.  The European Council proposes the Chairman of the Committee. That does not make him his secretary. The Commission is not a technical committee made up of brilliant senior officials at the behest of another institution. The Commission will be political. I want it more political. It will be very political. Its composition must reflect the plurality of the majority of ideas that are being put in place and I would like the European Council, when it organises its internal architecture, to be inspired by the same principle.  The President of the Commission is elected by your Assembly, but that does not make him a receiver of orders. I will not be the European Parliament's aide-de-camp. But do not doubt for a second my desire to terminate the office of a Commissioner to whom you have withdrawn your confidence, nor my willingness to follow in principle in principle by a legislative proposal your interventions and invitations in this direction. Also, the right to ask questions will not be undermined. It will remain as it is.  I will ask the Commissioners to attend the highlights of the important trilogues more often, and I would like the Council to do the same. I will ensure that the register of lobbies is made public and mandatory. I would like the Europeans to know who came to see who, who spoke to whom, and I would like the other institutions to follow us in this process. (Applause) I will ensure that the procedural rules surrounding the various GMO authorities are reviewed. I would not want the Commission to decide when a majority of Member States would not have encouraged it.  In general, ladies and gentlemen, let us renounce ideological debates which have no other purpose than to fuel divisions. Let us replace them with virtuous debates based on strong convictions and ambitions that bear far. Let's choose pragmatism as a method. Let's focus on concrete achievements that have beneficial effects for all Europeans. Let us not fatm those who observe us through inter-institutional debates that take us away from the essential, that is, the European citizen. And I say to governments: "Resist more often the temptation of criticism when you return home on the decisions you have taken together in Brussels."  (Applause) "If you said yes in Brussels, don't say no elsewhere. Never say, ever again, after a meeting of the European Council or the Council, that you have won a victory and that the others have lost. In Europe we win together and we lose together." (Applause) Europe has become unreadable because very often we turn its description into a caricature. Let's give up national navel-gazing. In Europe, let's play together. Let's apply the community method. Yes, it's demanding, but it's effective. It has a proven track supply and is more credible than intergovernmental excesses. Ladies and gentlemen, the Community method must be rehabilitated. (Applause)  Ja, Herr President - ich dr-cke mich jetzt in der Sprache des Weltmeisters aus , Europa hat an Glaubw-rdigkeit eingebàt. Die Distanz zwischen der European Union und den Bàrgern w-chst. Nur die total Blinden und die total Tauben h-ren und sehen das nicht. Die European Union befindet sich sehr oft in Erkl-rungsnot, und wir befinden uns in permanenter Bringpflicht, um Europa besser zu erklàren. Europa, Herr President, braucht eine breit aufgestellte Reformagenda. Der Status quo ist keine komplette Palette. Wir messen sie erweitern. Die Menschen haben sehr oft Angst vor Reformen. Sie empfinden sie als bedrohlich, als zu risikoreich. Aber wer kein Risiko eingeht, der geht das greere Risiko ein. Wir messen Risiken eingehen, um Europa wettbewerbsf-higer zu machen. Wir haben als European Union an internationaler und globaler Wettbewerbsf-higkeit eingebàt. Wir sind zur-ckgefallen, weil wir stehen geblieben sind. Wir messen wieder in Vorsprung kommen. Wettbewerbsf-higkeit wird oft verwechselt mit einseitigem Sozialabbau. Aber Wettbewerbsf-higkeit erreicht man nicht mit Sozialabbau. Wettbewerbsf-higkeit erreicht man dadurch, dass man sich ein breit gef-chertes Konzept an die Hand gibt. Ziel muss sein, die European Union zu einem aktiven Standort zu machen - Standort fàr Menschen, Standort fàr Investoren. Dazu geh-rt auch das Prinzip - man muss manchmal an die Notwendigkeit erinnern - dass die Wirtschaft den Menschen zu dienen hat und nicht umgekehrt. Wirtschaft hat den Menschen zu dienen. (Beifall) Dies erzwingt, dass die Binnenmarktregeln keinen h-heren Wert haben als die sozialen Mindestregeln. Binnenmarkt geht nicht immer vor, auch das Soziale muss seinen Platz in Europa behalten. (Beifall) Ich bin ein begeisterter Anh-nger der sozialen Marktwirtschaft. "Wohlstand for alle", hat Ludwig Erhard gesagt, nicht nur Wohlstand fer einige wenige. Wohlstand for alle, das muss die Maxime jeder Wirtschafts- und Sozialpolitik sein. Man sagt oft angesichts der Krise, die soziale Marktwirtschaft hette versagt. Nein, meine Damen und Herren, nicht die soziale Marktwirtschaft hat versagt! Versagt haben die, die gegen die Kardinaltugenden der sozialen Marktwirtschaft durch Profitgier, durch Geldgier, durch die Politik des schnellen Geldes verstoen haben! Nicht die soziale Marktwirtschaft hat versagt. (Beifall) Soziale Marktwirtschaft funktioniert nur, wenn es sozialen Dialog gibt. Der soziale Dialog hat in den vergangenen Krisenjahren gelitten. Er muss sowohl national als auch und vor allem auf europeischer Ebene wiederbelebt werden. Ich mechte ein President of the sozialen Dialogs breast. (Beifall) Standortsicherung braucht Wachstum, nicht schuldenfinanzierte Konjunkturprogramme, die zu Strohfeuer fàhren, die auf Dauer keine Arbeitsmarktwirkung zeitigen. Was wir brauchen ist ein nachhaltiges Wachstum for Jahrzehnte. Wir brauchen ein anspruchsvolles Arbeits-, Wachstums-, Investitions- und Wettbewerbsf-higkeitspaket. Wieso brauchen wir das? Weil wir viele Menschen in Europa wieder zur-ck nach Europa, wieder zur-ck in die Mitte des Lebens fàhren messen. Wachstumspakete, Wettbewerbsf-higkeitspakete, Investitionsprogramme haben nur ein Ziel: die Menschen wieder in die Mitte der Gesellschaft zur-ckzubringen. Es entsteht zurzeit innerhalb der Grenzen der European Union ein 29. Staat. Das ist der Staat, in dem die wohnen, die keine Arbeit haben. Ein Staat, in dem jugendliche Arbeitslose wohnen. Ein Staat, in dem Ausgeschlossene, Zur-ckgeworfene, am Wege stehen Gebliebene leben. Ich hette gerne, dass dieser 29. Mitgliedstaat wieder ein normaler Mitgliedstaat wird. Deshalb schlage ich ein anspruchsvolles Investitionsprogramm vor. Bis Februar 2015 mechte ich dieses anspruchsvolle Wachstums-, Investitions-, Wettbewerbsf-higkeits- und Arbeitspaket vorlegen. Ich hàtte gerne, dass wir in den nechsten drei Jahren 300 Milliarden Euro an 'ffentlichen und vor allem privaten Investitionen mobilisieren. Das werden wir tun, und ich wre dankbar, wenn das Parlament mich auf diesem Weg unterst-tzen wurde. Wir kunnnen das tun durch zielorientiertes Nutzen der bestehenden Strukturfonds und durch das zielorientierte Nutzen der verf-gbaren und auszubauenden Instrumente der European Investitionsbank. Wir brauchen Investitionen in Infrastrukturprojekte, abgestimmte Investitionen, wir brauchen Investitionen im Breitbandbereich, in Sachen Energienetze, wir brauchen Investitionen in die Verkehrsinfrastruktur der Industriezentren. Wir brauchen eine Reindustrialisierung Europas. Wir brauchen auch Investitionen im industrialn Bereich. Wir brauchen Investitionen in Sachen Forschung, Entwicklung, erneuerbare Energien. Erneuerbare Energien sind nicht das Spielfeld ökologischer Gutmenschen. Erneuerbare Energien und ihr Ausbau sind die Voraussetzung, dass das Europa von morgen wirklich dauerhaft best-ndige, nachhaltige Standortvorteile im Direktvergleich zu anderen Playern in der Welt hat. (Beifall) Ein sturker investierendes Europa ist ein Europa fàr mehr Wohlstand, es ist ein Europa fàr mehr Arbeitspletze. Investitionen sind der beste Verbendete der Arbeitslosen. Wir messen parallel dazu die Jugendgarantie ausbauen. Ich hàtte gerne, dass wir die Altersgrenze schrittweise von 25 auf 30 Jahre erh-hen. Investitionen sind nur dann zielorientiert zu gestalten, wenn wir in Sachen Bàrokratieabbau von der Stelle kommen, vor allem bez-glich der kleinen und mittleren Unternehmen. Mittelstundler sind keine Gro-kapitalisten. Mittelstundler arbeiten hart. Mittelstundler schaffen Arbeitspletze. Wir messen mehr for den Mittelstand tun, vor allem 'ber den Weg des resoluten Abbaus der bàrokratischen 'bertreibungen. Wir messen Ernst machen mit der Anwendung des Prinzips der Subsidiarity. Seit dem Maastrichter Vertrag reden wir 'ber die korrekte Anwendung of the Subsidiarit-tsprinzips. Wir tun is nur mangelhaft. Unsere Reden dauern lenger als die Anstrengungen, die wir leisten, um in Sachen Bàrokratieabbau von der Stelle zu kommen und um dafar Sorge zu tragen, dass die Europeische Kommission und die Europeische Union, statt sich in alle Details, Winkel und Ecken der Menschen einzumischen, sich um die wirklich gro-en europ-ischen Nicht jedes Problem, das es in Europa gibt, darf zum Problem der European Union werden. Wir sollen uns um die groeen Sachen kunmmern! (Beifall) All dies, Herr President, muss naturlich Stabilit-tspakt-konform in die Wege geleitet werden. Wir werden den Stabilitets- und Wachstumspakt in seinen Grundz-gen nicht verandern. Dies hat der European Rat festgestellt. Ich halte mich an diese Maegbe in den nechsten Jahren. Stabilitet war versprochen worden bei Einf-hrung der gemeinsamen Wàhrung. Stabilitet ist nicht nur ein Eintrittsgebot, sondern Stabilitet ist ein dauerhaftes Gebot. Stability war versprochen, Europa darf seine Versprechen nicht brechen! Ich werde sie nicht brechen! (Beifall) Aber der European Rat hat zu Recht festgestellt, dass wir die Flexibilit-tsmargen, die der 2005, 2011 reformierte Stabilit-tspakt enth-lt, auch nutzen, um die Dimension Wachstum des Stabilitàts- und Wachstumspaktes voll zur Geltung zu bringen. Das haben wir in der Vergangenheit auch getan, das werden wir in Zukunft verst-rkt tun - wobei es mir schon auf die Feststellung ankommt, Herr President, dass das, was wir in den vergangenen Jahren auf den Weg gebracht haben, das, was wir gele Ich war Vorsitzender der Euro-Gruppe und bin froh, es nicht mehr zu sein. Denn eine vergn-gungssteuerpflichtige Veranstaltung ist das nun wirklich nicht. Ob die Aufgabe, fer die ich mich heute bewerbe, angenehmer werden wird, wage ich im 'brigen zu bezweifeln. Aber wir haben w-hrend der Eurokrise - die keine Eurokrise war, sondern eine Schuldenkrise - ein brennendes Flugzeug im Flug reparieren messen. Das war nicht einfach, das entspricht nicht allen Anforderungen hoher Staatskunst, das entspricht nicht den Geboten ausgefeilter politischer.sthetik. Aber wir haben es geschafft, dass die Euro-Zone als Ganzes erhalten blieb. Vor etwas mehr als einem Jahr haben Spekulanten go Provenienz - und viele lachen da - darauf gewettet, dass die Euro-Zone in sich selbst zusammenfallen wurde. Sie ist es nicht! Es wurden auf vielen Finanzpl-tzen Wetten abgeschlossen, dass Griechenland aus der Eurozone ausscheiden wurde. Ich habe alles getan und ich bin stolz darauf, dass Griechenland, dieses t-chtige Volk, diese groe Nation, immer noch Mitglied der europeischen Wirtschafts- und Wàhrungsunion ist. (Starker Beifall) Aber, Herr President, wir haben auch Fehler gemacht. Ein brennendes Flugzeug im Flug zu reparieren, ist keine einfache Sache. Da verbrennt man sich schon von Zeit zu Zeit die Finger. Ich hàtte gerne in Zukunft, wenn es noch zu Anpassungsprogrammen kommt - ich sehe im 'brigen keine Notwendigkeit, dass es in den nechsten Jahren dazu kàme, dass, bevor ein Anpassungsprogramm zur Anwendung kommt, eine sehr minutise soziale Folgenabsch-tzungsstudie gemacht wird. Ich wesste gerne, wie sich Anpassungsprogramme im Leben der Menschen auswirken. Es wird in Zukunft keine Anpassungsprogramme ohne vorgeschaltete Analysis sozialer Impakte geben konnen. (Beifall) Und ich hàtte gerne, dass wir uns jedes Mal, wenn Anpassungsprogramme ins Haus stehen, einen Plan B zurechtlegen, einen Plan B, auf den wir uns dann beziehen kunnnen, wenn die makro-konomischen Voraussagen nicht stimmen. Wenn es weniger Wachstum in einem Land gibt, als dies Grundlage eines Anpassungsprogramms war, dann muss man auch die Anpassungsprogramme anpassen kunnen. Deshalb bin fer die parallele Aufstellung eines Plans B in all diesen Fullen. (Zwischenruf) It doesn't seem to convince you? Ich hette gerne, dass wir das Instrument der Troika neu nachdenken. Das Parlament hat in einschl-gigen Berichten dargelegt, dass es der Troika, so wie sie jetzt funktioniert, an demokratischer Substanz fehlt. Es fehlt ihr an demokratischer Substanz, es fehlt ihr eine parlamentarische Dimension. Wir messen die Troika neu ausrichten, sie demokratischer, parlamentarischer, politischer machen. Wir werden dies tun! (Beifall) We cannot spend money that we do not have. We have to replace deficits and debt with ideas. These ideas are there. We must better use the opportunities offered by digital technology, which does not know any borders. We must break down national silos of telecommunication regulations, of copyright and of data protection. We have to break down national silos as far as the management of radio waves is concerned, and so on. We must knock down these barriers, these hurdles to growth. Roaming charges in Europe have to disappear, and they will disappear. If we are successful in implementing a real digital single market, we can generate EUR 250 billion of additional growth in Europe, and we will do it. We need - as was so often said (mainly during the Ukraine crisis) - a resilient energy Union with a forward-looking climate-change policy. We have to reorganize Europe's energy policy into a new European energy union. We need to pool resources, combine infrastructures and unite our negotiating power vis-à-vis third countries. We need to diversify our energy sources and reduce the high energy dependence of several of our Member States. I think that the European energy union will become the world number one in renewables and will contribute to significantly-enhanced energy efficiency beyond the 2020 objective, notably when it comes to buildings. A binding 30% objective for energy efficiency by 2030 is, to me, the minimum if we want to be credible and forward-looking. We cannot pretend to be the leader as far as climate change policy is concerned if we do not become more efficient when it comes to energy efficiency. (Applause) The internal market has to be completed. If we are successful in this, we will add another EUR 200 billion of added value to the European economy. We have to do it. We have to complement the new European rules for banks with a capital markets union. To improve the financing of our economy, we should further develop and integrate capital markets. This would cut the cost of raising capital, mainly for small and medium-sized enterprises. Free movement of workers has always been one of the key looters of the internal market. I will defend that principle. Free movement is an opportunity, not a threat. The rules will not be changed. It will be up to national authorities to fight against abuse of fraudulent claims. I will initiate a targeted review of the Posting of Workers Directive and its implementation. We have to fight social dumping, and we will do it. I will fight tax evasion and tax fraud. I am in favour of the adoption at EU level of the common consolidated corporate tax based on the Financial Transaction Tax. We have to fight against money laundering, and we will do it. (Applause) With regard to economic and monetary union, Mr President, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that the crisis is not over. The crisis is not over. The crisis is not over as long as there are twenty-five thousand men and women who are unemployed. The crisis is over when full employment has been restored. To achieve this, we need to better coordinate our economic policies. We need to put in place an economic government, an economic governance, a kind of economic government. And we will.  We must remain demanding in terms of the necessary implementation of structural reforms which, in the medium term, will contribute to the growth of the European economy. If the Member States of the Economic and Monetary Union make special efforts, we will have to think about financial incentives that will accompany this process. In this context, it will be necessary we were thinking about establishing its own fiscal capacity for the euro area.  We must stop being ridiculous and be represented, as one of the strongest, by so many representatives who very often contradict each other. I would like the Economic and Monetary Union and the euro to be represented by a single chair, one place and one voice in the Bretton Woods institutions. (Applause) As I am in Bretton Woods, in the middle of the United States, I would like to say a word about the free trade agreement with the United States. I am in my united states. I believe that the two largest economic areas and the two largest democracies on the planet are joining forces in the interests of both Americans and Europeans. That said, the agreement will not be concluded at any price. We cannot abandon our health standards. We cannot abandon our social norms. We cannot abandon our data protection requirements. I do not want data protection to be part of the negotiation with our American friends. And I would not want us to set up secret parallel courts. We are spaces of law, and in the United States as in Europe, we apply the law and ensure that these negotiations are surrounded by maximum transparency. I say this: "If we do not publish the relevant documents, I am not talking about the documents that deal with the negotiating strategy, this agreement will fail. It will fail in front of our public opinion, it will fail in this Parliament and it will fail in our national parliaments should there ever be a joint agreement. So let's be more transparent because we have nothing to hide. Let's not give the impression of having to hide something. Let's not hide anything, let's make the relevant documents transparent. (Applause) The European Union is a union of value. We are credible to the rest of the world if we are demanding inwardly in terms of fundamental values. I will appoint a commissioner who will be responsible for enforcing the Charter of Fundamental Rights. I would like the European Union to reach the members of the Council of Europe's European Convention on Human Rights as soon as possible.  The anti-discrimination directive will remain on the table and I will try to convince the Council to adopt it as soon as possible, at least in its broad outline.  Immigration and migration, legal immigration, illegal immigration are subjects that, almost on a daily basis, occupy our citizens. We need a common asylum policy and I will propose a common asylum policy.  (Applause) We need to reflect on the legal immigration that Europe, in the next five years, will sorely need. We do as well as the United States, Canada and Australia. We can do what they have always been able to do. (Protests) I thought there would be moments of excitement at this place of my speech and I had seen right... Let's protect our external borders, and fight against criminal gangs who make money with the misfortune of others. Let us help those who come to us before they take the boat across the Mediterranean and make sure that a better solidarity is established between the north and the south of Europe. Illegal immigration, the problem of refugees are not the problems of Malta, Cyprus, Italy and Greece, these are the problems of Europe as a whole. (Applause) Zur Auenpolitik, Herr President, mechte ich keine groen Worte verlieren. Aber Auenpolitik, eine gemeinsame Auen- und Sicherheitspolitik, brauchen wir dringend. Mir wre es recht - und ich werde dafar sorgen , dass der oder die Au-enbeauftragte nicht mehr von den europeischen Au-enministern ausgebremst wird. Eine gemeinsame Auenpolitik braucht auch eine einheitliche Darstellung nach auen. (Beifall) Der oder die Auenbeauftragte, die ein weites Arbeitsfeld ihr Eigen nennt, wird von anderen sektoriell zust-ndigen Kommissaren unterst-tzt werden. In Sachen Verteidigung geht es mir nicht darum, die European Union als Gegenentwurf zur NATO zu etablieren. Beide messen zusammen arbeiten und zusammen atmen. Aber im Verteidigungsbereich brauchen wir verst-rkte Zusammenarbeit, so wie der Lissabon-Vertrag dies ja auch vorsieht. Und wir brauchen vor allem in Sachen Beschaffungswesen mehr Zusammenarbeit, anstatt dass wir gegeneinander das beschaffen, was wir alle gemeinsam brauchen. Es wird in den nechsten fenf Jahren kein neues Mitglied zur European Union hinzustoen. Aus heutiger Sicht ist es unvorstellbar, dass eines der Kandidatenlander, mit denen wir verhandeln, die Beitrittskriterien allesamt und im Detail bis zum Jahr 2019 wird erf-llen kunnen. Aber die Verhandlungen werden weitergef-hrt. Und andere europeische Nationen, andere europeische Lunder, brauchen eine glaubw-rdige, ehrlich gemeinte europeische Perspektive. Dies gilt vor allem fer die Lunder of the westlichen Balkans, denn diese tragische Region Europas braucht die europeische Persepektive. Ansonsten werden die alten donmonen wieder wach. (Beifall) I would have liked to talk to you, Mr President, about the necessary industrial policy that we need to put in place in Europe to increase the relative share of industry in European GDP to a value of 20%. I would have to speak in more detail about Ukraine, which I would like to greet the people today and tell them that we believe that this people are European and that they have a place in Europe. (Applause) I would have liked to explain in detail why I think it is necessary for us in all the countries of the European Union to introduce minimum social wages and minimum incomes for integration or guaranteed minimum incomes. We will do that.  I would have liked to express my conviction that services of general interest and public services must be safeguarded and cannot be at the mercy of the whims of the time. Let's defend public service in Europe. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, I would have liked to have told you about Africa, this Africa so often unhappy and so often forgotten, but this resource-rich And, in particular, resource-rich Africa. Let us not forget Africa and ensure that this scandal, this tragedy, this tragedy every day repeated, that every six seconds a man starves and that we lose twenty-five thousand children a day because they are hungry. As long as twenty-five thousand children are starving every day, Europe has not completed its work. Europe is responsible for changing this situation. (Applause) Yes, Mr President, we will have to make a fresh start, we will have to hear from those who spoke to us on 25 May. But this is not the time for revolution and the time is not for counter-revolution either. If we want Europeans to fall in love with their Europe again, let us tell them that we are proud of Europe. Let us tell them that we are proud of many of the things we have achieved over the past decades. It is often said that the question between war and peace no longer arises. However, the unsealed dialogue between war and peace remains a European subject. We have just discovered on the periphery of the European Union that peace is not a permanent visitor to the European continent. Let us be proud of the generation of our fathers and mothers, the generation of our grandmothers and grandfathers who, back from the battlefields and concentration camps, have made this eternal post-war prayer "never again war", a political program that has so far had beneficial effects.  (Applause) We are indebted to our parents. (Great applause) Let us be proud of having been able, during the 1990s, to succeed in enlargement, to have reconciled European history and geography and to have put an end to this disastrous post-war decree which called for Europe to be divided into two parts forever. We have reunited the geography and European history without weapons but with conviction. So I would like to pay tribute to those who, in Central and Eastern Europe, one day decided to take history into their own hands, to no longer suffer history but to make history themselves. Let us cease to talk about old and new Member States. There are member states, neither new nor old. (Great applause) And let us be proud to have set up the single currency. The single currency does not divide Europe. The single currency protects Europe.  (Protests then covered by applause) Mr President, I was Finance Minister in my country for 20 years. Every six months, I had to go to Brussels to see monetary realignments. Every six months I experienced "live and in colour" how dangerous monetary disorder was for the European economy. I have experienced many times the loss of dignity of a state which, for lack of being competitive, had to devalue. I have witnessed with bitterness terrible scenes where those who had to increase the external value of their currency did not want it, because losing the markets, and where those who had to devalue did not dare to do so because fearing a massive incursion, a disorderly return of inflation. If during the events in Ukraine, if during the economic and financial crisis, which hit us and which made Europe the epicentre of a global battle, we were still in the European monetary system, Europe today would be in a monetary war. France versus Germany. Germany versus Italy. Italy against Portugal and Spain. All against all. The euro, its discipline and ambitions ensure that we know a monetary order that protects us. The euro protects Europe. (Exclamations: 'What about Greece?') Mr President, Greece did not want to leave the currency area and we did not want Greece to leave that area. (Great applause) (Interjection from the floor: 'And Spain?') What about Britain? I am defending the single currency because the single currency is protecting Europe, its economy and its citizens. (Applause) Mr President, if we had not done what we have done in the past decades, if we had not made Europe a continent of peace, if we had not reconciled European history and geography, if we had not set up the single currency and if we had not built the world's largest internal market in Europe. , what situation would we find ourselves in today?  (Exclamations) We'd be unengradable, unarmed. We'd be weakened. We would be unarmed today and Europe, thanks to the work and convictions of our predecessors, is a continent that ensures that those who live there can live in peace and relative well-being. (The President interrupts the speaker) (Great applause) Mr President, I do not want a Europe that occupies the stands of history. I do not want a Europe that observes others when they do, when they act and when they move forward. I would like a Europe that occupies the middle of the field, a Europe that plays forward, a Europe that wins, a Europe that protects, that exists, a Europe that is a model for others. To do so, let us draw inspiration from the principles and convictions bequeathed to us by the great Europeans who were there when we were not yet anywhere.  I want to pay tribute here to Jacques Delors, the great President of the Commission. (Vis applause) It is not Delors who wants, but Delors is my friend and my master and his work will inspire me every day. I want to pay tribute here to François Mitterrand, who said that nationalism leads to war. François Mitterrand was right. (Live applause and protests) I also want to pay tribute to Helmut Kohl who was in my lifetime the greatest European I have been fortunate enough to know. (Great applause) Let's do what they do. They had patience. They had courage. They had determination. Let's have the same courage, have the same determination, have the same patience. Let us have the patience, this courage, this determination imposed by long journeys and great ambitions.  We can do great things together for Europe, for its citizens, for the world, mr President, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr Juncker, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has Today is a good day for Europe. The European institutions have shown in recent weeks that we are fully capable of acting. In the European elections, the citizens voted for the future of Europe, for more democracy, for reform, for growth. In the European Parliament, despite the social consequences of the great economic and financial crisis, we are relying on a majority of constructive forces to shape Europe's future. With this election, we have also made Europe a great deal more democratic. It is a historic day. For the first time, voters have been able to have a direct say in the top of the European Commission. Certainly not everyone has done that yet, but it is a first important start. One can find or criticize the concept of the leading candidates. But Democrats should agree on one thing: It is generally better to tell voters before the election where they want to go, what personnel they want to do with, than to say it after the election. (Applause) We have come a step closer to this principle. That is a good thing, and no one will be able to turn that back. Today is a good day for Europe, and as chairman of the group I can of course also say that it is a good day for my group and for my party. A candidate from the European People's Party is due to vote today. Let me remind you that all programme countries – Greece, Spain, Portugal and Ireland – are governed by the European People's Party. There were wage cuts, pension cuts, social benefits being cut back, taxes were increased. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has had to explain many unpleasant decisions to the citizens. We have demanded a lot from people. On the other hand, EPP governments – for example in Finland, Luxembourg or Germany – have had to explain to people the need for solidarity, the need for bailouts. During the election campaign, the difficult decisions of recent years were attacked by many. We – the European People's Party – and Jean-Claude Juncker have also defended these decisions and appealed to the people for their necessity. This has not been easy, and yet the European People's Party is once again the strongest group in the European Parliament. Jean-Claude Juncker won the election. He is the right man at the right time. (Applause) Jean-Claude Juncker is a candidate of the European People's Party, yes, but he is today seeking the approval of the entire European Parliament. We know that the principle of democracy is compromise. The ideas of the other constructive forces in the European Parliament must also be heard. Jean-Claude Juncker has been elected on his EPP programme, but Jean-Claude Juncker stands for consensus in this European Parliament. He also has the support of his group, the PPE-DE. There has been much talk of reform, of change, of departure. The tasks have been clearly defined. For the GROUP of European Democrats, the following four points are central: firstly, we need growth. Europe must become competitive. We need a reindustrialisation of our continent. Secondly, we must continue on the road to a stability union. Debt does not create a future, debt destroys the future. Thirdly, we need more respect for the national levels, especially our colleagues in the national parliaments. Fourthly, after the years of crisis, Europe must turn its attention to the outside world, on refugee policy or when it comes to partnership with our friends in Ukraine. Four priorities, which I would like to emphasise once again from the point of view of the PPE-DE. However, I do not want to use my speaking time to discuss this content in detail. We have plenty of opportunity to do so over the next five years. I would like to use my speaking time today to express two central ideas on culture and how to deal with our Europe. First of all, I would like to take up a thought by Jean-Claude Juncker and underline once again: we are talking about change and we must be aware that many people on our continent see change and reform as a threat rather than an opportunity, rather afraid when we talk about change. That is why it is important to win people over to this path of change on our continent. One thing is important to me: we must be aware that today we are living in a time when a plethora of fundamental changes are taking place at the same time. One 00 00 years ago, industrialization was a formative process, a great change that caused winners and losers in the society that changed the world at the time. Today, we live in a time when fundamental change is taking place in a diversity like never before. Think of the Demographics. Today, 15% of Europeans are over 65. By 2050, it will not be 15%, but 25%. More pensioners, less innovative power, will change our continent. Think of globalisation. Prosperity is being redistributed in this world at a breathtaking rate. Globalisation is making the states of Europe smaller. In 2040 – in 26 years' time – no European state is likely to be able to take a seat at the G7 summit, according to economic data. That says it all. Think of ecology, of climate change. Think about the question of digitization, how we keep in touch with friends, how we shop. Everything changes through digitalization. We see the advantages, but let us be honest: do we already have the disadvantages of this development under control? A plethora of fundamental changes is taking place at the same time. I think it is important that we explain this to the people, that we tell people that, because the prerequisite is that there is openness to change, to reform. Reforms are needed to preserve Europe's way of life, to upend our values, so that we can secure the extraordinary that makes Europe safe for future generations. And we must also make one thing clear: those who cling to existing structures, who are not prepared for change, will lose. This is also shown by a look at our Europe today. Where courageous politicians have carried out reforms, people are better off, there is a future. It is precisely in the Central and Eastern European Member States that we Europeans can learn this best. Since the collapse of totalitarian communism, much, enormous things have been turned around and changed there. You, ladies and gentlemen from these countries, know better than we from the West and southern Europe that stalemate and clinging means a step backwards. That is why I am advocating this understanding: clinging means regression, openness to reform, change means the future. Let us encourage people, let us make people want something new! Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I would like to introduce a second central idea: reform, objectivity – Europe must be thought pragmatically. That is what is currently being demanded on land, from now on. However, this has also made Europe more technical. People perceive a cold apparatus of Europe. Honestly, I don't just want to be pragmatic. I want to be able to have ideas for Europe again in the next few years. I would like to be able to rejoice in our Europe again in the coming years. I want to shape Europe's future. What do I mean by that? In my youth, when I began to be interested in politics, I read a lot about the European idea, about the founding fathers of Europe. On the rubble of the Second World War, there were people who said: I want to create a continent that creates peace. I want a continent that reaches out to the archenemy. I want a continent that defeats nationalism and totalitarianism, which is returning to its historical roots. Or I want a continent without border controls, a common market, a coexistence in diversity – on the rubble of world war II. A whole generation of politicians, from the left or the right, dreamed the unthinkable at the time. Today, one might say: what illusionists were they then? But they made the impossible possible, they won. And today? Ladies and gentlemen, today: Sixpack, Stabi Pact, MiFid Directive, Agricultural Reform and, and, and. All this is important. But is that enough? Europe has so much to offer! Britain, for example, is the motherland of parliamentary democracy. It gave us Europeans this idea. Today, the whole of Europe is proud of its parliamentary tradition. Or France: yesterday was national holiday – with the idea of freedom, equality, fraternity, developing human rights, especially equality between men and women. Developed in France, given to the entire continent. Today, we Europeans are proud of the Charter of Fundamental Rights that make us. In Germany: the Reformation, which enforced the separation of state and religion. Today European acquis. Greece, with its philosophy, Rome has given us the right. Without it, The culture of Europe would be unthinkable. And the great seafaring nations of Portugal and Spain have discovered the world. Each country has its own historical experience. And we have worked out a great deal together in Europe. Today, these achievements are a common European acquis. We Europeans have achieved this, each with his contribution and each depends on the other. Ladies and gentlemen, my vision of Europe refers precisely to these achievements. Globally, democracy, human rights and the separation of state and religion are not a matter of course. I always imagine when the world's big countries meet at the G20 summit and talk about world trade, for example: who raises his hand and says: yes, trade. But we must ban child labour, for example. Do the Indians do that? Does that make Brazil? No, we Europeans must do it. Who raises his hand when the question arises that we are fighting climate change? Does the US do that, does China do it? No, we Europeans must do it. And who, at these great summits, reminds the world that conflicts must first be resolved peacefully? Do the Russians do this, do the US do it? No, we Europeans must bring this in. That is my wish for today's young generation: a Europe that is proud of its great achievements in the history of the spirit, a Europe that ceases to wrestle with itself and is aware of its responsibilities in the world, a Europe that embodies this self-confidence and bears the commonground. If we live ideas today, then we should make people want to be Europeans! Anchored, rooted in the region in which one grew up, proud of one's own nation and aware that we Europeans have something to contribute to the development of the world. Europe, do not forget your task, this world needs the European contribution! Ladies and gentlemen, finally, can we perhaps love Europe, this continent, beyond the many contents, perhaps even a little bit? Europe with its landscapes: Wales, Tuscany, the Masuria. Europe with its proud cities: Rome, Athens, Budapest. Europe with its culture: the whole world visits our museums, our operas are performed all over the world, and today's European cultural scene is of richness and abundance like nowhere else. Europe is unspeakably rich, so diverse, so vibrant. I feel very comfortable on this continent as a Bavarian, as a German European. I like being European. And I believe that it is important to convey the emotional side to our citizens. Ladies and gentlemen, let us get to work, to kick off today, give Jean-Claude Juncker a strong mandate so that he can do his job! I and we in the Group of the European People's Party want us, together with him, to reduce the problems and concerns of the people of Europe, for Europe to do its job and simply to deliver it. And I want us to be able to have ideas beyond pragmatic everyday life, just as the founding generation did – ideas, a vision of the future of a united Europe in diversity, proud of its origins, proud of its nation, but also grateful to be Europeans. (Applause)

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker, I would like to begin by talking about a region that is not in the European Union, but which has never been so European in recent days: Gaza. There is war in Gaza, yet another war that causes thousands of civilian casualties. We must stop this war! No one can close their eyes or look somewhere else. The war re-emerges at Europe's borders: in Syria, a few kilometres from Cyprus; in Libya, in the south of Italy; in Gaza; but also in Ukraine in the heart of Europe. Well, the war we thought we'd exorcised forever is back and evokes ancient demons. It reminds us of Srebrenica, whose anniversary we are celebrating these days. But war, this war, is a mirror for us because it recalls the profound meaning – as Mr Weber has just said – of the profound meaning, the raison d' er of the European project. The European Union is certainly an economic and monetary union and also a banking union, but it is something more, it is a project of civilisation, peace and solidarity. As the first action of this new legislature we must work to impose a ceasefire and a humanitarian assistance plan for Gaza. Europe will not be itself unless it has found the message of peace for which it was born. My first thoughts are with the thousands of victims of the Gaza war. Mr President, five years ago José Manuel Barroso was in the same room. The crisis had begun a few months ago and many already foretold its end. Five years later – as you have honestly pointed out – the crisis is still there, Europe is mired in deep stagnation. There is a risk of deflation, unemployment and poverty have increased, a whole generation has lost hope in the future. Mr Juncker, you often speak – because you are a man of great culture – about the history of our European continent. I too believe that history is important and I believe that we must learn from the mistakes of recent years, from the mistakes that led us to this crisis. The first mistake is ancient, it is the same as the crisis of 1929 and it is called austerity. In the face of a demand crisis, we should have revived investment, which would create growth. Faced with the emergence of new poverty, we should have reformed and supported our social protection systems. Instead, in the name of an accounting vision, investment has been cut, social spending has been reduced and the growth potential of our economies has been reduced. No one wants to spread public spending indiscriminately, assistance. However, the right balance must be struck between consolidating public finances and supporting large-term investments. On the other hand, some people seem obsessed with the idea of tidying up public accounts. But I ask myself and I ask you: where is the order when one in two young people is unemployed? Where is the order when the poverty rate is growing at an exponential rate? Is the order of public accounts or the order of society, the order of our lives, more important? The great lesson of this crisis is that the rules – as you said in your report – all rules, including budgetary rules, must serve the lives of our citizens. The second lesson is that we in Europe are interdependent. Our societies and economies are linked to two strands, fibrillation in a financial market is quickly passed on to other markets. The immigrants arriving in Lampedusa today will probably be the marginalised in our suburbs, in the major European cities from Madrid to London, to Paris, to Berlin, to Rome. This interdependence imposes responsibility, solidarity and sharing on all of us. The third lesson is that we need more democracy. If we are mired in this crisis, it is also because – let us face it, Mr Juncker – dozens and dozens of intergovernmental summits have proved inconclusive and have produced confusing and ineffective decisions. We need a stronger democracy in the European Union. If we support you today, Mr Juncker, how do we support you? It is because we think that you have learned from these lessons, especially from the demand for more democracy. If you are here today, it is also because a small revolution has taken place in Europe in recent weeks. For the first time since the birth of the Union, the President of the Commission has been elected taking into account the votes of the citizens. This brand marks the advent of parliamentary democracy and is an irreversible step. If there had not been the obstinacy and tenacity of this Parliament, you, Mr Juncker, probably could not have become President of the European Commission. Our vote in favour of you today is not a blank cheque. We were very pleased with some of the references in his speech to the Social issues and the social market economy, which you have emphasized very much, belongs to the culture of European socialists, democrats and progressives. But we know that you are not a socialist and we do not ask you as a condition to become one – even if never say never in life. We did not win the elections, your party won, and it is right that you should be the candidate for president of the Commission. In the coming months, with the hearing of the Commissioners, we will check the compatibility between our programmes and those of the future Commission and we will be intransigent. Parliament's democratic control over the Commission will be strengthened, the debate on the state of the Union will no longer be an exercise in rhetoric, but will become an annual political review of the Commission's actions. Our support for you is not simply an obligatory homage to the new parliamentary democracy. In the last few days, as you know, we have negotiated and presented our priorities to you, as it should have been. We have called for more investment to create growth, a more social Europe, more solidarity with regard, above all, to immigration. You have given answers to our requests this morning, both in the document you have presented to us and in the report you have given us in your speech, which have convinced us. We asked you for figures and concrete commitments. You gave us the figures and also gave us a deadline. He said $300 billion for an investment plan that creates wealth, growth and new jobs and talked about starting in February 2015. You have cleared industrial policy, a word that has long been considered taboo by the liberal. Here, too, there are figures as it commits to bringing the weight of industry on European GDP to 20% by 2020. On social Europe, there are clear commitments to the fight against social dumping, through a revision of the posting of workers directive to establish the principle that the same work in the same place must be remunerated at the same wage. You are also committed to combating fiscal dumping, through the adoption at European level of a common corporate tax base and decisive support for the financial transaction tax. Your programme supports the overcoming of the troika which has done so badly to Greece and the countries subject to financial assistance. It also accepts our request to assess the social impact of national reform programmes and resumes our battle to adopt the anti-discrimination directive, which is currently covered up by unacceptable vetoes, as soon as possible. In his program there is also one of our workhorses: the refinancing and extension to as many girls and boys as possible of the Youth Guarantee. Before the negotiations these points were not in your programme and we are proud of these achievements and we are therefore voting for them. Much remains to be done on many other subjects. We would have liked more clarity on flexibility. You merely recall the Council's position on this matter. We welcome your approach to the likely appointment of a Socialist member as Ecofin Commissioner, but that is not enough. We will be intransigent on flexibility. We believe that those countries which promote ambitious reforms and invest in knowledge and knowledge should not be strangled by accountancy budgetary rules. We want the rules to be respected – let us be clear – but to be at the service of growth. We would have liked more courage on the directive on parental leave, because we need to put European women in a position to reconcile work and family life. We would have liked to see more reference to environmental sustainability in our development model, which must take charge of the care of the planet today. We would have liked to have paid more attention to human capital, knowledge and talent, which represent Europe's true riches. We're not going to let our guard down. We are loyal and demanding interlocutors, we have no right to error. If conservatism and inaction prevail, in five years' time we will be faced with an impoverished, afraid, divided and missionless Europe. That Europe would be doomed to decline. Instead, we can join forces and put Europe back, through our work, at the service of the message of solidarity, union and peace for which it was born. On this path we, from different positions and stories, extend your hand, we give you confidence. It is now up to you not to betray this confidence in the next five years. We will monitor you closely. Good luck, Mr Juncker!

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Mr Juncker, major change does not happen on its own. It needs leadership to drive it; leadership that looks forward, not back; leadership that recognises the challenges of the 2050s – not those of 1950s; leadership that understands the concerns of the people of Europe, who want a Europe of cooperation – not a Europe of centralisation. If you put forward an agenda that opens markets, tears down barriers and decentralises power, then we will stand with you. But if you espouse an old, tired, backward-looking agenda, we will simply offer constructive, positive alternatives. Many of us are looking for you to clarify your position, Mr Juncker. In last week’s hearings in the political groups on issues such as euro-federalism, maternity leave and budgetary rigour, you told the ECR one thing and seemed to tell the other groups another. We need the real Mr Junker to stand up and tell us what you really believe. But in reality, you know and we know that none of this really matters. The deal has been done; the spoils have been shared out. The election which was supposed to end all backroom deals has resulted in the mother of all backroom deals. You know, and we know, that you are likely to be the next President of the Commission. Mr Juncker, we wish you well, but members of my political group will not be able to vote for your today for two reasons: firstly we do not subscribe to the process that brought you here; we do not believe that you have an EU-wide mandate that stretches across all 28 Member States. Secondly, members of my group are not yet convinced that you are the right man to lead the charge for European reform. I hope that, over the next few years, you will prove us wrong. The question I want to put to you is this: do you want your Commission to be the last of an old era or the first of a new era? That is the crux of the leadership we would like to see. We need leadership to reform the budget for a new era, moving away from the idea that a bigger budget means a better budget. Instead, let us have a better budget, to invest – and facilitate investment – in infrastructure, technology and research. Let our children inherit a vibrant economy built for their future. They must not inherit the large debts built up in the past. Instead of focusing on how to raise money from our own resources, let us lead a debate towards how we spend taxpayers’ money better. That is why my group would like to see a dedicated commissioner for budgetary control. We need leadership to build a single market fit for the new era. Yet eight years since the Services Directive, a single market in services is still far from reality. Why do we not sit down with the digital entrepreneurs and ask them about the barriers they face – and then let us tear them down. It is time we delivered a single market for all. Let us look at the energy market and together identify and remove blockages in it; create incentives for consumers to promote energy efficiency, and ensure investment in energy security, new energy sources and more interconnectors to reduce our dependence on regimes in the Middle East and Russia. We need leadership to deliver trade and international development policies fit for a new era: more open, and yet more transparent trade agreements with fast growing economies, but also international development programmes to promote property rights, legal and financial systems, support for entrepreneurs in poorer countries to create wealth and jobs for local people in their countries.  We need leadership to promote better regulations that are fit for a new era; talk to businesses of all sizes directly and ask them what stops them from creating extra jobs, what stops them from creating that growth. We need leadership to address the underlying weaknesses in the eurozone; the significant productivity gaps that are inflicting job losses and crippling levels of youth unemployment in southern Europe. Now, with the euro, many Member States have lost the instrument of exchange rates to address these problems. As a result, we have seen burdens passed from banks to taxpayers, treaties broken and untold state intervention. (Scattered applause) We need leadership on immigration in order to restore people’s faith in both the principle of free movement of those workers who wish to work and contribute to their new host countries, as well as in controlled migration which respects the rights of all Member States – both those welcoming new workers, and those Member States who are losing their youngest and brightest talents to other countries. Mr Juncker, today I have only outlined a few examples of where leadership is needed to build an EU fit for a new era; to build an EU fit for the century ahead of us, not the century behind us; leadership to address the fears and suspicions of our voters towards the EU’s direction; leadership which seeks to fulfil people’s hopes and aspirations for the future. Sadly, Mr Juncker, members of my group do not feel able to vote for you today. But where you put forward an agenda which leads the EU towards the future – to the challenges of a new era – then you will be able to look to us for support in the future.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I think that we can say that it is an historic day. Not because of all the rhetoric we have heard this morning, but because we stand here to elect the President of the Commission and not, as was the case until now, by mainly rubber-stamping the choice of the Council. We participated in that both of us, dear Jean-Claude. This time it is the voters in fact who have the last word and I think that by voting for Mr Juncker today – let us say it, let us say it openly, it is difficult for a certain part of this Parliament to accept it – but by doing so we establish once and for all real European democracy in which the voters are deciding what is happening … (Applause) … and it is not by accident that it is happening. It is the result of the long, long way that we have walked together, it is the result of the Convention we established in 2001 and – let me say it very openly – it is also the result of the perseverance of a number of parliamentarians, of at least two dedicated Europeans that I want to mention today in this debate: Andrew Duff and Elmar Brok, Andrew who is no longer here and Elmar who will always be here in my opinion. But I have to tell you for once he is not here. Normally he is always there – on 199 – but they are still fighting with each other about who in fact invented this proposal in the Convention to elect the Commission by the European Parliament. So my first message of today – I have to tell you, Jean-Claude – is not so much for you. My message today is for those Members, mainly in the big groups, who intend to vote against you. And I want to tell these people in these two big groups, and maybe in other groups, that by doing so what they are doing is intending to side with the anti-Europeans. In fact failing their voters, because what their voters are asking – that is their choice, and the choice made by them fell on Mr Juncker – should be followed. I find the irony of today is that today in fact the anti-Europeans like Mr Kamall would deny the choice of the voters and apparently prefer the old system of backroom deals which Mr Cameron likes so much. So today by voting for you we are giving a clear green light because you have taken on board a number of our proposals. The main proposal is that we have to stop this choice of what I call ‘austerity or growth’ – as though there was an opposition between them. Everybody knows that we need both of them and after five years I hope that you will lead a Commission doing both – that is fiscal discipline on the one hand and a growth pact on the other hand. Because we all know that without fiscal discipline, without respect for the Stability Pact, there is no growth possible in the medium term and we have to accept that. On the other hand we know also that if we want to have growth we have to go beyond the fiscal discipline and we have to have a growth package, as has been proposed now in your programme. The second reason, Mr Juncker, why we are pleased with your programme and we shall support you, is that you also say a number of things on migration, legal migration – finally we are talking about that; it was a forbidden area in the European Union until now – and also about values, and that you will entrust a Commissioner with specific responsibility for the rule of law. However, I have to contradict you on one thing, and that is, whatever the diversity of our constitutional systems or our cultural traditions, fundamental rights are fundamental. We cannot discuss them. If they are fundamental values everybody has to respect them, whatever the traditions are in the European Union.  And the third commitment that you are making, and it was an important point for us, is the fact that you will have a real gender-balanced Commission, and let us hope that you can also achieve that goal. Finally, Mr Juncker, I want to ask you three things because you will now be leading the Commission. Three things: first of all, return – you have said it yourself – to the Community method, because all the intergovernmental arrangements we have made in the last five years were not an example of good governance for Europe. Secondly, my most important point, please don’t do as your predecessor did: use your right of initiative. Don’t start to phone Berlin, Paris and then London and Rome before putting a legislative package on the table of the Council and the Parliament. Do it because your Commission is ready to do it, has the courage to do it and not because there is a decision of the European Council. And do not listen only to the European Council. From time to time – why not every day? – listen to the European Parliament too, because we are equal as an institution. And finally, create again a vision for Europe. That we need. You feel that when you see a number of people, they are lost in Europe, because the vision is no longer there. Create the vision that it is only by more integration of the European Union that we can emerge from the crisis, like we did in the 80s. And if you are doing that I can tell you that you will find us by your side all the way. All 68, Mr Commissioner. (Applause)

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Mr Juncker, I would like to thank mr Juncker for his excellent work and for his excellent work. I am always reluctant to disagree. That's a bit of my guy. But to the general euphoria that we are dealing with a historic day today, I would like to pour at least a few drops into the wine, because I simply do not believe that. I think it has been a step to say: yes, the elections to the European Parliament should also influence who will lead the European Commission in the future. I say no, however, if it now suggests that this is the great victory of democracy. We are at the beginning. Above all, we are at the beginning because far too little has been done with this small first step in recent weeks and months in order to really credibly suggest a democratic development here in the European Union. It is said that a victory has been achieved, and at the same time democracy is reduced to a smattering of posts, to the structure of power between institutions, to the supremacy of the grand coalition. In my view, however, the facade democracy that Habermas spoke of is at best crumbling, and the facade does not collapse. What it takes is to really build democracy from the bottom up and develop it. We need to look more closely at the election result. It is not that the Conservatives won the election. More than three and a half times as many people in the European Union have not voted for the Conservatives – and I am really only talking about those who either did not go to the polls or who, because of the development of the European Union in recent years and the impact that this has had on their own lives, they choose not to promote a future of the European Union, but to say: back to the national answer, back to the national question, which, in my view, is very dangerous. All of us – and this is actually the truth – have lost this election, all those who believe and want the European Union to become a union of democracy, of social justice, of solidarity, for the European Union to be a real force for peace, for the European Union to play a different role in foreign policy, to actually live what was originally formulated as an ideal, as a vision, and that people do not always identify with it. But what happened after the 25th  May happened here is exactly the opposite. That is why I warn against too much euphoria. We have a great deal to do – and to do so as democrats – to ensure that the European Union actually has a vision for the future for the people, and for everyone. The message that was conveyed to the electorate during the election campaign, in the weeks, months, years before, also during the election campaign, was: there is no alternative – no alternative to the policy of market radicalism, the rigid cuts in public finances, the destruction of the developed social models in the EU, the privatisation of public services, the liberalisation, deregulation of social systems and also ecological standards, to subordination to the interests of the European and global organised economy. This is the revival of the former British Prime Minister's famous mantra of "There is no alternative." However, the number of people who have been guided by other ideas – these very people have been pushed in the head, and more and more of them have also withdrawn – is the great challenge that we are facing and which you, Mr Juncker, are also facing and which we believe should be used really intensively. You should take advantage of the question of what caesura you stand for in the European Commission's policy. It cannot be a 'continuing like this' – but that is obviously also the image that is now being conveyed to us – in following the direction of development of the European Union to date. We expect clear answers from you on the changed role of the European Commission in the Troika. We are not content with your saying that the troika should become a democratic instrument. What does that mean? It cannot just be the participation of parliaments. Nor can it be a question of the troika continuing to carry out a policy by which it itself interferes with the constitutional reality of so-called programme states. This has nothing to do with democracy! When people destroy the realities of life, it has nothing to do with democracy! So how do you want to live up to this responsibility? What should come instead? It is not enough simply to say: 'The International Monetary Fund must get out'. What answers do you have – and therefore also with regard to the Commission's role in the troika – on the debt issue, on a debt audit, on the assessment of debt, on debt cuts? How do you want to deal with this? You have also talked a lot – and I am very open to you on this – about the fact that you will place a much greater emphasis on social priorities. We like to hear that, of course. But we have heard this too many times in recent years, we have heard it over and over again. We want to know specifically: how are you going to do this? You are talking about the minimum wage in the Member States. We think that is important. But is this a minimum wage that is poverty-friendly? Are these minimum standards, minimum social standards that are poverty-friendly and prevent poverty? That will be the crucial point. Before I conclude, perhaps one more comment: we have had you in our group. You have answered or not answered questions. However, as has been pointed out time and again, we expect you, as the head of the Commission, to be much more involved in the specific major problems within the European Union. I am thinking in particular, for example, of the situation in Cyprus. Who, if not you, must start talking to Turkey? I also expect this to be the same for the ukraine and Russia issue. You talked about not allowing Russia bashing - we will support you. We need a Europe that includes all states. We do not need new separations. Mr Juncker, we will not elect you as a group. They will not get our vote today. But we will measure what you do on a daily basis, and where you advocate for improved people's living conditions, we will support you.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when twenty-seven million citizens, including six million young people, are not only unemployed, but have no prospect of employment. When 25% of Europeans, or one in four Europeans, are below the poverty line and social exclusion, when 10% of us own 60% of the collective wealth of Europeans, it is the very existence of our societies that is at stake. Dear friends, when the climate deteriorates to the point where we could envisage an increase in global temperatures of more than 6 degrees, when 30% of the world's non-renewable resources have been used in the last thirty years, when a third of the species still alive are threatened with extinction by 2050, it is the very existence of our societies that is threatened. Colleagues, when democratically elected governments are subjected to the daily blackmail of both financial markets and the dictatorship or permanent blackmail of financial institutions deemed too big to be allowed to go bankrupt; when increasingly unelected experts influence, or even write, directly the laws that will apply to all, when in the name of freedom or profit sometimes our privacy and freedoms are called into question, democracy is at stake.  I will say, dear friends, that time is running out. So, will Jean-Claude Juncker be the man? Will you be the man of a union, of a true fiscal union? Because there is no sustainable public finances without controlled spending or sustainable revenue. When a trillion euros escape the public treasury every year through the magic of tax competition, opacity and money laundering, clearly, the soundness of our public finances is at stake. There is no future for a single currency without financial solidarity within this monetary zone.  Will you be the man of a social union? A social union that replaces the dogma of competition between our social protection systems and replaces it with a convergence of our social protection systems? So let us start by setting up wages and minimum incomes across the European Union and finally abolish this initiative that many of you like here and which is called REFIT, which, under the guise of involvement and the elimination of bureaucracy, aims to reduce our social and environmental standards, and all without an American treaty.  Will you be the man of an energy union that is anything other than a gas-buying union, but which is truly the instrument of an industrial policy which, through renewables, energy efficiency and the networking of our energy distribution networks, makes Europe the world champion of greening the economy? Will you be the man of a Europe that, at last, speaks with one voice - and which is not the laughing stock of Vladimir Putin by his action in Ukraine or considered a negligible quantity by all parties and, unfortunately, there are many - to the multiple conflicts of the Middle East?  I will end with the question that seems fundamental to me: will you be the man of a re-democratisation not only of the European institutions but of Europe? Today, it is above all that is being questioned by our fellow citizens. It is about ensuring that our parliaments - not only the European Parliament but national parliaments - are really involved in political decision-making. It is a question of the social interlocutors being involved whenever it comes to matters that concern them. It is also about ensuring that our citizens are more and more directly involved. We have the European Citizens' Initiative, we need a much more participatory democracy. It is, of course, a matter of ensuring that lobbyists of all kinds are referred to their business, that is, the defence of their particular interests. It is not for them to write the laws. Will you be that man? We'd tend, if you'd listen to, to believe it. I sincerely say that. I knew you in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs; I followed you; we are not exactly the same age, but we would tend to believe you. But we also cannot forget who are the supporters of you today? I must note that the three main political families that support you today, in any case, who will support you, are also the political families that have been in power in Europe for decades. If they wanted to do something else, I think we would have seen it before. Besides, I can't help but make the connection with what I heard yesterday from Mario Draghi within Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee. For his part, I have heard only one thing: structural reforms, cutting public spending, reducing taxes, increasing labour market flexibility. Obviously for this gentleman, the things that happened on May 25 have no meaning. In conclusion, I will tell you that we are divided. Because for many of us, the mechanism that brought you before us today is clearly a modest but real step towards a more democratic Europe. I will be careful - and Gabrielle Zimmer is right - to make it the democratic revolution that will, by magic, make Europe a democratic institution, but it is a step in that direction. And so for that a number of us want to support you. But it is true that another important part of our group does not trust, wonders when seeing who supports you today and wonders if you will be able to give flesh to the radical changes that Europe needs. In any event, whatever the outcome of the vote, Mr Juncker, know that every time your Commission tables in this House proposals that respond to the challenges of our time, which want to make Europe once again an area of shared prosperity, an area of sustainable prosperity and a democratic space, we will be by your side. (Applause)

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, if this is European democracy in action, as we have heard this morning, then I suggest we have a rethink. We are told that as a result of the European elections, Mr Juncker here is the nominee. Well I can tell you that absolutely nobody in the United Kingdom knew that when they voted in the European elections it had anything to do with the next nominee. The truth of it is that no voters in any of the countries actually realised what this process was. Mr Juncker’s name did not appear on any single ballot paper. The whole thing has been the most extraordinary stitch-up. The loser, Mr Schulz, gets the consolation prize of being an unprecedented second-term President in Parliament. It is all just a pretence that we are increasing democracy. Of course, I will be told ‘ah yes, but hang on a second, the European Parliament, the elected bit of the European institutions, did actually have a say and did decide whether Mr Juncker was to become Commission President or not’. Well, let us just have a think about the process we are about to engage in.  We are all going to be asked to vote – and we have got one candidate to vote for! It is like good old Soviet times, isn’t it? Surely, democracy means you get rather more of a choice than one. But far worse than that is that it is going to be a secret ballot. You really could not invent it, could you? Hard on the heels of European elections, our voters are not going to know how any of us have voted. I would say to you Mr Schulz, as President of the Parliament, that Parliament should not vote in secret. The whole point of being publicly-elected representatives is that we should be held accountable for our actions to our own voters. To be asked to vote in secret is a huge insult to voters.  (Applause) I would have thought that after the huge advances in the Eurosceptic vote, there might have been a rethink somewhere in Brussels, but clearly that was not to be. Mr Cameron had a brief go and tried to oppose Mr Juncker’s candidacy, but he was busy succeeding with reshuffles in Britain and failing with reshuffles here, and Mrs Merkel of course crushed him because what the German Chancellor says goes in the modern Europe.  So what of our nominee? On the plus side, Mr Juncker, you are a sociable cove with a very much better sense of humour than most people I have met in Brussels, and there is no question that you are a political operator. You have even managed over the last couple of weeks, as you have gone round the political groups, to change the mood music a bit. You have said that you do not believe in a united states of Europe, and that you do not believe in a common European identity, but I have to say I did not believe a word of it. Today you have proven that actually you are stuck back with the ideas of the old Europe. You talked about Mr Delors being a hero of yours. I can understand that from your perspective, but you also talked about Mr Mitterrand and Mr Kohl as being heroes of yours. I would have thought a wartime collaborator and somebody who left German politics under a huge cloud of a massive party-funding scandal should not be the kind of people that we should stand up as great models of virtue in modern Europe today.
