You talked about the need for a common foreign policy and security policy. You talked about the need for a common energy policy. What is clear is that you are going to carry on with the process of the centralisation of powers, which is not surprising because for 20 years you have been a key player in this whole process, which frankly has treated democracy with deliberate contempt. I think the best example is your quote about the French referendum on the constitution where you said if it is a ‘yes’ we will say ‘on we go’, and if it is a ‘no’ we will say ‘we continue’. How is that for belief in democracy? Your dedication to the project is unchallengeable. You have said before that when it becomes serious, you have to lie. So in many ways you are the perfect candidate for a lot of people in this House and I have no doubt that you will get the nomination, but we are being asked to vote for the ultimate Brussels insider, somebody who has always operated with dark backroom deals and stitch-ups, and I have to say that our group overwhelmingly will vote ‘no’. We do not want business as usual. We want real change.  You said at the end of your speech that this is not the time for a revolution. I put it to you that there has already been a revolution. There has effectively been a coup d’état on nation state democracies without people realising, without people realising what was being done to them. After these elections, the Eurosceptic may not yet have a majority in this House, but please do not think we are over, because the vast majority of European people do not want a European state, do not want a European Commission to be the executive, do not want that flag and do not want that anthem. So, you will get elected and we will enjoy doing battle over the course of the next year or two. (Applause)

name: Marine LE PEN
text: Mr President, so on 25 May, the awakening of the European peoples began to lift the old continent out of its torpor. Many nations, particularly the France I represent in this House, have chosen to send a very clear message. (Various movements) Yes, don't displease you, my fellow citizens. They chose to send a very clear message: "No to Europe in Brussels. No to the confiscation of democracy. No to the imbecility of recessive policies. No to decommissioning. No to organized mass immigration. No to diluting our identities. Yes to our nations." The European Union has become a crazy project, a deadly project, from which people are gradually turning away. But as soon as the ballot boxes were stripped, representatives of a political class of another age bowed to the defence of their privileges and obsessed with maintaining the system they defend, ready for all compromises - thank you for giving us proof even today - to defend the interests that are not those of our peoples, no doubt panicked by the result of the elections - it is understood - have chosen to turn their backs on the message democratically launched in the spring. The Conservatives and the Socialists - I am not talking about the liberals, they are the mercenaries - once again, according to their old and detestable habits, immediately distributed the posts, denying all of the desire for change and integrity expressed in the ballot box. Between the EPP and the PES, between the UMP and the PS - to talk about the French parties - this is the usual sharing of the cake. To you Parliament, to me the Commission. I'll get you to vote here, you'll get me to vote there. And do not make us believe that the peoples of Europe would have chosen Jean-Claude Juncker in the European elections rather than Martin Schulz as head of the Commission or vice versa, for that matter. Both are in the countries of the European Union complete strangers who represent nothing and embody nothing! (Applause) Mr Juncker, you have come to the head of an institution to which the patriots in France, but also in many other countries of the European Union, reject any legitimacy. You are not the chosen one of the people. You have not been chosen in any way by the French people, nor by any other for that matter. You have no basis for claiming to be in charge of the lives of our fellow citizens. Your immense and illegitimate power, you will hold it from treaties imposed on peoples despite their vote and from financial and commercial lobbies that make the headquarters of your institution to corrupt it every day more. From that moment on, you represent the archetype of the denial of democracy.  Mr Juncker, I remember one of your statements in December 1999 in a famous German newspaper. You said, "We make the decisions. We put them into practice and wait a while to see what happens. If there is no howl and no revolt, the majority does not understand what has been decided, we continue as we go until there is no more possible return." What an admission! What cynicism! Are you replacing Barroso? Martin Schulz could have taken your place. I don't care. In any case, it is the same guidelines that will guide the Commission's deleterious action. It is the obsession with the end of the nation. A dangerous federalist utopia that will continue to dominate. This is the promise for the peoples of Europe and, in particular, for mine, the great French people, less democracy, more misery, more inequality and dilution of our national identity. After Mr Barroso, you will contribute to the misfortune of the peoples of Europe. You have been put in this position for that. You ran a tax haven, you are now the guardian of the European underworld. Congratulations, Mr Juncker! (Applause) Nice promotion! But your federalist utopia, your obsession with the end of nations, we will fight it, sir. We will fight it here and in our respective countries. We will fight it with all the more energy as we measure every day the progress we are making in our nations. In France and other countries too, patriots are now the most numerous. They are encouraged by their election result, poll after poll, and are waiting for only one thing: to be able to send your Commission and all this European technostructure into the oblivion of history.  In the meantime, we will vote against you. Know that we, elected patriots, will be the most scrupulous observers of your misdeeds, whom we will denounce to the peoples. I will constantly warn the French people of the harmful projects built in Brussels. You are being watched by the people, Mr Juncker. You are under surveillance like anyone who, like you, represents a system in disarray. You did not want to admit the result of the polls but we will be there with all the patriots of Europe to remind you constantly! (Various movements)

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: candidate for the post of President of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I wanted to thank all those, apart from a few, who took part in this debate (Various movements). I have listened carefully to what has been said. During my already long political career, I have always listened to parliaments, including the European Parliament, whose debates and meetings I have practiced for many years. So thank you to everyone who intervened. I understood that if I had taken into account the entire program of each party, the approval of the various parliamentary groups would have been greater, but the assent of the Assembly as such would have failed me, which made me want to be - after having analyzed each other's words - as gentle as possible. I understand that your Parliament will vote by secret ballot. I understand that because Mr. Farage would not want his constituents to find out that he voted for me. (Laughs) The secret ballots are therefore a step, a concession that you make to Mr. Farage. I wouldn't have done it. I thank Mrs Le Pen for not voting for me. I do not want to have the consent of those who reject, who hate, who exclude. Thank you, Madam, for not voting for me. (Loud applause)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. - Today the Parliament elected the new Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, an expression of the great coalition EPP, S & amp; D and ALDE. During his speech, Juncker said he wanted to revive growth and competitiveness through investment, while respecting the strict budgetary constraints imposed by the Stability Pact. Contradictory and cryptic phrases that lend themselves to multiple interpretations: on the one hand, in fact, the flexibility to please the socialists is proclaimed, on the other hand the desire to respect the strict budgetary rules to reassure the popular is reaffirmed. In short, to change everything in order not to change anything. Juncker speaks like a new European leader, wanting to imply that he has never trod the European political scene. Too bad, however, that we are faced with a dinosaur of politics, Prime Minister of a tax haven such as Luxembourg for 18 years in a row, as well as president of the Eurogroup from 2005 to 2013, which for a long time endorsed and carried out the draconian measures of austerities that have brought European citizens to their knees and that now, instead, they say they want to fight. Which Juncker to believe then? Juncker's election is just a grand coalition's political make-up to perpetrate the status quo.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. – The appointment of Mr Junker as the new President of the European Commission is drearily predictable. David Cameron objected to Mr Junker, but was supported by only one of the other EU Member State leaders. It was something of a mystery as to why Mr Cameron objected so strongly to Mr Junker in the first place, given that if he had not been selected for the job the alternative was Martin Schulz, who is just as big a champion of political and economic integration as Mr Junker. Mr Cameron was of course just playing to the gallery back home in the hope that his ʽpluckyʼ opposition to Mr Junker would win him some sympathy and give him a rise in the opinion polls. It did not work. It is obvious to everyone that the course the EU is embarked upon is to create a United States of Europe, and it does not actually matter very much who is President of the Commission because the project is bigger than the man or woman sitting in that chair. If the British people do not like it then their only solution is to demand that Britain leaves the European Union.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - First of all, I would like to emphasize that one of the biggest problems in many countries of the European Union is undeclared work. Illegal work has a negative impact on the economy of Europe as a whole and on individual countries, and on the security of social security systems, destroying the system of financing social benefits and public services as a whole. People forced to work illegally are insecure, vulnerable and live in poverty in their workplaces, both at work and in old age. The Italian Presidency has identified the fight against undeclared work as a key tool for promoting employment and growth in Europe. Do you not think that the fight against undeclared work should be declared one of the EU's strategic priorities for the next term? What specific measures does the Commission intend to take, and when, to step up the fight against illegal employment in the EU? Secondly, do you think that the European Union should not take responsibility in solidarity and set up a special solidarity mobility fund to compensate for the money invested in the education and training of emigrant workers in those countries, including Lithuania, from which most workers have left? This problem is very relevant because the movement of workers takes place in only one direction, i. y. one Member State loses most of its staff and others come in large numbers. Finally, I would like to ask you whether you intend to appoint a Commissioner for Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and how do you intend to address the issue of gender balance in the formation of the new Commission?

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - The economic recipe proposed by President Juncker does not respond to the real needs of the European populations and does not allow for a sustainable recovery. Austerity policies have proved absolutely ineffective, especially in the long run. Europe has lost commercial ground to other major economic players such as the United States, which has rightly reversed the crisis by injecting liquidity into the economic system. Europe continues to throttle peoples with suicidal economic policies that do not allow for growth. We continue to seek a formal perfection of public accounts by sacrificing the incomes of less well-off families. In fact, it is precisely the low-income categories that suffer the heaviest tax levies by keeping GDP growth in check, which would receive a huge boost when the heavy tax burden on low-income earners is eased. Numerous economists have sided in favor of theories developed by John Maynard Keynes and I refer to the "principle of effective demand": the level of production of a nation, its income and consequently employment are determined by consumer demand. When the income of most of them is reduced, then the countries plunge into a destructive spiral.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- Compromise or sovereignty?"The principle of democracy is compromise".This July 15 statement comes from Mr Weber, representative of the EPP.It is radically wrong.The true principle of democracy is the sovereignty of the people, as Article 2 of the French Constitution of 1958 reminds us. For there to be sovereignty of the people, and therefore democracy, there still has to behave a "people", that is to say a nation willing to assume a community of destiny.However, this is not the case with the European Union, which does not rely on the existence of any European people.Mr Weber would therefore have done better to assert that "the principle of the European Union is compromise".Because in the absence of the sovereignty of the people, only a system of incessant compromise can temporarily save an artificial Union that the European nations will end up dismissing.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - European political groups presented their candidates for the presidency of the European Commission, aiming to increase the democratization of the decision-making process, to bring voters closer to those elected and to give greater credibility to the public cause. In view of the electoral results following which the EPP won, it is with great satisfaction that I verified the appointment of Jean-Claude Juncker as future President of the European Commission. I believe that its work program focused on economic growth and job creation could lead the European Union to new times of prosperity and to the creation of wealth so fundamental to improving the quality of life of the 500 million European citizens. I believe that it is essential to pay special attention to the new generations and to work actively to increase youth employment, through concrete measures that encourage labor mobility and allow for faster recognition of skills across the European space.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I support the candidacy of Jean-Claude Juncker for the post of President of the Commission and welcome the holding of this election today to the European Parliament. Jean-Claude Juncker presents a program in line with the current political, economic and financial situation in Europe. The implementation of a 300 billion euro investment plan to fight unemployment will mark the coming years and allow the European Union to return to growth and employment. These investments will focus on broadband infrastructure projects, energy networks and transport infrastructure, thus leading to the reindustrialisation of Europe. In addition, the future President of the European Commission undertakes to fight against tax fraud and social dumping, while ensuring that free trade agreements, and in particular the transatlantic partnership, are not concluded without no matter what price.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: written. - Looking at the work program of the future commission, it is initially positive that the free movement of workers is to be accompanied by the principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place. But we have to go one step further here: wages and working conditions have to be based on the highest social standards. The implementation of the Posting of Workers Directive as requested by the future Commission President is not enough. The existing directive promotes social and wage dumping throughout Europe, as everyone who has looked at it a little more closely knows. If you now say that social dumping has no place in Europe, then within the framework of the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive it must be made clear: We need effective prevention against posting for wage dumping, effective controls and sanctions against letterbox companies, against all forms of social fraud and against abusive ones Use of temporary work and bogus self-employment. We want equality for all employees - regardless of their origin and form of employment, and this at a high level. Here we ask for a clear commitment from the future Commission. But also many other forms of social dumping via company relocations, alleged internships and forms of bogus self-employment must be consistently combated by the new commission.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – The Political Guidelines for the next European Commission presented by Mr Jean-Claude Juncker is a solid document. It is focused on the main challenges of the European Union. The political guidelines are good answers to these challenges for a new start of Europe. However, I cannot agree with Mr Juncker’s statement that ‘ .. no further enlargement will take place over the next five years.’ This statement is a wrong signal sent to countries like Montenegro, the Republic of Moldova and others which have a dream to join the European Union. I hope that the Republic of Moldova will fulfil the criteria to become at least a candidate country in this Parliamentary mandate.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - Today, the European Parliament voted in favor of the appointment of Jean-Claude Juncker as President of the new European Commission. This is an important moment, because, for the first time in the history of the EU, the European Parliament elected - and not just approved - the President of the European Commission, following the proposal of the European Council, according to the rules established by the Treaty of Lisbon. As a representative of the Social Democratic Group in the EP, I would have liked to be able to vote in favor of a Social Democrat President of the European Commission, but today's vote is the result of the vote of European citizens and is proof of the triumph of European parliamentary democracy. It should also be noted that this vote was not a blank check for JC Juncker, but was based on a serious negotiation by the EP Social Democrat Group with Mr JC Juncker, following which, in the program of the future President of the EC, , there are the most important social democratic principles and policies: creating new jobs and reducing youth unemployment, upholding the principle of "for the same work, the same salary", stimulating investment in infrastructure, etc. As an MEP, I will make sure that all these social democratic policies and projects are respected by the new President of the European Commission.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing.- It is commendable that Mr Juncker has promised to resurrect the common defense and security policy, but before that, the Paris arms trade with Moscow should be resolutely stopped.It is inconceivable that the export needs of the arms industry of one Member State should be placed higher than the security needs of the Member States bordering the Baltic and Black Seas.Ceterum censeo, the French still bitterly regret their decision to sell Mistrale to an authoritarian Russia that loves aggression.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - The fate of a united Europe with Juncker at the helm of the Commission is seriously at stake. We need a radical change of course with respect to the policies of austerity and rigor, not the continuation of a bankruptcy policy, where people find themselves stripped of their wealth, traditions and rights in the name of a greedy market too big to fail. States must be able to react by proposing multi-year economic plans based on public spending on productive investments in the real economy. This is why we must act politically to loosen budgetary constraints and to force banks to circulate money in the pockets of citizens and not financial speculators. Unfortunately, the monetary measures taken by the ECB with the TLTROs will not resolve the situation. The regulation of 3 July on refinancing operations does not place effective obligations on how the money requested with this liquidity provision will have to be lent and banks will easily maintain the established benchmarks by investing a very large part of these billions in the financial speculative circuit. The non-change of austerity policies and the scarce collaboration of private banks herald a further deterioration of internal national markets, bankruptcies, increase in unemployment, poverty, social tension up to the very probable victory of nationalisms.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: written. - I hereby protest that the debate on the declaration of the candidate for the office of Commission President did not allow a general catch-the-eye debate. This approach is undemocratic and bears traits of a neo-absolutism of the EU bureaucracy that is remote from the citizenry. Such a Europe may be the Europe you want, Mr Juncker, but it is not a Europe of peoples and citizens. I can well understand why the Presidium is not interested in an open debate: Mr Juncker's ideas about Europe as a country of immigration, the transatlantic free trade agreement TTIP and NATO should not be discussed in depth. The members of this house were degraded to “voting animals” without any say. But: stay seated, shut up and vote - that cannot be the job of a member of parliament. Mr Juncker, I therefore contradict the guidelines you sent out last night for the future of Europe. I don't want a federal state of Europe with the euro as a single currency, I don't want a free trade agreement with the USA, I don't want ever more centralization and a loss of sovereignty! Neither do I want my country Germany and the other countries of Europe to become the continent of forced mass immigration that can only plunge our continent into ruin. Mr Juncker, I assure you: in the interests of the peoples of Europe and their future, I did not vote for you today.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: in writing. - Mr Juncker, your priorities refer extensively to five pillars of EU immigration policy. Given that preventing and tackling illegal immigration will help prevent the loss of migrants' lives, and that strengthening immigration policies should be an integral part of the Union's foreign and development policies, I would like to ask you the following question. Based on the overall approach to migration and mobility and applying the "more incentives for more results" principle, do you intend to consider redefining fiscal policy, especially for the southern Member States, which are also Europe's borders? It is well known that these countries, such as Greece and Italy, are under intense migratory pressures as a result of which they are unable to cope effectively with the new data in the field of migration flow management. Because, of course, migration is a pan-European issue, but it concerns the Eastern Mediterranean countries much more as a problem.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: signed up. - Since spring, I have said that 2014 must be the year of a new beginning for Europe. The election campaign showed us that we need a fresh start. The President of the EC, together with his team, must regain the confidence of citizens in the idea of ​​European construction. The community method is the way. Only by working closely and more honestly with the EP can this goal be achieved. Of the many priorities that Jean-Claude Juncker presented today, three I consider stringent: reindustrialization, investment in infrastructure and jobs for young people. Any political program is valuable insofar as it is fulfilled. We cannot afford to wait five years for a partial success and then say, as in the case of the Lisbon Agenda, that we need to re-evaluate the goals. I believe that the key moment of the new mandate will be the end of 2016, when the MFF evaluation will take place. The decision to reduce the value of the MFF for the first time in EU history was wrong. I hope that the next two years of the new term, through close cooperation between the Commission and the EP, will bring the reassessment of the MFF to empower the EU institutions, together with the Member States, to create jobs and ensure sustainable growth.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. - Today we heard in this House the speech of the nominated (nominated) candidate to lead the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker. A choice decided at the table by the political agreements between the Popular and the Socialists, who have decided to continue sharing power as they please. It is indeed true that Juncker was the candidate proposed by the European People's Party, the major political expression that came out of the polls last 25 May. However, his appointment was decided and formalized only after a very precise agreement with the Socialists, to whom the Presidency of the European Parliament was confirmed in the stainless figure of Martin Schulz. The guarantee of this agreement will be the continuation of the policies undertaken in recent years, which have clearly shown all their criticalities and failures, but which in Brussels and Strasbourg they pretend not to see. Here we are dealing with tradesmen of European politics, people who have played key roles in recent years. The results are there for all to see, yet we continue to persevere in error. I like to judge people for what they do, so maybe Juncker will be a very good President of the European Commission. I wish him so, for the good of all, but I'm not particularly convinced.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - European citizens need a sign of change. No more beautiful speeches are needed. Words are no longer enough to change the demotivation and dissolution dynamic that risks contaminating the European Union. This election must be the result of clear commitments: investment commitments, intelligent management of migratory flows, territorial cohesion, innovation, investment in the new industry and strategic investment in clean energy. The Commission's program for the next term is itself a compromise, but in which the matrix of the social-democratic vision for Europe is clear. It is important that this matrix is ​​subject to permanent surveillance by the European Parliament, that there is an awareness of Governments led by socialists to promote their multiplication at the national level and that active cooperation between Parliament / Commission, which will, as I hope, make this possible. election, have dynamic continuity throughout the term. We are facing a new departure in the process of developing the European project, a new departure that resumes, in a modern framework, the convergence between Christian democracy and social democracy. It is in the name of this new progressive alliance that I will vote for Juncker as President of the European Commission.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the election of the Commission President.(The ballot will begin.) First of all, we have to draw counters who take their places at the ballot boxes from A-B to W-Z.First of all, these counters must be drawn.Then I have to ask whether all the Members in this Chamber have received a ballot.Are there colleagues who have not received a ballot who are here in the room?Did everyone get their ballot?If not, I ask the messengers to take one where MPs signal that they don't have a ballot.I will now start drawing the counters.If I don't hear anything else, I'll assume they'll accept that.(The President draws the following names from a lottery wheel.) Herbert Dorfmann Iratxe García Pérez Jonathan Arnott

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: Mr President, I am not happy to accept scrutinising a ballot which is secret and which should be public. Sorry.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Francisco Sosa Wagner Christel Schaldemose Nathalie Griesbeck Christian Ehler Diane Dodds Goffreda Maria Bettini Adam Gierek Ivo Vajgl (The MPs go to the ballot boxes and cast their ballots.) (The President closes the election at 12:58 p.m.) (The meeting closes at 1 p.m.Until the announcement of the election results.)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! With the announcement of the current election results, a process is provisionally coming to an end which, without a doubt, all of you, or at least most of you, has called a historic process. The European Parliament paid the utmost attention to this ballot and this process, both in the previous parliamentary term, but also in this one. I believe that with the result that I am now announcing, a fundamental change in direction has been achieved in the structures of the European Union. The result of this process is the next President of the European Commission, who will take up office like no other with parliamentary strength. Voting slips cast: 729 Blank voting slips, which are counted as abstentions: 47 Invalid voting slips: 10 According to the EU Treaty, the President of the European Commission must have a qualified majority when voting on his nomination, i.e. the majority of the legal members of the Parliament must reach. That number of votes is 376. For Mr Jean-Claude Juncker, 422 MEPs voted. (Sustained applause) Votes against: 250 The European Parliament has thus elected the candidate proposed by the European Council for the office of President of the European Commission. Pursuant to Rule 117 (3) of the Rules of Procedure, I shall inform the Council of this and request the Council and the President-elect of the Commission to nominate by mutual agreement the candidates for the various posts of the Members of the Commission. I will state your choice, ladies and gentlemen, in a legal act which I have to sign and I will hand over the result of this election to you, Mr Juncker - provided that you now inform me that you agree to it.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President-designate of the Commission.- Mister President!It is not just a matter of courtesy that I am happy to agree to the procedure you have proposed.But please send a copy to everyone.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, this is a crucial issue, a breach of the Rules of Procedure. You have deprived us of the floor and the Bureau has a significant responsibility. The European Parliament group of the Communist Party of Greece is protesting and does not accept the characterization given to a member of parliament that he is speaking on behalf of the non-registered. The non-registered, according to the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, are not a political group. So no one can stand on their behalf or represent them. Any unregistered Member may speak for himself or herself or on behalf of his or her party. That is why it is necessary to clarify the above issue. The European Parliament group of the Communist Party does not belong to any political group and is placed independently in the European Parliament and in all its organs.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Papadakis, I take note of that.You know the regulations that result for the non-attached Members in this House.We will check your wishes.As part of the coordination of non-attached MEPs, every group organized among non-attached members has its say.But I will take your wishes with me.We'll see what we can do.(The sitting was suspended at 1.55 p. M. And resumed at 3 p. M.)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Ukraine (2014/2717 (RSP)).

name: Štefan Füle
text: Member of the Commission on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Madam President, the crisis in eastern Ukraine has not abated; each day we continue to receive alarming reports about casualties. The activities of illegal armed separatist groups remain a source of great concern. Militants still occupy buildings and border posts, keep dozens of people hostage, and threaten the territorial integrity and independence of Ukraine, as well as the security of its citizens. Innocent civilians, including women and children, are caught in the crossfire. We must do all we can to protect and support them. Each civilian killed is one too many. The increase in the numbers of displaced people is also of concern. It underlines the importance of supporting the work of humanitarian organisations. It is essential to provide protection and emergency assistance to all of the Ukrainian civilians who are in need of it – whoever and wherever they are.  There are worrying reports regarding respect for human rights – not only in eastern Ukraine, but also in Crimea, which remains illegally annexed by Russia. Crimea is where the most dramatic changes in the situation of minorities and in the enjoyment of human rights have taken place. Earlier this month, the leader of the elected Crimean Tatar assembly was refused entry to Crimea. This is a clear violation of international law and the European Convention of Human Rights. Allow me to stress that we have not forgotten about Crimea; it will always remain on the radar of our policy until international law is restored. The Ukrainian military campaign in the eastern Ukraine continues. It is every country’s right and obligation to uphold law and order on its territory and to defend its sovereignty and territorial integrity. In these extremely difficult circumstances, we encourage the Ukrainian authorities to maintain a measured approach. This is not about fighting the popular movement in part of eastern Ukraine at a time when the Ukrainian authorities offer discussions about decentralisation and other democratic changes. It is about fighting highly trained and equipped paramilitary forces that have hardly any regard for the needs of the local population. This is exactly the reason why we need to put the protection and well-being of local civilians at the heart of our policy. Diplomatic efforts towards peace in eastern Ukraine must continue. There is an urgent need for all parties to agree on a genuine and sustainable cease-fire in order to create the necessary conditions for the implementation of President Poroshenko’s peace plan. President Putin supported the peace plan in principle; the Federation Council has revoked the authorisation to use military force on Ukrainian soil. However, Russia has not stopped the flow of weapons, equipment and militants across the border; nor has it used its influence over illegally armed groups in eastern Ukraine to stop the violence and get them to lay down their arms. So it is now urgent that Russia takes concrete steps in this direction. We welcome the diplomatic efforts launched in Normandy on 6 June by Ukraine, the Russian Federation, France and Germany, and we hope that this process – as well as the joint Berlin Declaration of 2 July – will contribute to de-escalation and to a peaceful resolution of the crisis. Diplomatic efforts will only be successful if all players show genuine commitment to the process. The European Union welcomes the trilateral efforts of Ukraine, Russia and the OSCE, which could lead to de-escalation and a peaceful resolution, including an agreement on a cease-fire, the release of all hostages, border security, and the effective monitoring of border crossings by the OSCE. Unfortunately, we are not there yet. Tomorrow in Brussels, the Heads of State and Government will again assess the situation on the ground against the conditions put forward by the last European Council and, should it be required, adopt the necessary decisions. In parallel, the European Union supports Ukraine where it can. In March, the European Commission proposed a support package of over EUR 11 billion for the next couple of years. The Commission has also decided to create a Support Group to ensure that the Ukrainian authorities have all the assistance they need to implement reforms. Last week,  The European Union also actively supports the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission and stands ready to further assist the organisation in supporting a cease-fire and border monitoring. At the end of this month, we are also planning to launch a common security and defence policy mission to assist Ukraine in the important areas of civilian security sector reform, police and the rule of law. 26 June 2014 was a historic day for Ukraine and for the European Union. After years of negotiations and hard work, the remaining provisions of the Association Agreement – with its deep and comprehensive Free Trade Area – were signed. This achievement is a powerful symbol of the Ukrainian people’s aspirations to get closer to the European Union, and of the European Union’s commitment towards Ukraine. The Agreement will help to drive reforms and boost growth by offering Ukraine access to the world’s largest market. We now look forward to its swift ratification and subsequent provisional application, so that Ukrainian citizens and businesses can benefit as soon as possible from the new opportunities that the Agreement opens.  Needless to say in this House, the Agreement is not meant to replace Ukraine’s relations with any neighbour; Ukraine can perfectly well have free trade agreements with Russia and the European Union at the same time. The European Union has engaged with Russia in order to dispel any possible misunderstandings in this regard. Last Friday, trilateral talks were held by Commissioner De Gucht with Ukraine and Russia at ministerial level on the effects on Russia’s economy of the implementation of the Association Agreement. An agreement was reached to launch a consultation mechanism with a focus on regulations and standard procedures arising from the implementation of this Agreement. The purpose is to reduce unnecessary tensions by filtering out misunderstandings and by focusing discussions on possible solutions for any remaining concrete issues. Experts will produce a preliminary report no later than 1 September 2014, and a new ministerial meeting will take place in that month. Russia’s threats to take unilateral ʽpreventiveʼ safeguard measures are unacceptable and legally unfounded. We now hope that Russia will refrain from taking any such unprovoked, restrictive measures. Finally, he Association Agreement does not constitute the final goal of European Union-Ukraine cooperation. On the contrary, it provides new opportunities and is an important step in the European Union’s commitment to support Ukraine along the road of transforming this country into a stable and prosperous European democracy.

name: Jacek SARYUSZ-WOLSKI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, in reaction to what the Commissioner has said, I would say that we should give Ukraine a chance. The situation in Ukraine is escalating, but it is being escalated by Russia, which is  increasing the presence of its military forces and its equipment. Contrary to misleading signals from Russia, Russia did not give up its preferred scenario of creating a frozen conflict there in order to block Ukraine’s path to modernity and to Europe. We owe Ukraine – our associated partner – our assistance and our full political and economic support: support for the peace plan of President Poroshenko and also support for Ukraine’s right of self-defence, based on Article 51 of the UN Charter, to regain control over its territory and its borders. Our mediation is not enough. We are on the side of Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity. The EU has special responsibility for safeguarding respect for our values of democracy and rejects the challenging of borders by force through Russian action. Consequently, we need action towards Russia. If Russia does not de-escalate or fulfil the requirements which we put on the table, the Council decision on further third-stage sanctions should be put into motion in sectors like defence, banking and energy. As a sign of our support and solidarity towards Ukraine, Parliament should quickly and swiftly proceed with the ratification of the Association Agreement.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! We finally expect convincing deeds from the Russian government instead of just dissuasive words. Russia has a clear responsibility for the fact that the situation in the eastern regions of Ukraine has escalated to this extent. That is why we also expect Russia to stop the flow of arms and mercenaries across its borders into Ukraine now. We expect them to use their last remaining influence on armed separatist groups, to exercise and call on them to end their illegal activities and to adopt the peace plan proposed by the Ukrainian President. We support the Ukrainian government in its endeavors to ensure peace, security and stability in the country and, in this context too, we urge the proportionality of the means. It is particularly important to us that we continue to support the government in its endeavors to organize an inclusive national dialogue that can adequately take into account the interests of its citizens in all parts of the country. Third, we welcome the activities of various foreign ministers, including my own. We urgently appeal to the High Representative or her successor in office to actively contribute to international efforts to find a sustainable solution to the crisis in Ukraine. I believe that we in the European Union must see that we are actively helping to shape it ourselves again and that we do not leave it to the national foreign ministers. Let me say one last sentence: I believe that the resolution that we are going to adopt together is a good basis for setting out what our real demands are. However, we should do this in a way that does not create new rifts, but rather helps to level rifts.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The European Union is a global player on the international stage. It is extremely important that we diagnose the process we are dealing with very precisely. This precise diagnosis is especially needed by the countries and peoples of my region - Central and Eastern Europe, including my country - Poland. We are with Ukraine, with the Ukrainian nation, in its struggle for sovereign statehood and for the territorial integrity of the country. And for many years we have been warning and warned that the process that has been taking place in the Russian Federation since Vladimir Putin took the presidency for the first time is the renewal of neo-imperial policy, that is, regaining influence in the post-Soviet sphere. The model is very simple - it starts with destabilization, then installs sympathetic authorities, then eventually ethnic cleansing, favorable agreements, such that allow the presence of military or paramilitary bases and forces. This was the case in Crimea in the case of the annexation, when once again in the post-war history of the world, it was decided to unilaterally question the stability of the borders of a sovereign state, despite the guarantees provided by important world democracies. I have a favorable attitude towards the actions taken by the European Union, I believe that a civilian mission is important, but it is far from sufficient. We should go further - in sanctions and in clear diplomatic signals.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first of all, we should salute the Ukrainian people for having organised independent, free and fair presidential elections which brought a clear result: that is the result of democracy. The Russians talked repeatedly about ‘the fascists of Maidan’ and ‘the fascists of the interim government’. But it was not they who won. The extremist vote was very small and this was a very good election result, given also the fact that Crimea was under Russian rule and Russian was intervening in the eastern part of Ukraine. So let us salute the Ukrainian people and their new democratically elected President. Secondly, President Poroshenko has his 15-point programme and we should support him in this because he wants to talk with all sections of Ukrainian society. He wants to talk about decentralisation within one Ukraine – the Ukraine we have all recognised, including Crimea and including, of course, the east – and President Putin should now do what he sometimes talks about. He sometimes speaks words of conciliation but his actions are different. If he really wants peace, President Putin needs to stop all help to the separatists – all help. He should patrol his border and he should come to a free and fair agreement with Ukraine on oil and gas. He should also accept international law, and that means that Crimea is not a part of Russia. Putin now has to accept international law. That is the most important thing, and what we should do is demand Russian action rather than talk and, if the action is not satisfactory, we should impose further sanctions because in the end that is the only way to keep Russia on the right side of the Russian-Ukrainian border.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: for the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, I welcome the fact that this issue is being discussed in the European Parliament. However, I would like to emphasize that serious negotiations should have started much earlier, ie before the conclusion of the Association Agreement, ie before November 2013. The Association Agreement is one of the basic factors that contributed to the open military conflict and the civil war. The European Union, especially its Commissioners, and the European Parliament, which did not intervene in time, played a major role in exacerbating the situation. In any case, we had to monitor the situation, take objective positions and also send observers in time to objectively assess the situation. We are currently facing war on the European continent, at a time when we are remembering 100 years since the beginning of the First World War. At the same time, we are confronted with fascism and a humanitarian catastrophe. Among other things, the unfortunate policy of the Eastern Partnership has driven half a million Ukrainian citizens to seek security and refuge in the Russian Federation. It would be good to ask these people how they want Ukraine. Against this background, I believe that the European Union should set up a commission to investigate crimes committed, such as the shooting of snipers in Kiev's Chreshchatyk, the killings in Odessa and, last but not least, the disproportionate use of force in south-eastern Ukraine. I consider it necessary for the European Parliament to call on the Ukrainian authorities to implement a constitutional reform that respects the historical specificities of each region. The European Parliament must insist on avoiding the ethnic cleansing that unfortunately can be expected. Let me also express my fundamental disagreement with the impending ban on a parliamentary party such as the Communist Party of Ukraine. I consider this step to be a sign of a dangerous move towards fascism ... (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: blue-card question. – Mr Maštálka, when you say that it is a European Association Agreement which is the cause of all the war and military activity and disruption of civil life in Ukraine, it reminds me very much of a comment I have heard from men – that when a woman is raped, she has asked for it. Could you answer me on that point?

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- You must have had a bad translation, I said it was one of the factors.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: blue-card question. – I want to ask about whether there is really time to talk about more urgent measures, because news is coming in about the approaching humanitarian crisis in Donetsk. The leaders of the separatists have said that there will be an evacuation of 100 000 people from Donetsk. What is going on there is a humanitarian crisis and a provocation that could then be a pretext for a Russian invasion. We all know how this pattern is working. I think this is not the time to talk about what we did wrongly earlier on, but it is time to talk about what we can do urgently to help Ukraine stabilise the situation and to stop the provocations.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: We are going to resume our debate (The chairman considers that the question asked does not correspond to a "blue card" question).

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, It actually fits the previous speaker very well. At this point I would like to emphasize once again - also for Russian citizens, who should perhaps also have to hear this debate unfiltered - that the association agreement that we signed with Ukraine was never directed against Russia. That was not aggression against Russia, it was a treaty that we wanted to conclude for the benefit of better democratic and economic development in Ukraine. I am delighted that the association agreements with Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine have now been signed. In view of the meeting last week between Ukraine, Russia and the EU in Brussels, I would say again: you can talk about trade, but the European Union must not allow Russia to veto these agreements, because that would promote the ideas of democratic development actually undermined. I have to tell you, from week to week I am more appalled at how successful Russia’s strategy is to undermine the democratic process in Ukraine through tolerance and now through the increasingly active support of the self-proclaimed separatists, some of whom are criminals. in eastern Ukraine. That is not acceptable. That simply speaks against normal relations with Russia. We don't have to change our relations with Russia. Russia is changing its relations and the way it deals with Ukraine, including us. I want to talk again about the sanctions: we have talked about them so often. When the sanctions started to work - capital flight is a big problem, the ruble has gone down - when you felt the effects, there was a parliamentary resolution in Russia and you have this 100% announcement: We will defend all Russians outside of Russia, if need be, withdrawn. This decision was withdrawn under the pressure of economic conditions. But then the European Union began, through individual member states, to contradict itself and the idea of ​​sanctions. I find it unbearable that weapons are still being exported, that Russian soldiers are being trained in France. This can not be! (Applause) I also find it unbearable that Austria and our Council Presidency in Italy are suddenly pushing South Stream forwards, because this is not a project for energy security, it is a project that is strategically directed against Ukraine! (Applause) I think anyone who wants to influence President Putin has to be consistent at times, and he cannot go into this dispute with four different strategies. Peace is urgently desired, but we can only achieve peace in Ukraine if we make a clear statement towards Russia - not militarily, but with the willingness to change our circumstances. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mrs. Harms!As far as I know, it was a condition on the part of the EU that the Association Agreement be signed with Ukraine, that Ukraine should not be allowed to sign a customs agreement with Russia.If so, I would like to ask what you think of it.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- This topic has been discussed again and again in Ukraine all winter.Ukraine did not want to enter the customs union with Russia.Ukraine wants the Association Agreement with the European Union.The presidential election has shown once again the large majority with which Ukrainians want this.This does not mean that Ukraine would not also like to have good business relations with Russia if Russia were then interested in good business relations.Russia is currently keen to see the reform process in Ukraine fail.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: - As for the situation in Ukraine, it is very important to correctly identify what is happening there. In my opinion, there is an undeclared hybrid war going on in Ukraine, during which one state, I am talking about Russia, has illegally seized part of another state, I am talking about Ukraine and Crimea. Russia continues to encourage and support further military action in the rest of Ukraine and the illegal military groups there. Thus, although unpublished, albeit using unusual methods of war, war is taking place in Ukraine. People are dying there, including civilians. It is important to understand that this is not just a war against Ukraine. This military conflict is a reflection of Russia's current global conflict with Western civilization and Europe. If we do not respond properly, there will be only one question: which European country will be the other? Will it be my homeland Lithuania or other Baltic states, or maybe Moldova or any other country in the world or Europe? And this will happen simply because one of these states or their decisions will not please those who caused and still support the war in Ukraine. That is why the common position of all European countries and coordinated action to stop military action in Ukraine and to find a peaceful solution is so important today. Our common and determined position is important not only for Ukraine and the integrity of its territory, but also for our states, the citizens of our states. Therefore, let us be united and act decisively together today, because tomorrow may be late. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: question "blue card".- Mr Mazuronis, doesn't the association agreement that is being proposed to us between the European Union and Ukraine risk, today, benefiting the latent integration of Ukraine into theNATO and bring about the inevitable return of a cold war in Europe?

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: the answer to the question posed after the blue card was raised.- The signing of the agreement signed by Ukraine was the choice of Ukraine's legitimately elected government.I believe that every state has the right to choose as I see fit.I really don’t think these steps, rather than the aggressive actions of another state, i.y.Russia's position poses a potentially serious threat to the stability of Europe and the security of all our states.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I am somewhat dismayed when I see on the one hand that there is a warlike danger at the gates of Europe in Europe, and on the other hand I see here that 80% of the mandataries do not even take part in the debate and probably assume their responsibility the cafeteria - a bad sign for the European Union. The second thing I ask myself is, above all, as far as the speakers from the majority groups are concerned, that obviously no research is being carried out here on the things that are read from the slip of paper and one gets the impression that the majority of this is European Embassy of the United States of America instead of a confident European Parliament. Please remember what happened on the Maidan, how a supposed democracy movement, which was supported by the European Union, suddenly handled assault rifles and machine guns and subsequently a government was pushed away, not with the required quorum in the Kiev Roda of 75% that would have been necessary, but below it. Here, too, people closed their eyes to this wrong decision of a coup. As a result, people closed their eyes when suddenly 400 Blackwater mercenaries from the US administration were discovered in the Ukraine - according to a report by the German magazine "Der Spiegel". I ask the European Union not to take the American position unilaterally, but, on the contrary, to assume a neutral role, to enable a tripolar negotiation - the Russians, the Ukrainians and the Europeans on the other hand. It's about the population, it's about avoiding the dead and securing peace. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Madam President!Interestingly, Mr Vilimsky, you mentioned that there was an “alleged democracy movement” on the Maidan, that the government was put off.Have you been there?My colleague Rebecca Harms was there - quite often.She talked to people, she has known them, not just now, but for years, and many others in the house.You and your colleagues, from the FPÖ and others, were at the invitation of the Russian government and Russian organizations in Crimea and observed the so-called referendum there.Where is their actual view of things?You weren't at the Maidan.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mrs Lunacek!I was the chairman of the Austrian-Ukrainian parliamentary friendship society for eight years.I brought relief supplies for children to Ukraine.I brought an Austrian daily newspaper to the Ukraine to help the animals in Ukraine in the run-up to the euro.And I have a lot of interlocutors.If you criticize today that we caught our eye on the ground in Crimea while you were sitting in Vienna or wherever and reading some newspapers that are the truth to you, then I am more of the opinion that II am on site, inquire there and use these things as the basis of my argument instead of anything that someone tells you.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues! Mr. Vilimsky! I was there in Parliament on the day when Parliament decided by a large majority, in accordance with the agreement, to reinstate the 2004 constitution. I didn't see assault rifles, I saw happy people who saw democracy, people who demonstrated under the flags of Europe. That is to say, people who have obviously understood democracy, while your arguments are supporting the Putin regime, which is not free. You should be ashamed to take up such positions here! What is clear is that the people in Ukraine made a decision in the presidential election: their friends like the fascists together got less than 10%. A decision was made in favor of democracy and freedom for the West. The decision has to be made in Kiev, in Ukraine, not in Brussels, not in Washington and not in Moscow. We only want that: The Ukrainian people must have the freedom of choice! We make an offer of an association agreement. Each country is free to decide whether it wants that. We will ratify this quickly as a parliament - as we did with Georgia and Moldova. But I would like to make it clear: this is not directed against Russia. This has no trade-policy disadvantages for Russia. The disadvantages arise only from Russia, which is imposing unilateral punitive measures in trade policy against countries that are not politically compliant. This is unacceptable! That must be rejected! And about what's going on in eastern Ukraine: As long as there are Russian arms deliveries, as long as you have rockets with which you can shoot down planes over six kilometers high - this is not just that of rioters - we have to say: as long as Russia pursues this policy , Russia must also expect that sanctions can be imposed. I think it must be clear: every people must be free to make their own decisions. We should help the Ukrainians - perhaps with OSCE groups, the observers - so that control of the Russian-Ukrainian border can be regained so that this border cannot be abused by arms shipments into Ukraine. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: question "blue card".- I would just like to say to Elmar Brok, when we talk about a fascist in this case Svoboda and Pravy Sektor, that they were supported by the West and the United States, even if subsequently, indeed, they lostin the elections.So, be careful when we threaten and when we criticize our friends and those who try to put the truth of fascist.This time, as if by chance, the fascists are on the side of what you wrongly call the West.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- At the Maidan and in all the talks, the wish of all political forces - the large majority in Parliament, entirely the Maidan - was of the opinion: We want human rights, a rule of law in which there is no arbitrariness.If you call that fascism: you are one of those people who say in Russian terminology that anyone who was against Russification, against Sovietization, is a fascist.I cannot agree with this definition.Nobody was followed there.No Russian has been persecuted in Ukraine for their language - these are all myths.And for this reason it should be made clear that this propaganda cannot be followed.You should be ashamed of the people you are in the boat with!

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: Madam President, there are two main questions for which we desperately need a well-articulated answer in the future, bearing in mind the recent past. Firstly, we must measure how sincere and real the Russian commitment to de-escalating the situation is, in view of the developments in eastern Ukraine – regarding which you, Mr Commissioner, and other colleagues mentioned the real involvement of Russia. Secondly, we need an immediate solution to the energy security problem. The solution is not to build other pipelines to bring Russian gas to Europe – as Austria and Hungary are doing now – but to find different sources and different routes. I hope that the next High Representative for Foreign Affairs in the next Commission will not only find the answers to those questions but also build up a more coherent and more articulated strategic approach.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: On the press telexes I read that today again Ukrainian soldiers are killed at the border with Russia in attacks by pro-Russian militias. There are also civilian casualties every day. Both countries accuse each other of border violations. Everyone sees that it doesn't take much more to escalate this conflict. The Union must definitely get stronger and do everything it can to silence the weapons. That can only be done if we stop Russia from implementing its Crimean scenario in eastern Ukraine, if we get Russia to stop destabilizing the country. Putin says he wants peace, but his actions prove otherwise. In the meantime, Mr Füle, I would like to draw your special attention to the pressing problem of the tens of thousands of refugees. They are in Russia, they are in Ukraine itself. They are not so visible there, but they are there, tens of thousands of them, and they are causing a humanitarian crisis. They depend on charity and on their own. And that takes place at our borders! It will not be long before we ourselves suffer the consequences, if we do not see the urgency of it. The association treaty with the European Union may offer long-term prospects, but citizens are not buying anything for that now. [The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: blue-card question. – Well it is all just wonderful isn’t it?  I am just hearing a lot of wind here. No-one is coming up with solutions. We are not talking about some sort of tin-pot state, we are talking about Russia, which lost 80 million people in the last century: the siege of Leningrad, the battle of Stalingrad, a revolution. Sanctions are not going to work, militarism is not going to work. So come on, give us some answers, because nobody is putting forward constructive proposals.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: "blue card" answer.- A reference to history can of course never justify what Russia is doing at the moment: operating in a kind of gray zone.This cannot and should not, it is against any international agreement.The referendum in Crimea is a mockery of the concept of referendum itself.This can never be justified.Europe must indeed come out stronger.Then Europe must indeed think of sanctions that have an effect.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Mr President, it seems to me now that the situation in Ukraine is still escalating and that Russia is probably already moving into some kind of conquest of eastern Ukraine. One problem here is, and has been referred to in many speeches, that there is now a great deal of propaganda in this war as a tool. This is a pretty new situation, and I would like to ask Commissioner Füle what tools we have to act in this situation, to pass on information based on verified sources? You yourself said that you are trying to avoid unnecessary tensions by filtering out any misunderstandings about the situation, but what are you doing about such outright propaganda, which is then likely, for example in Russia, to justify President Putin's actions? In this situation, for example, can we support independent civil society, independent media in eastern Ukraine, Russia? What can we do? It is quite clear that if Russia does not stop talking about one thing and doing another, then we are in a situation where next-degree sanctions are needed.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: Madam President, I am quite sure Members of the Parliament will join me in expressing concerns for those suffering in the ongoing conflict in Ukraine and in hoping for a quick resolution. But it is my firm belief that the EU contributed to starting this conflict in the first place and that signing an agreement for deeper political ties with the Ukraine was simply irresponsible, especially while taunting Russia with sanctions. What a crazy way to go about sitting on the fence, as some in the Parliament have demanded we do.  Do you not realise that much of Europe is dependent on Russian gas for winter warmth and that most of the constituents I represent are already struggling to pay their energy bills each month, without the added cost of increased wholesale prices? Are you all so arrogant and out of touch as to think that the EU’s actions to-date have done nothing more than to throw fuel onto the flames of conflict, an especially dangerous act in a situation that threatens to take us back to the bad old days of the Cold War? To me, it seems that the EU’s policy on the Ukraine seems to be more about adding another country to its dictatorial empire in a political blitzkrieg that does nothing more than further its own selfish agenda, no matter what the costs. (Applause) This is despite the potential for conflict escalation and spill-over that threatens the security and stability of the entire region and despite the increased security risk to the UK which we already have seen. Another conflict is the last thing the United Kingdom needs, coming on the back of over 20 years of the Labour Party’s wars and at a time of savage Tory cuts to our already overstretched armed forces. In UKIP we do not subscribe to the Clausewitzean theory of war being merely the continuation of politics by other means. War is never desirable. UKIP wish to see peace between all peoples brought through democracy, diplomacy and meaningful dialogue. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- I have a question for my colleague from Great Britain: why, while respecting the sovereignty of Great Britain and representing a party that attaches so much importance to this value, at the same time does not respect the sovereign decision of Ukraine?

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: blue-card answer. – We respect the sovereignty of all your countries – and actually I think that talking about respect for sovereignty in this place is a bit of a joke. (Applause)

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, I would like to make a general comment on the situation in Ukraine, which has had a significant impact on the European Union's strategic cooperation with Russia. In my view, the policy pursued by the European Union in Ukraine was wrong. Reasons for political expediency sparked ethnological differences among the population of this country, a peaceful demonstration became the occasion for bloodshed and people who until then lived and worked peacefully began to fight among themselves. What happened in Ukraine is very likely to happen in any country of the European Union where there are religious and ethnic minorities. That is why the European Union must pay special attention to the sensitive issue of minorities. It must not be indifferent when their rights are violated, but also its policy must not incite, provoke and incite minorities to revolt, because then there is a risk that a third country outside the European Union will intervene and create problems in the European Union. If this happens, the European Union itself risks becoming a source of unrest and controversy between its states.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Madam President, the last time we discussed the situation in Ukraine in this forum was three months ago. Since then we have had some very good news. First of all, the election of a president under very good conditions, with free and fair elections despite the difficulties in the East. Second, the presentation of a fifteen-point peace plan by the elected president. Thirdly, on June 27, we saw the signing of the remaining parts of the Association Agreement with Ukraine. Of course, we also have bad news. First of all, the ceasefire plan imposed by Ukraine was not respected by the rebels in the east, which led, as we know, to the army offensive. Ukrainian to defend the territorial integrity of the country. There are also people who regard the revocation of the Federation Council's authorization to use force in Ukraine as good news. But we must not be naive and believe that Vladimir Poutine has abandoned his plans for Ukraine, especially since he has other legal bases to continue his aggression. Make no mistake, it would be a monumental mistake to believe in Russian propaganda, a very dangerous mistake for the security of Europe and for the development of Ukraine. We have to admit, I believe, that we are at a critical point in this crisis and Ukraine needs our support more than ever. In recent days, moreover, both President Poroshenko, NATO and the American administration have warned that Russia continues to provide heavy weapons, equipment and that it still allows separatist militants to enter Ukraine freely. We must therefore remember not to release the pressure on Moscow.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Madam President, after the annexation of Crimea, which could be used as a launch pad for further military action in the area, Eastern Ukraine has been transformed into a magnified Transnistria whose instability is being used by Russia to try both to control Kiev and to prevent its efforts to implement the association agreement with the EU.  The situation in eastern Ukraine is increasingly alarming. It appears that Russia is concentrating forces again on the border and has resumed military support to the pro-Russian forces. New weapons systems have entered the scene, border clashes provoked by attempts to infiltrate heavy weapons from Russia are multiplying, manifestos calling for the liberation of the rest of the Ukraine and the reinstatement of socialism are being circulated, the Russian TV 1 channel is in the middle of a total propaganda war against Ukraine, and the information war against Moscow acquires a new dimension every day.   In the meantime the EU appears to have considerably reduced its visibility on the diplomatic scene. If we do not properly turn our attention to Ukraine now, Ukraine faces the risk of becoming an empty shell, a state only in name, and that is not in our interests.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Mr. Chairman!Ladies and gentlemen!I've been to Kiev, I've only been to Maidan six times since November.I know that is very little, but I have the impression that many of the speakers who have spoken in our Parliament today have never been there, and say what they say only on the basis of media appearances.And there is nothing to laugh at, because I saw young people in Ukraine aged children and grandchildren of those who speak here today who fought for the sovereignty of their country.And if they ask me about this debate in our Parliament today, I will exercise my right to remain silent, because I do not want to quote the nonsense I heard here.It is the duty of the European Union to support the Ukrainian people, because they are part of European culture and will become part of political Europe in the future, and let no one say otherwise.It's just a shame to say that ..

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: Ukraine's choice, born and raised earlier this year in Maidan - to live freely, democratically, to embark on political and economic reforms - was not in line with Russia's future plan. Russia has taken all kinds of political, diplomatic, economic, military and other actions to destroy Ukraine's statehood and the free choice of the nation. Initially occupied and annexed, Crimea, later financially and militarily backed by separatist-terrorists, began military action in the southeast of the country. We are witnessing an innovative war: the war has not been declared, but the number of victims is growing every day, there is no front, but foreign territory is being captured, and there is a relentless information struggle in diplomatic relations. I call on Russia to be part of the solution, not the initiator of the conflict. The war against Ukraine has dangerously weakened the foundations of European security, restored mistrust and the red light of threats, and given rise to the risk of regional terrorism and new frozen conflicts.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: Officer!Fellow Members!As this is my first contribution to the European Parliament, allow me to greet you and wish you all good luck with your next work.(The Member will continue to speak in English)

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the wave of violence still affecting the Ukrainian people, such as the Odessa pogrom, requires us to reflect on the legitimacy and real capacity of government of Poroshenko and his ministers. We ask ourselves how much of this tragedy is not rather a consequence of Western strategic and commercial interests linked to the transit of Russian gas and to the Ukrainian Shell gas fields that too many hands would like to exploit without obstacles and regardless of economic, human and environmental costs. Europe cannot afford a conflict over energy resources right on its borders, for ethical reasons and because Russia still possesses these resources in an economic form in such abundance as to give Europe the time it needs to become independent of sources fossils. We therefore believe that the Association Agreement signed with Ukraine was an early and imprudent step and we ask that Europe remain as neutral as possible and to activate all possible means so that independent observers can be sent to ascertain the responsibilities and the real initial instigators of this bloody civil war with unpredictable consequences.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, our already misinformed Parliament once supported the war in Iraq. Our Parliament approved the NATO bombings for the respect of minorities and the right to self-determination in Kosovo. Our Parliament today suffers from the same disinformation with the complicity of European governments and the action of the United States; the same media manipulation with, in addition, this time a policy of double standards, double standards, double measures, in Ukraine. If we followed the logic of the previous actions and votes, Kiev should be threatened with the worst reprisals, but this time our Parliament approves Kiev and lets it quietly slaughter its civilian population. We must pull ourselves together! Let us immediately propose a real ceasefire, let us put OSCE observers and interposition forces as proposed by Russia, let us support in Ukraine a federal constitution with a special status for the eastern regions. In short, let's support peace!

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: Madam President, Commissioner Füle, thank you for recalling very factually what still attests in the reality of Ukraine today, of the Russian strategy, deliberate, to fuel instability in eastern Ukraine, with continuous flow of supplies to the separatists, the dispatch of mercenaries, many so-called Russian-speaking Ukrainian separatists who are in fact Russian citizens. All of these facts need to be remembered - you did well to do it. This deliberate strategy of Moscow is obviously also based on the violation of the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine. It is also based - and this is very serious and we often forget to recall it - on Russia's international and multilateral commitments signed in 1994 in the Budapest memorandum. So obviously in the light of all these elements, one can still wonder why the European Union does not finally adopt the policy of firmness that it declaims at length of advice and finally adopts this third measure concerning sanctions. However, alongside these elements on the ground, there is still a political and diplomatic process that exists. I agree with what my colleague Preda said earlier. We have legitimate authorities in Ukraine, which are also recognized as legitimate by Moscow. This is a big step forward. We have a dialogue with Moscow, which exists, particularly in terms of trade measures. You recalled the existence of these high-level discussions. Then there is a diplomatic process with a contact group and a very important role for the OSCE. So, the European Union must support this political and diplomatic process with all its might, simply by not forgetting a red line, which is that this diplomatic and political process cannot be done to the detriment of sovereignty and the territorial integrity of Ukraine.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Speaking of Ukraine today, pessimists claim that post-revolutionary Ukraine has fallen into a hopeless civil war, sponsored by Russia. Some add that Russia's goal is no longer the annexation of parts of Ukraine but the permanent destabilization of the entire country, the blockade on the European path and the strengthening of the Union's energy and thus political dependence on Moscow. It is precisely because of these assessments that the recent signing of the Brussels-Kiev Association Agreement is to be welcomed. This has largely removed dilemmas about Ukraine's future. It is not a vassal part of some post-Soviet space but a country in the regular process of joining the European Union.
