If there has been fatigue with enlargement, if there will be no enlargement of the Union in the next five years, there must be no fatigue in providing our support to the Ukrainian people to gradually achieve their key goal - EU membership. I believe that the Association Agreements signed at the same time with Moldova and Georgia have also cast shadows on the question of their future. So called. GUAM countries have been exposed for too long to the negative consequences of tense relations between the new East and the new West, as well as the disastrous rule of domestic corrupt regimes.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: Today, we have heard the promise of the President, the future President of the Commission, Juncker, that Europe needs a more active role in foreign policy.We have had quite a bit of it now as well and Mr Fühle has shown a lot of initiative in his tenure.However, I think that at this point, we should tackle the problem of how to stop violence by all means.How to stop violence as a means of resolving disputes on either side.The other thing we need to do is to further support Ukraine's democratic independent path, Ukraine's European path.And finally, because time is passing me by, it is wrong to see in Russia only a potential enemy, in Russia we need to see a neighboring country, and a dialogue must be established with neighboring countries, even when it is difficult.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen!In the whole debate I miss the question: How can you de-escalate between Ukraine and Russia?Instead, I keep hearing the question and call for sanctions.But sanctions are not an instrument of de-escalation; they are poison in cooperation between European peoples.I think Russia is as much a European people as Ukraine.Mr Juncker said this morning: “I greet the people of Ukraine who are a European people and belong to Europe”.That, dear ones, naturally also applies to Russia, which is part of Europe - in contrast to the United States of America.I also ask you: what has the EU done so far to clarify the backgrounds and perpetrators of the human rights violations in connection with the Odessa massacre?I look forward to your answers.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: After the provocations of the last days on the Russian-Ukrainian border, after the Russian armed forces invaded the Donetsk region, we are probably a few hours or a few days away from a real war between the nuclear power of Russia and Ukraine. Putin's goal is to make Ukraine a failed state. But let's not entertain illusions! Putin will not stop with Ukraine. His dream is to regain control of the entire former Soviet empire. That is why I am calling on you, fellow Members, to face this harsh truth, so that there is an urgent need for third-level sanctions, including an arms and technology embargo against Russia. Such a decision would force Russia to stop and abandon its revanchist goals. At present, Putin is the main winner from Europe's inability to act together, but the real loser is Europe, which we united with great determination and great political will after the collapse of the USSR. Ukraine also has the right to belong to this Europe. Thanks! (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: blue card issue.- Mrs. Kalniete!You talked about sanctions against the Russian Federation, but you know that the country I represent and you, Latvia, is a border country - one that can expect a backlash from Russia - a country whose economy can suffer greatly from Russia's backlash.Speaking of sanctions, are you aware that this blow will also be in the direction of the Baltic States and Latvia?Thanks!

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: answer to the blue card question.- I am aware that this blow will be in the direction of us all, the whole of Europe.However, a much bigger threat to Latvia, Estonia, Lithuania, Poland and other countries is Russia's growing aggression.Then, if something irreversible happens, the price that Europe will pay economically is much higher.We have other means at our disposal to diversify Europe's energy supplies within a year and a half, and we must act immediately to create a European Energy Union.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you very much Mr. Chairman! In my speech, I would like to refer to the speech of Commissioner Füle and also to the motion for a resolution on Ukraine. The first thing that is very important - the postulate: stop fighting immediately, stop killing people, stop destroying the country. Two - enough chaos: start introducing stabilization - both economic and social stabilization. Three - Ukraine should be offered an economic program, both in terms of this material sphere and new institutional solutions and legal solutions - then our 11 billion may make a lot of sense. I also like the demand to ensure continuity of energy supplies and energy sources to Ukraine at a reasonable price. What is important - our message, which we should send to Russia, is that the case of Ukraine is a matter in which the European Union is a partner, not individual states, and that here the community method is the most important, not intergovernmental. By the way, I do not quite understand why two foreign ministers have been traveling to Ukraine recently, and the Polish minister of foreign affairs has "dropped out". Thank you for your attention.

name: Javier NART
text: Mr. President, politics is not the art of the ideal, but the art of the possible. From the certainty that Ukraine must have the guarantee of its sovereignty and its territorial integrity, there is a third fundamental element called security. And security has two components: objective security — real security — and perceived security, which is subjective security. Here we are talking about Russia as if Russia were any other country; and reality — not ideality — determines that we have to have a special consideration with an extraordinarily important neighbor in the strategic, economic, and military terms. I am surprised that we are absolutely logical, for example, in our response to the United States - which has shown extraordinary aggressiveness in violation of fundamental rights in espionage matters, which have been discovered twice - and that, instead, we treat Russia as if Russia were any other country. The moment we turn "ideality" into reality, we are violating reality. Consequently, I consider that it is absolutely necessary that, out of respect for the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine, we have common sense to deal with a fundamental issue, which is our security with respect to Russia and Russia's security with respect to its own environment. Let's have common sense.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Mr President, in Ukraine we need a ceasefire that is respected as soon as possible, to put an end to so many deaths and so much suffering. It is imperative that Russia - as has been said - is seriously involved in the resolution of the conflict and exerts its real influence on the secessionist rebels, especially in Donetsk. Otherwise, many more lives will be lost in that city. The Federation Council's authorization for the Russian army to intervene on Ukrainian soil was revoked, but Russia has much more to do. The border cannot remain open to arms trafficking and armed groups. Effective measures have to be taken. The double track of threat of more sanctions and of diplomatic dialogue with Russia is inevitable. Russia has to cooperate more in the solution of a crisis that it itself contributed to unleash with inappropriate behavior and contrary to international law and the 21st century. Finished. I am pleased that the first triangular consultations took place last Friday on the impact for Russia of the European Union-Ukraine Association Agreement. Commissioner Füle has referred to these talks, but I would also like a greater presence and of course greater visibility of the European Union and the European External Action Service in solving the problem in the dialogue and negotiation forums, and I I am referring to the two existing ones: the Contact Group and the so-called 'Normandy format'. I would like greater visibility of the European Union.

name: Boris ZALA
text: Through the Vilnius process, the European Union has become a real geopolitical player, with great attractive force.The paradox is that the EU itself did not expect this.But Russia understood it all the faster.The EU's attractiveness has shattered Russia's geopolitical game of sphere of influence.Russia's foreign policy has sought to operate within the borders of the former Soviet Union through a system of spheres of influence.The Vilnius process shattered this plan and severely paralyzed.It is from this perspective that we must see the situation in Ukraine, but also in Moldova and Georgia.In all three cases, we may encounter a Russian attempt to resolve the situation by military force.The European Union must prepare for this, diplomatically but also militarily.This also requires a completely new approach to EU policy towards Russia.This is a new challenge for us Members, for AFET, but also for the Commission.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Mr. President, Commissioner Füle, thank you for your report. Ukraine and the crisis in Ukraine today represent a real test of the credibility of the European Union's foreign policy and its comprehensive approach, from our values, violation of international law, respect for Ukraine's territorial integrity and integrity to economic relations, enlargement policy, energy policy, relations with strategic partners. Coming from Croatia, it is not difficult for me to recognize what is happening in Ukraine today. Parallels with the aggression on Croatia in the early 1990s and what is happening today in Ukraine, the support for the rebels by the Russian Federation in relation to what was in Croatia and the support of Serbia are quite clear and very transparent. What we need to do today is to continue to put pressure on the Russian Federation with further restrictive measures, to pursue a coherent, clear foreign policy of all actors, led by the High Representative and the Commissioner, but also to make it clear to the Association Agreement to improve and speed up the ratification process. and support President Poroshenko's peace plan with the right of Ukraine to exercise control over its territory.

name: Kati PIRI
text: A special moment, because my first contribution to the plenary debate deals with a problem that has occupied many in Europe in recent months: the future of Ukraine. It is important that violence in the east of that country is stopped as soon as possible. A military solution to a political problem puts a mortgage on Ukraine as a whole. A political solution means talking. Ultimately, everyone should see the need for dialogue and the Kiev government should also be ready for far-reaching decentralization. Then about the role of Russia. In recent weeks, the EU has held intensive consultations with Russia on the consequences of the free trade agreement between the EU and Ukraine. Consultation is good and where there are bottlenecks solutions must be found. But let it also be clear: Russia cannot dictate how a bilateral agreement is implemented. Moscow will have to accept that Ukraine has made this choice and cannot therefore impose unilateral interpretations of the trade agreement.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mister President! I think we have to call the child by name. In eastern Ukraine the violence has been carried across the borders by Russia. Without the tanks and rocket launchers and the fighters who cross the border there every day, there would be no violence there. Putin is escalating the situation every day instead of de-escalating. He's testing us to see how far he can go. We need a strengthening of the international presence at the borders. The OSCE must finally be present there with a major mission. Then Russia too has to be opposed to what is happening there. I think the EU must also stand by its decisions. It had already been decided to implement the third level of sanctions if it does not stop its destabilization. Then there were only eleven people who were also put on the black list, who do not come to visit us anyway. I think it is now very important that we make it clear to him that he cannot continue this destabilization. In my view, unfortunately, alongside an OSCE mission, this only works if we finally implement the third level of sanctions. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Yannick JADOT
text: question "blue card".- Mr Gahler, you did indeed speak of the Russian arms arriving in Ukraine.I would like to know what you think of the French, German or Italian weapons that are going to Russia today.Do you think, for example, that France should end the export of two Mistral ships with a strong transfer of military technology to Russia?Wouldn't it be more appropriate today, since we need a European defense policy, for these ships to go and strengthen a European defense policy rather than Russia, which is organizing civil war on our borders?

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I will tell you quite frankly: that would be my ideal solution if we, as the European Union, were to buy up these two ships together, in order to then find the refugees or the smugglers in the Mediterranean, for example by reinforcing Frontex with helicopter carriersdo.I also know that this is not possible under the current treaties.But one might find oneself willing to actually consider using these two helicopter carriers for a European purpose.I would like that best.Because I also see that costs have arisen and that the companies that produced this should also get their money.But that shouldn't benefit Russia.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: Mr President, I am pleased to make my first speech since being elected as Coordinator Spokesperson for the Socialist and Democrat Group on Foreign Affairs, to renew my warm acquaintance with Commissioner Füle and, of course, to help bring this Parliament’s attention, at the beginning of our new parliamentary term, to the crisis in Ukraine. This is a crisis which has critical humanitarian consequences in the country and on its borders, and far-reaching political consequences for the country, the Neighbourhood, and for Europe itself. I join all colleagues who have spoken in favour of a peace plan, and I add my explicit support for the proposal for a collective ban on arms sales. I call on other groups to support the S&D text calling on all sides to respect international and humanitarian law. I say to our EPP colleagues that there is a proper debate about third stage sanctions. We support the recent decision to put separatists on the black list, but what we call for today – and what the Council might decide tomorrow – has to be credible, or we will undermine our own position. The Kharkiv Human Rights Protection Group has called EU sanctions ineffective. We owe it to them most of all to find solutions which represent a true consensus for us but which can be effective for them.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: I would like to thank you, Commissioner, for the diagnosis that you presented to the European Parliament as to the causes, effects and what has emerged recently. You can not declare war, but fight it. It is possible to interfere with the territorial integrity of the country by sending unidentified soldiers. We have to do all of this and we say that you have to put STOP. Ukraine has done a lot: it has elected a president, it has a government, it is trying to stabilize the internal situation - which is not easy. Let us note that, after all, certain time barriers have also been set up there to allow for a peaceful solution. We are concerned. The association and trade agreement is ready - it needs to be ratified now. The economic situation in Ukraine will not bring any quick results for the population, we, as a Union, should also send a signal that we take Ukrainian citizens seriously, that we respect them. That is why I think that progress on the visa regime would send such a clear signal. Let's do it, we are very close to this situation. At the same time, I would like to say to my British colleagues: we perfectly remember what Yalta was and what the situation in Central and Eastern Europe faced us. Do not lecture us that we should respect the policy of gas supply and "hot water taps" more than the territorial integrity of a dependent country (the speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- (no beginning of the question) that we are influenced by aggressive Russian propaganda.However, there is a much more dangerous thing.It seems to me that the vast majority of those who speak here do not realize that they are influenced by their own very aggressive and deceptive propaganda.This is much more dangerous because it gives a completely false picture of the situation.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- I would like to reply to the deputy that I am not influenced by false propaganda in any way, but this is how I assess the right of the Ukrainian nation to have its own independent state, that it also has the right to the integrity of this state, that it also has the right to choose its futurethat he would also have the right to whom he wants to make alliances with and what path he wants to choose.This is an integral right of the Ukrainian people.I respect it.Poland also had this choice.Thank you very much.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Dear Mr. PRESIDENT! Fellow Members! As this is my first speech, allow me to introduce myself. I live in Transcarpathia, Ukraine, and have won a seat on the FIDESZ-KDNP list. I am therefore the only Member of the European Parliament who is also a Ukrainian citizen. That is why I am glad that the situation in Ukraine is so high on the European Parliament's agenda and that the EU's support for Ukraine's independence. As a Hungarian of Transcarpathia, I consider it my task to support the establishment of peace, stability and democratization in Ukraine's domestic and foreign policy, the preservation of its sovereignty, the promotion of Euro-Atlantic integration and the visa-free entry of Ukrainian citizens into the EU. Respectively, all the efforts that would help Ukraine to get out of the crisis would create peace, because this is also the main interest of the population of the whole country and the Hungarians of Transcarpathia. I also consider it an important task to promote the enforcement of national minorities and to promote respect for human and minority rights and minority languages, as well as for them to be settled at European level. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I very much appreciate that we have a colleague who lives in Ukraine.It is interesting to me that you were elected to the European Parliament for Fidesz.I would like to know from you how you view Viktor Orbán's decision to sign a new nuclear treaty for Paks with Rosatom specifically at the beginning of the escalation in Ukraine by Russia.That actually contradicts the idea that we want to have a different energy policy.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Blue card answer."I don't think the two should be treated together."So the resolution of Hungary and the FIDESZ government is clearly in favor of Ukraine's sovereignty and support.The other issue, which is an economic issue, is a completely different issue.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me a question.Has the European Union and our European Parliament borne the burden of responsibility for the Ukrainian crisis?Are we aware that Europe's security system, built for almost 70 years, has been affected?Why is our action against violations of international law by the Russian Federation so ineffective?I see one serious cause here.Traditional members do not perceive the historical experience of the countries of the former Soviet bloc.This also applies to Ukraine.I visited Maidan several times in Kiev and understood that the Ukrainians were not even interested in an association agreement with the European Union.They do not want to be controlled by the newly emerging Soviet Union.Historical memory does not allow them to do so.They have famine, gulags, deportations in front of their eyes.Let us feel, ladies and gentlemen, that we, the former Soviet colonies, are not losing historical experience.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: Ukraine is a big test for the EU and its foreign policy.We need a stable and democratic Ukraine, but also a partner with whom we will share values.That is why the signing of the association agreement was important.However, the EU should go further.Ukraine needs our support on the international stage and it is in our interest that the conflict in eastern Ukraine be resolved and not deepened further.In this, the EU must be active in all international fora.Relations with Ukraine, but also with other eastern partners, are partly linked to relations with Russia.We must be united here.I am sorry that Europe is not yet able to speak with one voice on energy security.By our disunity, we give Russia the opportunity to use energy as a political weapon.Such an approach is dangerous for the whole of Europe in the long term.If we are not united, we will pass this test weakened.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: Mr President, today's debate is welcome and I welcome the determination of my colleagues in the European Parliament and the European Commission to do something about the situation in Ukraine. I hope that this determination will turn into concrete action, especially as the situation risks turning into an issue that affects the European path of other Eastern Partnership countries. It is inadmissible for a Eastern Partnership country, a country that has an association agreement with the European Union, to be jeopardized by its territorial integrity, to be threatened by its citizens. We must use all the means at our disposal to preserve Ukraine's territorial integrity and provide political and economic assistance to help it build its rule of law and prosperous economy. I also believe that we need to have better coordination with our transatlantic partners, the United States, in order to do something more concrete for Ukraine.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: Mr President, Commissioner Füle has pointed out that the loss of one other human life is one too many and certainly he is perfectly right. We should be thinking very carefully about our own actions in the next hours and days, so that this threat and these losses are put to an end as quickly as possible. Here I would invite Commissioner Füle to tell us a bit more about the Normandy initiative and about the Berlin declaration and what he feels that the European Union should be doing to give a very strong impetus to precisely this direction in the effort to stabilise and overcome a terrible crisis.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: The situation in Ukraine has not particularly improved since the last time we had a debate on this topic.Unfortunately, I foresaw such an unfolding of events because it was clear that due to particular interests, the European Union would not make more decisive moves towards Russia.Russia has deliberately threatened the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine, which is itself the guarantor under the Budapest Agreement.This makes Moscow a completely unreliable interlocutor in the international arena, and it asks us to take a different position.Today, only a few people mention Crimea in the context of an open issue, which is shameful from the perspective of the freedom-loving and democratic community that the European Union pretends to be.I am calling for stricter sanctions and an urgent agreement among the member states on a united approach towards Russia in order to finally put an end to the instability in the east of our continent.For that, we do not need further integration, common institutions or the EU army, but just a little good will and common sense.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Mr President, I welcome the line taken by the June European Council on Ukraine. However, I also expect the European Council this week to endorse further steps vis-à-vis Russia. Russia’s actions have dramatically changed the European security environment. This was the main concern during the elections to the European Parliament in my constituency and elsewhere. There cannot be any business as usual with Russia, as Russia is not doing business as usual with Europe.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: The PCP expresses its concern at the worsening situation in Ukraine. However, it is important to remember, and I apologize to the most sensitive ears, that this situation results from a coup d'état that happened last February and that was marked by an escalation of violence and political repression, promoted by the most reactionary sectors of the Ukrainian oligarchy and by forces of a fascist nature. This coup d'état had the explicit support of the United States of America, the European Union and NATO, a supreme demonstration of complete hypocrisy and contempt for national institutions and the international order. In the same way that we express the most intense indignation and concern at the worsening humanitarian situation in Ukraine, we also express it in the face of all the measures that undermine the activities of the Communist Party of Ukraine and the outrageous public demand for its prohibition by the coup leaders, and we now note, in this regard, the silence of this Parliament on this issue.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: Mr President, it is regrettable that High Representative Ashton is not with us here today. Just after the tragic events in Odessa of 2 May 2014 – when over 40 people were burned alive or were beaten to death in the Trade Unions House – I sent a letter to Baroness Ashton asking her to start a procedure to include the Ukrainian Right Sector group on the EU list of designated terrorist organisations. The Trade Unions House was set on fire by Right Sector activists after they surrounded and destroyed the tent encampment of anti-government protestors. Baroness Ashton, in her answer to my letter, said that these incidents must be thoroughly investigated and all those responsible brought to justice. There is no word on who will carry out an independent investigation of this event. Moreover, it is necessary to make a parallel investigation into whether the Right Sector fits in with the concept of a terrorist organisation. I urge Mr Füle to carry out all of the actions which are required for this purpose.

name: Milan ZVER
text: We must also look at the Ukrainian crisis in a geostrategic sense.Russia has destabilized the region because it has such geostrategic goals and interests.In doing so, it does not take into account international law and the territorial integrity of states.Putin is known to have said that the collapse of the Soviet Union was the greatest tragedy of the 20th century.That is why Putinization means re-establishing the Soviet empire.The European Union has not been effective internationally in recent years.I hope it will be different from now on, and I agree with my colleague Plenković when he says that the Ukrainian crisis is the right test for tomorrow's security and foreign policy of the European Union.We must immediately and comprehensively help the Ukrainian people to become more permanently an integral part of civilization, where human rights, freedom and democracy are the highest values, and Russian politics must receive a clear message with more effective sanctions.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: We have turned this debate on the situation in Ukraine into such a somewhat Russophobic debate, so if I may, I would like to make two such remarks: first of all, I would like to ask Mr Füle, who is here on behalf of the Commission, and I join Tani Ždanoke that it is unjustifiable. that Mrs Ashton is not in this discussion. So, through you, Mr Füle, I would like to ask the Commission and the Council to define very clearly how the losses will be compensated for the countries that will provide the reverse gas flow. I come from a small country, from Slovakia, our country will provide reverse gas flow to Ukraine, but I want to have guarantees for compensation for our country. The second remark concerns that human rights aspects should really be taken into account in the solutions that we are now adopting, but in all their forms, and human rights aspects and human rights protection also belong to minorities. To all minorities in Ukraine, and if we ever want the situation in Ukraine to be truly stable so that Ukraine can prosper, then it is essential that we also ensure security for the Russian minority living in Ukraine.

name: Štefan Füle
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, where to start? Maybe looking to the right, to see whether there is still the same number of people as at the beginning, when they claimed that they were here just to express how much they care about Ukraine. Catherine Ashton is in Vienna. She is holding and participating in extremely important discussions about Iranian nuclear programmes. It is a time-consuming programme. It is about an issue which poses a lot of important questions concerning European security. She would like to be here, but it is the success of those very important negotiations, with her personal participation, which has kept her from coming to this august body. A second short remark, before I make my two or three points: I have heard a lot of expressions about solidarity in this House and not only in this House but elsewhere. It is interesting how many different meanings we sometimes attribute to the word solidarity, but I think the most important meaning of the word solidarity is that we are not thinking only about ourselves but also about others who are in need of assistance and help. I will find a way to reply in a concrete and written way to one of the last questions here. Another short reply refers to the terrible crime that has happened in Odessa. Other crimes are happening at the Maidan in Kiev and elsewhere. Together with the Secretary-General of the Council of Europe we have been discussing these issues for a long time and he had my and the EU’s full support when he called in December for the international advisory panel to be set up.  This panel is being chaired by the former President of the European Court of Human Rights. It has one member from the Ukrainian Government and one member from the Ukrainian opposition. The panel is not there to investigate all those crimes, because that is ultimately up to the Ukrainian authorities, but this panel is to oversee and make absolutely clear that, in pursuing that work, the Ukrainian authorities are also pursuing European principles and standards when putting together the facts and drawing the necessary conclusions from them.  I think it is also important to state, although I do not know whether I will change the minds of some of the honourable Members, what happened and what did not happen at the end of February. What some now think of as a coup d’état was actually a sincere effort to stop the bloodshed that was going on in the streets of Ukraine, as some of you might still remember. There was a plan that was also elaborated with US assistance, and Russia also participated and contributed in an important way.  It was President Yanukovych who at that time decided not to deliver on the part that was his responsibility. He fled Kiev and later also the country. It was not a different country in which Mr Poroshenko was elected President in the first round, and not just in a part of Ukraine but throughout Ukraine. Many of you called for solutions rather than rhetoric. Actually, in my opening statement, which was a little bit more than nine minutes long, I tried to provide you – on Catherine Ashton’s instructions – with not only as objective an assessment as possible, but also clearly defining what we believe are those important steps which need to be taken to bring a peaceful solution. Let me not repeat it – I am on the record and my statement is at your disposal, if you are interested – but let me make three remarks, by way of a reaction to the number of arguments I have heard.  I am Czech. I was born in the Czech Republic. And I would not be standing here if this institution, this Parliament and Member States of the European Union, were indifferent to the calls of my compatriots to join the European Union. I would not be here if our choice to join the European Union and also to join NATO had been ignored by the very institutions we wanted to join. And it was not just for the sake of being a member of something – we had been a member of something for a long period of time before that – but because we believed in the values and principles of the organisation we wanted to be part of; because we believed that, if it had not been for the coup d’état in 1948, we would have been part of that Europe since the end of the Second World War.  It is sad for me to see that the UK, which was one of the most active proponents of EU enlargement, as far as not only the Czech Republic but also other Central European countries were concerned, now through its representatives in the European Parliament voices a little bit different – let me be politically correct – opinion. Let me make one more thing very clear. Has our relationship with Russia actually become a victim of our membership of the European Union and NATO? My answer is very clear: no. They are free of those emotions which relate back to 1968, and not only 1968. They are very pragmatic. We have never had such good and pragmatic relations with Russia as we have had since joining the European Union and NATO.  My second remark is about the importance of this institution and the discussions between one part of this House and the second part of this House about a number of important issues. I am going to talk about the bigger picture; but I am not going to talk about the bigger picture being defined by President Putin saying in 2008 that Ukraine is an artificial country or the very same President saying that the dissolution of the Soviet Union was the greatest catastrophe of the 20th century. I am going to define this bigger picture a bit differently because, whether you like it or not, whether or not you have a different opinion, whether February this year was a coup d’état or not, it is this Parliament which will have to face the issue of the consequences of the Crimea and its illegal annexation for European security. You will have to look at the issue of what has happened with the Helsinki Final Act and to what next extent European security is still based on the principles we have been working on for decades.  Secondly, this House will have to tackle the issue of the relationship between the European Union and the Eurasian Union, which is in the making. It is this bigger picture within which the issue we have been debating for almost two hours is taking place and there are some important decisions to be made, to focus on making sure that the regulatory framework between the EU and Eurasian Union is compatible, because here our responsibility and the responsibility of our partners working on the Eurasian Union is huge because if we fail on this one we might not recreate an Iron Curtain, but we might create a big trade and economic divide throughout the European continent. This House is also going to discuss the issue of the future of the Eastern Partnership, which from the very beginning was put together as a transparent, coherent and predictable policy vis-à-vis our partners, making sure that it does not offer a straightjacket, but a differentiated policy tailored to the different ambition of our partners. And it is about the ambitions of our partners, not the ambitions of some bureaucrats in Brussels, as some of you might think. And whether you like it or not, you will have to tackle the issue of propaganda, the propaganda which, as I already said in the previous House, is essentially more dangerous than that which I know from the time of the Cold War, because this one mobilises people, this one calls for mobilisation and it does not stop at what was yesterday the Iron Curtain. This one spreads throughout the European continent.  Point number three, the final point, is that we started seven-and-a-half years ago – seven-and-a-half years ago! – to negotiate the Association Agreement with Ukraine and we have been saying since the very beginning that this is not a policy that will force our partners into making a choice between Moscow or Brussels. No. That was our policy seven-and-a-half years ago and that is our policy today. The Association Agreement is not about making our partners make choices at the expense of their traditional ties. The Association Agreement and the deep and comprehensive free trade area actually strengthened our partners’ sovereignty. This is the only right thing we can do, because in the end it is up to them and their ambitions to make the choice, as it is up to us, also, to find the most adequate and most effective response to their ambitions.  Let me make my very last comment. There is no doubt that we take Russia seriously. There is no doubt about us considering Russia – despite the Crimea, despite not stopping the flow of heavy equipment across the border –as a strategic partner, and no doubt that we were sincere when we started, when my colleague Günther Oettinger started the discussion on the price of gas and my colleague Karel De Gucht held the trilateral discussions on the implementation of the Association Agreement with Ukraine and Russia. And we also take them seriously when addressing the number of issues facing those who would like to build the South Stream and to make it an EU-compatible project – and I am not talking about politics, I am talking about the legislation – and to hold these consultations with the Russians, despite them taking us to the WTO on the third energy package. This is how we in the best way and in practice show what we mean, that our policies do contribute to security on the European continent. Our policy is not divisive. Our policy is a win-win and not a zero-sum game.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: To close the debate, 7 motions for resolutions have been tabled in accordance with Article 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure.The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, July 17, 2014, at 11:00 am.Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulations)

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. - The ongoing conflicts in Ukraine are a matter of great concern and concern. Events that have exhausted the country have already had a negative impact on the country's future development and prosperity and will continue to do so. This situation confirms that the EU has not paid due attention to the Eastern Partnership policy in the past and has not properly assessed the political issues of the countries participating in this partnership. Russia's actions in the context of the events in Ukraine clearly demonstrate that the country is not a reliable partner for the EU, and that its words are significantly different from those of the EU. The EU's failure to find a united and clear position vis-à-vis both Ukraine and Russia divides Europe itself and weakens it politically. It is precisely because of the EU's delayed inaction that we have an unstable, conflict-torn, fragmented and destabilized Ukraine today, which poses a serious threat not only to the security of its closest neighbors, the Baltic States, but also to the security of the European Union as a whole. The EU must strengthen its external policy, especially in the area of ​​the Eastern Partnership, make every effort to agree and implement coherent EU action to stabilize the domestic situation and to take a clear position on the EU's relations with Russia. The President-elect of the new Commission, Mr J.-C. Juncker says the EU needs a stronger Ukraine, but to achieve this, the EU must first and foremost become united on foreign policy issues.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - Recent events in Ukraine have once again drawn our attention to the fact that resolving national and ethnic issues inside and outside Europe is a key factor. I welcome the parliamentary debate on the situation in Ukraine and call on the officials of the EU institutions to do their utmost to resolve the conflict as soon as possible. Without the support of the European Union, the stabilization and democratization of Ukraine will not take place. European cooperation and peaceful coexistence are based on mutual respect for the sovereignty of nations and solidarity with each other. The European Union must pass on this message to its negotiating partners outside the Union. As a Hungarian politician in Slovakia, I am commenting on the debate, as an acquaintance with minority problems. I mention the fact that there is a significant Hungarian community in Transcarpathia, Ukraine. Enabling the exercise of their rights, together with the other national, linguistic minorities living there, must be part of future democratic processes. All this can be achieved if the European Union calls for the recognition and practical application of fundamental human rights, including linguistic and minority rights, in Ukraine as soon as possible.

name: Eduard-Raul HELLVIG
text: signed up. - The Ukrainian crisis is becoming more and more bloody, tending to degenerate into an armed conflict, which, however, cannot be characterized as a civil war, given Russia's involvement in sending fighters and weapons. The escalation of tension mainly affects civilians, who are forced to take refuge in increasing numbers from the clashes. The European Union cannot accept the onset of a humanitarian tragedy in a country that has just signed an association agreement and whose citizens are paying dearly for their election. The possible state failure of a dismembered and destabilized Ukraine, as a punishment for its European aspiration, would be tantamount to a defeat of the European project. At the gates of Donetsk, there is a legitimate battle to defend Ukraine's sovereignty and to curb neo-Soviet expansionism, which forces the re-Bolshevism of the East and the return of Europe to the twentieth century - conflicts and violations of citizens' options and rights. We owe it to ourselves to show more effective solidarity with this fight for the values ​​on which the European Union is founded. I propose to include in tomorrow's European Parliament resolution a request to the European Council to redefine the EU's involvement in defending the integrity of Ukraine and the Republic of Moldova, boosting diplomatic dialogue and concretely supporting Ukraine's peacekeeping and reconstruction efforts.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - Ukraine has a peace plan - that of President Poroshenko. It must be implemented to stop the violence. Strong measures must be taken to ensure the territorial integrity and unity of Ukraine. It is unacceptable in the 21st century for a country to take advantage of the internal problems of its neighbors and seize territories. Russia is acting against the norms of international law and its own commitments and is helping to escalate the conflict. I expect the Kremlin to support the peace plan not only in words but also in deeds and to stop continuing support for the separatists and the regrouping of its troops along the border. The international community and the EU must continue to engage Russia. The Kremlin is also responsible for deteriorating relations with the European Union. I believe that Russia should be our strategic partner, not an enemy that uses divide-and-rule tactics. I urge the rapid ratification and implementation of the Association Agreement with Ukraine by all member states, including Bulgaria. This will be another step towards normalizing the situation.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the discussion based on the Commission Statement on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) (2014/2714 (RSP)).

name: Karel DE GUCHT
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, let me first of all say that I am particularly pleased to be here today to discuss the ongoing Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations with the newly constituted European Parliament. You have a very serious responsibility as it will ultimately fall to you to vote on what will have been negotiated. Your thumbs up or down will make or break TTIP. Given the wide spectrum of opinion in this Parliament, disagreement is unavoidable, but I hope the debate will be based on facts and logic. We cannot afford to let it be controlled by irrational fears or false information. Let me focus on three themes that have been at the forefront of the criticism levied against TTIP: the alleged lack of transparency, the alleged risk of lowering the regulatory standards which underpin our way of life and ISDS. Many people have alleged that the negotiations have been conducted so far in secrecy. It is true that when I meet my counterpart, Ambassador Froman, we prefer to do it without TV cameras being present. If you want to build confidence you also need a certain degree of confidentiality. It is also true that the Commission historically has conducted negotiations without that much media attention, not because we wanted to keep them secret but because the interest was much lower. TTIP has completely changed that. The Commission has worked hard to accommodate that new reality. To give one example: recently some media reported that leaked secret documents revealed that Europe is trying to get access to oil and gas via TTIP. But it was not much of a revelation. As a matter of fact position papers have been available for a long time on our dedicated TTIP website, clearly stating that we want the US to remove export restrictions in the energy field. Tomorrow, in the middle of the sixth negotiating round, the chief negotiators will take a break to interact directly with stakeholders. As in every single negotiating round, there will be scores of presentations from all kinds of parties with a stake in the negotiations and they will be given direct access to the two chief negotiators for questions and answers. When each negotiation round is over, we will publish written summaries of the outcome. We have also put in place an advisory group, consisting of experts carefully selected to represent a broad array of interests from civil society, including unions, consumer organisations and relevant business sectors. We have also persuaded the US to allow us to share negotiation documents with Member States and Parliament in reading rooms. But that does not mean that we cannot do even more. In fact, I wish we could. But the US only gives access to the Parliament on a reading room basis, so you can imagine that it is particularly difficult to convince my American counterpart to go any further with our Members of Parliament than they do with theirs. One of the sources of confusion is the fact that the negotiating directives given by the Council to the Commission have not been made officially public. I am deeply convinced we should change that. The negotiation guidelines summarise the EU objectives in the negotiations and could reassure citizens that there is nothing dangerous in TTIP. In May I called on the Council to declassify them and today I hereby call on them again to publish the negotiating directives. In addition, I will continue to be fully at your disposal to answer all questions you may have. I am ready to consider any other specific ideas on how we can further improve transparency. One of the loudest arguments against TTIP that is often raised is that the agreement will force Europe to lower its high standards for protection: protection of the environment, of consumers and of workers. The argument is that our European model is much better than the American one and if we try to tear down trade barriers between the two continents we will also automatically tear down the high European standards. Some are tempted to turn this into a Kulturkampf, claiming that TTIP threatens to Americanise our way of life. The Commission does not share this line of reasoning. First, it appears to suggest that the US is not interested in protecting the environment or its consumers or workers. Actually, sometimes protection in the US is higher than here. To illustrate: US courts are much more likely than European ones to award high damages to consumers if they have been harmed by a product they have purchased. The air and water quality legislation in the US is not softer than ours. We do approach many areas in a different way from that in the US and sometimes our rules here are stricter than in the US but we share the same objectives of quality and protection and, even where we differ, our values and concerns are more similar than with any other parts of the world. That is why President Obama flatly stated in Brussels that he would not agree to any deal if it lowered the standards of protection. Neither would the Commission. Secondly, it is also a wrong argument as a matter of logic. There are plenty of barriers to trade that can be removed without lowering standards. Take the internal market. The internal market is low on barriers to trade and high on standards of protection. The same philosophy underpins the TTIP negotiations. We should remove protectionism but keep protection. Does it really make sense for an inspector from the US to fly over here to inspect our pharmaceutical production sites and repeat exactly the same work already done by a European colleague. If we agree that the American inspector can stay at home and just rely on a copy of the inspection report we have already made, there is no lowering of any standards anywhere. The only thing that is lowered is the amount of red tape. And where the gap in approach between the EU and the US is too wide, we just will not change our rules. We will not import any meat that is treated with hormones. We will not give a blanket approval of imports of GMOs. On the other hand it is not because the US makes a claim that it must be wrong by definition. We should rely on the opinions of our own scientists in EFSA and not on ideology. Finally, I know that many EU citizens are afraid of including ISDS in the agreement. The feeling is that this will open a way for large American corporations through arbitration to undermine policy space for our democratically elected parliaments. One often-cited example is the ongoing lawsuit by Philip Morris against Australia for introducing plain packaging for cigarettes. We have suspended negotiations with the US on this issue while we conduct a public consultation. We will draw the conclusions from it in due course. We need the debate to be about the ISDS provisions we are considering including and not some imaginary alternative. The Commission’s current ideas are available, black on white, in the consultation document. They have been carefully drafted to ensure that damage claims can only be raised for very clear violations or very fundamental principles of investor protection and that the policy space is fully preserved. Contrary to what is alleged by some scaremongers, a US multinational will not be able to successfully sue for damages for lost future profit just because a parliament introduces a new law with the legitimate aim of protecting the environment or public health. The terms of this debate should not be ISDS or not ISDS. ISDS is already a feature in investment treaties between some of our Member States and the US. The core question is: what sort of ISDS do we want for investment protection vis-à-vis the US but also any other third country? There is also a question of consistency to keep in mind. I think it would be difficult one day to claim that we must avoid ISDS provisions with the US because they are dangerous and then the next day insist on including the same kind of provisions in agreements with others, such as China. The provisions we propose in the consultation represent a very substantial improvement over most of the ISDS provisions in the 1 400 bilateral investment treaties that currently bind our Member States. I am looking forward to an engaging debate.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! It is good that we have another round of negotiations this week in Brussels. My group sees great opportunities for citizens, consumers and businesses in a carefully negotiated TTIP agreement. It is good that we have a broad debate on the subject - again here in plenary, often in the committee or in the specially set up observer group and also among the population. It gives us the chance to listen, but it also gives us the chance to get better information. I think it is great that Commissioner De Gucht has now given us negotiating documents. I would be happy if the Council finally had some understanding and made the negotiating mandate public. Because it is important that we inform the public, on the Commission's homepage, but also here, what it is about and what it is not about. It's about growth and jobs, and it's not about lowering standards or protecting consumers. It is about better market access for our companies - large and small - and it is not about the forced privatization of the water supply. It's about removing tariffs on trucks, cars, shoes or clothes / clothes, but it's not about the deterioration of workers' rights. It is about solving the problem that foreign investors are still often disadvantaged, and not about restricting political leeway or disempowering national courts. It is about the question of how 500 million Europeans look for constitutional and democratic partners in a globalized world with today eight billion people, and it is not about the abolition of public service broadcasting, national film funding or local municipal theaters. The Commission has a great responsibility. We want TTIP, but we don't want it at any price. We want a TTIP as outlined in the negotiating mandate and set out in the resolution of May 2013. This is how we will measure the text in the end. That is what we as the EPP will ultimately ensure, and only then will we approve the agreement. Until then, a lot of negotiating skills and success in the talks!

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, at the start of this new Parliament I want to lay out my Group’s position on TTIP as clearly as possible. We in the Socialist and Democratic Group believe that TTIP does have the potential to be a significant catalyst for jobs and growth, and we know that this could be the EU’s last chance to be a setter of global standards. If we do nothing we will be relegated from leaders to followers; it will be China, India, and Brazil who will set the global standards, putting our industries at a significant disadvantage.  As well as regulatory cooperation, we want to see the United States open up to European investment its transport sector and its public procurement, to level the playing field for our industries. We want to see quality European products such as Parma ham and Feta cheese given strong geographic protection against genetic products and misleading marketing, and we want to give our small and medium-sized enterprises the same opportunities as multinationals currently enjoy in easy access to the US market. We do accept that this agreement could and should benefit consumers, and that is why we welcome the fact that the Commission has involved consumer groups, NGOs and trade unions in the European discussion on priorities. For all of these reasons the Socialists were proud to be at the birth of TTIP, and we do not want to have to be its assassins. I want to tell the Commission clearly now, though, that if we have to be, we will be, and that is why we want the Commission to listen carefully to our concerns, such as those over food safety. Regulatory convergence must not lead to chlorinated chickens, hormone-treated beef or GMOs getting access to the European Union market. We have had assurances from the Commission on this but I want to tell you that we will keep reminding you of this and we will keep watching you throughout the whole of the negotiations. Similarly with our concerns over investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS): we do not believe that this consultation is the end of the process. We want to ensure that the Commission listens carefully to public opinion on this issue and that ISDS does not become a backdoor route for a corporate power grab. We also have concerns about public services; again we have had some assurances from the Commission, but we want to make sure that our public services remain of the highest standard and receive the highest possible protection. We want to make sure that in this trade agreement there is no ratchet effect and there is no ability to prevent Member States returning health, education and other vital services to public control if they have been privatised. So we will keep scrutinising TTIP to make sure that the quality of our services remains high, that corporate power is not increased unnecessarily, that our high levels of protection are retained. But we have to say to the Commission: we recognise that a good TTIP would be good for Europe, and the pledge we give to the Commission and to the Member States is that we will watch the outcome of this agreement and, if we think it benefits Europe, benefits European jobs and European standards of living, we will vote for it. If we think it damages our concerns we will vote against it. We will make up our mind at the end; unlike some groups we have not made up our mind one way and unlike other groups we have not made up our mind the other way. We will judge this agreement on its merits at the end of the process. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Georgios KATROUGKALOS
text: blue-card question. – My question is about ISDS. I am quoting from the guidelines given by Mr Juncker in today’s speech. I will not accept, says Mr Juncker, that the jurisdiction of courts in European Union Member States is limited by special regimes for universal disputes. We heard another version from the Commissioner, so I would like to ask Mr Martin which of these opinions he supports: the opinion of Mr Juncker or the opinion of the Commissioner?

name: David MARTIN
text: blue-card answer. – I have my own position and my group has its own position, which is that we do not want investor-state dispute settlement in this agreement. We will judge the agreement at the end of the day, but at the moment our position is very clear: we do not think ISDS belongs in such an agreement because we think the normal legal system is the way to deal with these issues.

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I should like to thank the Commissioner for addressing the issue of TTIP here in the Parliament with us today. It is vital that we keep in mind just how important a deal this is for the EU. We must grasp this opportunity: a free trade deal is good for growth and jobs, but this is particularly true of one of this scale. In the long term, we can expect it to boost the EU economy by as much as a hundred billion pounds annually, and this does not even take into account the benefits arising from the dynamic productivity gains which could be realised from a comprehensive deal.  For the individual man or woman on both sides of the pond, they will notice that they have more products to choose from – products which are of a better standard and at a cheaper price. But we must also ensure that the deal benefits businesses on both sides of the Atlantic, irrespective of size. We can help our smallest businesses by eliminating tariffs, by aligning customs processes at borders, and by increasing regulatory coherence between the EU and the US. If we take these steps, we can aspire to one day having a truly transatlantic market. There are, of course, concerns amongst a wider European public about this deal, particularly when it comes to food standards and investor-to-state dispute settlement. EU negotiators have ruled out the inclusion of hormone beef and chlorinated chicken, so I hope that this scaremongering will stop. While the ISDS will be there to act as a safeguard for investors, I am pleased that the Commission has recognised concerns by launching a consultation with stakeholders on its provisions. Commissioner De Gucht, I urge you to keep your foot on the gas – to use an American phrase – with this deal until the end of your term. It is crucial that we build momentum with this deal, and for that we need renewed political support on both sides. At the same time –and as important as this deal is – let us remember that we must maintain and develop our existing trade relationships, which we have worked hard to build up over a number of years. We must deliver jobs and growth for our citizens and stay committed to keeping our markets open. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Thank you very much!My question is: how will this agreement work for small and medium-sized enterprises?What impact will there be here?Can you see that the Commission's forecasts here could also result in employment growth in Europe?

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: blue-card answer. – I do believe that there is a huge opportunity and potential for the TTIP and for an EU-US free trade agreement to deliver for all businesses of all sizes, as I say irrespectively. We must take into consideration the impact it will have on small businesses, but we cannot undermine the opportunities that are available to them.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, a year and a half ago – with the necessary heavy lifting and political leadership – we kicked off the negotiations on a comprehensive trade and investment partnership. But those days, when Vice-President Biden liked to talk about finishing the deal on one tank of gas, seem a little bit far behind us at this moment, one-and-a half years down the road. It seems as though the Americans have chosen an exceptionally environmentally friendly car to drive in. In any case, I think that they and maybe all of us should step on the gas to keep the very important momentum that started these negotiations. For our group, jobs and growth without government investment, the opportunity to set global standards and meet competition from emerging economies, and eliminating unnecessary bureaucratic burdens, remain the essential points on the horizon. We have to find ways to preserve our cherished standards when it comes to food safety and the environment, as well as fundamental rights, such as the right to privacy.  These are points which are being raised by people all over the EU, and I think it is good to have an active debate. Transparency and active engagement are essential to acquiring consent at the end of the day. So, Commissioner, my question is: how will you help dispel the feeling that quite a few people have that there is not enough clarity on where the process of negotiation stands, and that there may not be enough space to participate while there may be enough space for corporations to have access? Now the investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) consultation seems to show that there is great interest. I have heard a number of rumours about the amount of consultation submissions which were received. Perhaps you could also say something about the amount of responses that came in, as well as when you expect an initial assessment or final assessment. Do you believe that TTIP is possible, from the American point of view, without ISDS? Is this a negotiable point from their side? But with all these challenges, we might almost forget that there are also non-controversial issues and opportunities, such as procurement.  For the EU, it is crystal clear that the US market should open up for our businesses, to end explicit protectionism through the ‘Buy American’ and ‘Buy America’ Acts, as well as implicit protectionism through national security clauses, as seen in the Jones Act, which restricts access for European ship builders and operators, as well as domestic flights by European airliners. Is there any progress on this point?

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! The public's criticism of the TTIP negotiations is growing ever stronger. You can also see this in the result of the European elections and the success of my group. We take this as a mandate and, on behalf of my group, I call on you not to continue negotiations on TTIP now. Take the time to pause for thought! You conducted a consultation on ISDS and Ambassador O‘Sullivan announced yesterday that it had received more than 115,000 responses. The population does not want ISDS - neither in TTIP nor in the agreement with Canada. So draw a line, because instruments of the 20th century don't have to be right in the 21st century. So why don't you ask the public for their opinion on other chapters of free trade policy? That would be an innovative approach! Do you think that farmers and consumers want further liberalization in the trade in agricultural products? I assure you: it is not. - Incidentally, not only in the EU, but also in the many states of the USA, people don't want that. So do not represent the interests of the corporations, but those of the population! Yes, it is not about a culture war - I agree with you, Mr De Gucht - but rather the question of our economic and consumption methods. It's on the negotiating table. And one more thing, because I come from Germany, against the background of the NSA espionage affairs etc .: As long as the Americans do not want to commit themselves to protecting and respecting the data of the European population and also of economic actors, there is no basis for a trade deal. So: keep common goods and interrupt the negotiations on TTIP!

name: Yannick JADOT
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, from the start, the environmental group has denounced this negotiation because we consider that these are societal choices which are being negotiated. These are societal choices on the environment, on health, on social law, on public services, on intellectual property, on agriculture, on food and today these social choices are negotiated in total opacity on the sole basis of their commodification. It is a deep problem. We are being told today that it would be good for Europe. No! We can see that today, what Europe needs is to define its project, to strengthen its project with an industrial policy, with a specificity of sustainability and what this negotiation offers us, it is to dilute the European project in a large transatlantic market. So, Commissioner, you explained to us how much the European Commission was making efforts on transparency. Since yesterday, the consolidated negotiation texts - that is to say the heart of the negotiation, which is really being played out today - have been placed in reading rooms. Reading material for member states means going to the American embassy if they want to know what is in these negotiating texts. For MEPs, this means going to a reading room located at the European Parliament in Brussels or at the European Commission. How can we imagine, today, that social choices are reduced to consultations without a telephone, without the means to take notes in reading rooms. The transparency that you are offering us, Commissioner, is an artifice. It is totally contradictory with the democracy that European citizens expect, with the control that European citizens want to exercise over European institutions. Pardon me, Commissioner, but the environmental group today considers the way in which the European Parliament and the governments are informed of the holding of the follow-up to the negotiations - either by means of reading documents - is contrary to the Treaty on the functioning of the European Union is contrary to Article 218 (10) of that Treaty. MEPs have the right to follow these negotiations and to be fully informed. This is the text on which the European Court of Justice has already ruled. This negotiation led by the European Commission is already illegal. And this is also why the environmental group supports the European citizens' initiative which is launched today by dozens of organizations to ask you, the European Commission, to put an end to this negotiation as well as to refuse the adoption of the treaty with Canada. Finally, on ISDS, Commissioner, that's good, you continue to promote it. You can see that groups which, until now, have always supported this negotiation after the European elections are starting to squirm a little and the new President of the Commission has, at least, made the gesture of saying that national courts are enough , that it would be unacceptable to transfer democratic sovereignty from citizens to multinationals. This is not what voters said on May 25. (The speaker agrees to answer two "blue card" questions (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Dear Mr. Jadot!You have just complained very loudly about a lack of transparency.Could it be that you yourself may not have even accessed some of the documents that are available to us?And can it be that at the regular information meetings - before and after the negotiation rounds - no MEPs from your group were present on several occasions?

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question.- (FI) Mr President, it is unfortunate that this agreement of the century has such a bad reputation.Yes, it is up to the Member States to take responsibility for not defending this.The Commissioner and the Commission are, as it were, driving this alone, even though the Member States had agreed.I would like to ask you, honorable Member, do you see any good things in this planned agreement?In terms of growth, employment, labor rights, do you see any good things?

name: Yannick JADOT
text: answer "blue card". - Mr Caspary, I do not consider that from the moment when, as Vice-Chairman of the Committee on International Trade, coordinator of the Group of the Greens / European Free Alliance, on this subject, I have access to some documents negotiations, I will begin to imagine that the process is democratic and transparent. From the moment when issues as important as public services, data protection, health and environmental protection are discussed, I consider that citizens - and not only Yannick Jadot, MEP - must be informed and when I see the communication papers provided by the European Commission on the state of negotiations, I find a line per topic. I do not consider that this gives transparent and complete information about the negotiations. I would remind you that Article 218 (10) of the Treaty says that parliamentarians must be fully informed. As for the benefits of the treaty, Mrs Jaakonsaari, I don't see any. You know that the European Parliament carried out an expertise of the estimate made by the European Commission, and that this expertise clearly indicated that it was almost impossible to make this assessment and to promise such benefits by 2027. Commissioner De Gucht himself said that the 545 euros per year, per European household, did not mean anything, and the model that was used did not make a single assessment on the profits or losses in terms of 'employment.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, citizens, as a spokesperson for the Five Star Movement and a member of the EFDD group, I have a simple question to ask the Commission: Commissioner, but what is TTIP really? This is not a simple free trade agreement. Moreover, the duties between Europe and the United States are already very low. Instead, it is a tool for removing barriers to free trade. These barriers are: the rights our workers have acquired after generations of struggles; environmental regulations that limit pollution; the rules on food safety, the same rules that protect us from GM food and from meat treated with hormones; European laws prohibiting harmful chemicals and finally our privacy, the protection of our personal data. Commissioner, the Commission has repeated several times that the negotiation process is transparent and open. Even now it is being discussed, there is no secret. Well, Commissioner, you couldn't find me more in agreement: it is true, there is no secret. But there is no secret for lobbyist groups and lawyers for large multinationals. On the other hand, real access to documents is impossible for European citizens, it is impossible for parliamentarians and it is also impossible for me as a member of the Committee on International Trade. I ask once again why these documents are kept secret and why a process, which should have been inclusive from its inception, is instead becoming increasingly exclusive and secret. Gentlemen, what is at stake here is not just an economic agreement but the very concept of democracy. I wonder what is the idea of ​​democracy and inclusion that Europe wants to achieve. Is this the same idea that inspired most of the political parties that sit in this Parliament when they turned down any presidency and vice-presidency for the members of my political group, thus excluding more than 10 million citizens from key roles in Parliament? Dear colleagues, for all European citizens I really hope not! (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162.8))

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr President, Madam Beghin!I am also on the Committee on International Trade - like you.I look forward to the cooperation.I just wonder how you know that we are not getting any documents - the committee has not even met.I know that the Commissioner and his negotiators are providing the so-called monitoring group there with precisely the documents that you are currently requesting.So would you agree that we might wait for the committee to meet and see what kind of documents we get before we do as broad an assessment as you have just done?

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: rapporteur.- I have been here for about fifteen days and I have requested these documents which no one has been able to obtain.When we get this far in the negotiations, what is it we still have to wait?In my opinion it would be appropriate for us to know what has been discussed so far.(The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 149 (8)).

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we do not trust, we do not trust! Five years of trade policies run by this Commission have led to disaster. The agreement with Pakistan for textiles has closed thousands of companies; the agreement with Morocco for fruit and vegetables and fishing has damaged thousands of fishermen and farmers; the rice deal with Burma is bringing tons of fake rice to our children's tables. And then the brilliantly conducted negotiations with India, Vietnam, Korea, Japan, Colombia: lost jobs, lost rights, quality of life gone up in smoke! Why should it change with the United States, which is also much smarter than us? The United States protects their brands, they have made in products, they have duties. Your European Commission, the Brussels Bureaucrats Commission does not protect what is produced in Europe. Every year - just to stay in my country - in Italy we have damages of one billion euros for the fake Italian wine sold as Italian; we have three billion euros in damages for oil, cheese and fake food products passed off as Italians in the United States. What is there in this text to defend this work, this history, this origin, this future, this tradition? Anything! So, as far as I'm concerned, either this text changes entirely or the Northern League will vote against it from the first to the last line.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, this free trade agreement with the United States continues to raise many questions. I would therefore like to remind you of our attachment to the various red lines and our determination to guarantee our social choices. Our agricultural and food models must be preserved as well as respect for our geographical indications. This agreement must also guarantee real access to American public markets, including for our SMEs. And whatever you say about ISDS, we must ensure that our investors are protected and that all of our public policies in the social, environmental and health fields cannot be called into question by foreign multinationals. So that ISDS is not an additional weapon in the hands of multinationals, we also demand that it be really accessible to SMEs in a simple and inexpensive way, and according to a transparent procedure. This is why, for lack of sufficient guarantees on these points, we must question whether this mechanism will be maintained in the current discussions. Commissioner, we are emerging from a difficult electoral campaign: Europe is not seen as being close to the citizens. Questions about this agreement have come up over and over again in the discussions. As representatives of European citizens, we therefore want these negotiations to be conducted with firmness and transparency in order to avoid misunderstandings and political exploitation. (The speaker accepts to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: blue card question.- Mr President, I would like to ask the colleague the following question: while there are trade relations of all the countries of Europe with the United States, suddenly a different type of framework appears.Is it the other form of NATO, that is, is this new agreement the trade NATO?

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: answer "blue card".- Mr Glezos, I do not think that we are in an agreement which would be another form of NATO.I think the United States is a big power, Europe is a big trade power, and it makes perfect sense that we can have a much deeper trade relationship.But, simply, we are vigilant, we have social choices, we have red lines and we want to make them respected.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! It is quite obvious that many people associate worries and hardships with this agreement. I believe it is time to take these worries and fears seriously and not to put them off. This primarily includes transparency. You have to admit that it has been a very slow process to get more transparency into the negotiations and I am still not satisfied with it. I find it unbearable that the Council - which is not here again today - is preventing the negotiating mandate and the fundamental documents from being published. It is a scandal and I appeal to the governments to finally give up this situation so that the citizens of Europe can really participate in the discussion and know what is going on.
