I also appeal to the United States to abandon its policy of foreclosure. It's an absurd situation: on the one hand there are NSAs, spies and whatever, and the US is trying to get all the information. And when it comes to documents, they prevent their own negotiating documents from being published and ensure that consolidated texts are only accessible in a reading room. The USA, for example, presented a paper on the liberalization of education in the private sector - an exciting question, everything that has to do with adult education. I want to know what the United States is asking for there. I cannot see this document. It can not go on like that. When we negotiate, there must also be transparency in all the documents that are on the table. Otherwise one side is clearly disadvantaged. I just want to be able to sign something that has been negotiated transparently. I also have the feeling that when it comes to ISDS, people's worries and needs are now very, very strong - by the way, also on the other side of the Atlantic. More than 150,000 entries during the consultation showed that. So we should draw the line and say: Yes, we want trade agreements, but without ISDS, that is the perspective. The United States, by the way, has a trade agreement with Australia - even without ISDS. In this respect, we should clearly take the concerns here seriously and forego them. Commissioner, if you are serious about investment protection mechanisms beyond court situations, then I ask myself: why did you not take an activity to set up an international court for investment protection at the WTO instead of enforcing something like that in bilateral agreements? Incidentally, the old member states of the European Union do not have such an agreement with any OECD country. In the end we decide, and I think we do it very consciously and rationally, as we showed in the ACTA case. The Commission should therefore take the signals seriously. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8)).

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr. Langen!Thank you for your clear words on investor dispute settlement.I have a question about this: Does this clear standard that you have applied also apply to the agreements with Canada, Singapore and Vietnam?These are all agreements that also provide for these mechanisms.Do you also demand there just as clearly that these dispute settlement mechanisms should not be part of the agreement?

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- There are enough studies now that ISDS is not significant for investment.Brazil, for example, doesn't have an ISDS, and yet there is a lot of investment in Brazil.In this respect, I believe this instrument is from the last century and should also be thrown in the rubbish heap of history.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: Mr. Chairman! Ladies and gentlemen! Agreements that are made to facilitate international trade are usually good. However, there are a few points that may be of concern. Negotiations, as has been said many times, are kept secret. And we know that the US economy is larger and stronger than the sum of the economies of the European Union. If the contract is poorly structured (and because it is construed confidentially, we cannot rule out that it will), it could happen that Europe becomes a space for American expansion, and Europe in America has less and less to say. I warn you against this, because this is what happened in Poland after 1989: we have many retail chains in Poland, but only one of them is Polish; the rest are based in Western Europe. Americans care about the environment, even though we think we care better for it. However, they do not believe - at least those who decide on the economy - that lowering carbon dioxide emissions can affect climate change and therefore their products are cheaper ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, basically, public opinion was invited into this debate on TTIP. I think this is a good thing. This is a good thing because it should perhaps help to change certain bad habits and to get out of this kind of closed session, especially since, contrary to what you said earlier or failed to say, ratification will not only take place here in the European Parliament, it will take place in all the national parliaments of each of the Member States. This means that our democracies, not only European, but also national, must also be involved in this debate and that answers be given to our citizens. Not to do so would obviously be extremely negative. Basically, what are Europeans waiting for? They wait for their national or European leaders - for them it is the same thing - to defend their interests and tell them so. So, it's basically pretty simple. Obviously we need transparency. It is stupid that the negotiating mandate is not public, especially since it is on the internet. We obviously need to reassure Europeans about the standards. I think we have exceptional standards which protect us better than anyone, better than elsewhere and that we must keep them. It is an added value for Europe and not a less and it is also obviously the question of arbitration. We don't need an arbitration process when we have the rule of law here in Europe and the United States that works, that allows appeals and that makes investments very secure. I therefore invite you, Commissioner, not to dismiss like that the fact that public opinions have entered this TTIP debate and on the contrary to take their questions into account in order to answer them.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: Mr President, Commissioner, if you have nothing to fear from the reaction of the populations to this great transatlantic market, get out of the secrecy of these negotiations and bring all the content of the discussions to light. Publish or have the negotiating mandate published. Give all the elements under discussion to our Parliament, to national parliaments, to unions, to consumer associations, to non-governmental organizations. Be transparent about all the players associated with these bargains. You have just made a plea for the project of an international arbitral tribunal. However, it is the elected representatives of the people who make the law, not the lawyers of multinationals. We therefore refuse to allow business law to take precedence over human and social rights. Contrary to what you say, this is not a question of so-called trade policy choices. It is about job security, knowing what we will eat tomorrow, our health, access to education and culture, biodiversity, ways of producing. It is about our economic and social rights. In fact, it is a choice of civilization. It is even about the future of the European idea itself. This project would stifle it in a single market dominated by multinationals. On all these elements, we expect transparency and more explanations from you and, above all, the abandonment of this dangerous project.

name: Ska KELLER
text: Mister President!More people participated in the investor-state litigation consultation than at any other consultation.This shows how uneasy people across Europe are about private law that only benefits large companies.We should take this discomfort seriously.Now that the newly elected Commission President has spoken out against this kind of parallel justice, will you, Commissioner, then rule out the investor complaint procedure from CETA, the Canada Agreement, and TTIP, the agreement with the USA?I would like to hear from you.

name: Petr MACH
text: Commissioner, as a libertarian, I see free trade as a fundamental manifestation of human freedom and as a condition for prosperity and peaceful cooperation between nations. So I'm definitely in favor of free trade with the United States. I want us to be able to import goods from the United States without customs and other barriers, so that our companies can freely export goods to America, so that we do not have to pay extra money every time goods cross borders. But such a contract cannot be so thick in my opinion. A contract that would really only be about free trade must, in my judgment, fit into two sides. So I suspect that the forthcoming agreement will not be about free trade, but about new regulations. I want free trade, really free trade, with the United States, but also with Ukraine, Israel, Morocco, Russia - simply put, with the rest of the world. I am afraid the European Commission does not want this. Customs bring billions to her budget she doesn't want to lose. I want the Commission to hear this liberal voice for free trade. If you negotiate only new restrictions instead of free trade, remember that there is an alternative to the European Union's bureaucratic and over-regulated approach in the form of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA), which may gradually become a more attractive choice for many countries.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: Mr President, I had prepared a speech, then, listening to you, I changed my mind because I found that at the end of these debates this Parliament is pitiful, you see. This morning you were all there, triumphant, like roosters who believe that by singing they make the sun rise. You were full of your phantom power. "Look at us, we elected the President of the Commission". You had ended up believing in the illusion of your phantom power and of this so-called democratic process, which moreover has no "democratic" in name. And look at yourself a few hours later, but look at yourself! Do you hear! "We want transparency. We would like to see transparency. Will we have the right to have the documents on which we are negotiating or will no one give them to us?" No one will give them to you! And all of a sudden you see the contempt of the Commission. The Commissioner looks at you with an amused air, with a little smile on the corner of his lips, asking for transparency. You will not have transparency, because the contempt of this Commission and its anti-democratic process mean that this Parliament has no power, and therefore it is much more serious. The peoples of Europe have no power and in particular no knowledge of what is happening behind their backs and which resembles, as you know much more, a single market than a transatlantic free trade agreement. And this negotiation has been going on for a year. And, for a year, you have been moaning to demand transparency and you have not obtained this transparency today, nor yesterday, nor probably tomorrow.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: Mr President, very specific questions have been posed to the Commissioner. I myself have three questions but very simple ones. First of all, in the transatlantic relationship is the status quo an option? No, I think in the rapidly changing global environment standing still means falling behind, so the status quo is not an option. Second: do the WTO multilateral trade negotiations represent an alternative? We saw the Doha Development Round stalled, and we see that the Bali Agenda is endangered. No, I think WTO negotiations are no alternative.  Third: can we allow Europe’s food safety, social system, our data protection and cultural diversity to be endangered by the new provisions of the FTA? No, and I think it is the role of the European Parliament to make sure that the fundamental interests of our citizens are safeguarded, and that TTIP, when concluded, will equally serve all Europeans.

name: Jörg LEICHTFRIED
text: Mister President! There is a saying that means: “Well meant is the opposite of good”. I think that happened here. These negotiations may have been well-intentioned, but they went terribly wrong. There are many examples of what went wrong. Many colleagues have already mentioned a few things. But I would like to address these investment protection clauses again and perhaps to put it in a very simplified way: a common citizen who buys a diesel car, for example because diesel is cheaper and is less taxed, cannot go to a special court that is sitting in London when a democratically elected government suddenly increases taxes on diesel. But these investors could do it. That's unfair. Why are there special rights for large investors? We live in a democratic legal system - both in Europe and in the United States - and there is no need for either side to do that. When investors struggle, there are proper courts. Otherwise, in my opinion, this agreement cannot be approved. Then this gossip about secrecy! I once believed that too. It has been explained to me that if you negotiate with the Americans, you cannot open all negotiating positions. I understand that already. But we have now come to the conclusion: Americans already know our secrets before we even know them because they eavesdrop on us. You have to take that into account. It is therefore high time everyone found out what is being negotiated here! Commissioner, I have the feeling that this agreement is an agreement that benefits large financial investors and harms democracy, and such an agreement is out of place. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mister President!Yes, colleague Leichtfried, I am very enthusiastic!In contrast to two colleagues in your social democratic delegation, you voted with full enthusiasm for the negotiations a year ago.In April you were still in favor of the ISDS agreement.I am really fascinated.What made you rethink so quickly that you have rethought in the last few days?Yes, in the newspaper in Austria you are even calling for an exit from the negotiations!You have no confidence in the Commission.What was the reason?Can you tell me the key experience in your knowledge?Why has your love for America grown cold?Or was it the poor election result ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jörg LEICHTFRIED
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Herr Obermayr, I think you don't know your way around.It has been going on for a long time.Of course I said: I am in favor of negotiations.Of course I said: I will see how they go and in the end I will decide whether I am for or against.Of course, I have now said: I have the feeling that they are going very badly and I have explained why I think they are going very badly.Unlike you, I worked on it for five years and was on the right committee.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Today we are debating TTIP under the misleading title of “free trade”. The investor protection ISDS threatens to slip through the back door as a further curtailment of the competences of the national parliaments. If parliaments in Europe have to decide consumer protection, data protection, environmental protection, health policy and employee rights in the future under the sword of Damocles of financial demands by corporations, this will change the political culture in Europe. You, ladies and gentlemen from the Commission, are responsible for this. Are you willing and able to take on this responsibility? Would you like to represent a majority of the population in Europe on this issue? The negotiations on TTIP belong in the hands of the national parliaments. The Commission does not have the necessary democratic legitimacy. If she does negotiate, please act as a pioneer exclusively for free trade between the peoples of the world. Then a democratic political and social consensus could be reached quickly. The freedom, democracy and the right of self-determination of the European peoples must not be up for grabs - not even as a price for free trade, Commissioner De Gucht.

name: Olli REHN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is now on the path to recovery, and that recovery and growth must be nurtured on all fronts. We also need to look for new fins for growth in cross-border markets. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Agreement is a key part of Europe's new growth and jobs agenda. It is a tool to open up better access to the US market for European companies. This agreement must make a strong contribution to the export success of European SMEs. At the same time, however, mutual acceptance of standards must not mean weakening our own laws. For example, the agreement must not interfere with the parties' right to maintain a high level of food safety and environmental protection. Care must also be taken to ensure the competitiveness of European agriculture. The key to accepting the agreement is to find credible answers to citizens' concerns. This requires transparency and effective dialogue with civil society. Commissioner De Gucht's readiness to announce negotiating mandates is a positive step. This is also the case with the Commission's public consultation on investment protection and mediation in the context of the rule of law. This is the right direction. We must see the forest from the trees, that is, the impact of the agreement on European growth and employment. But the condition of the trees, ie consumer protection, the countryside and the rule of law, must also be taken care of.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems clear to us, even from this afternoon's debate, that the discussion on TTIP is a measure of the quality of democracy in the European Union. We have reached the sixth round of negotiations and the negotiation is essentially in its real terms hidden from the townspeople, hidden from the members of this Parliament. Commissioner De Gucht himself here told us about a reserved and read-only room. Decisions with such an impact on people's lives cannot be made without information and consent. And this is one of the reasons that leads us to say: stop TTIP now! We ask, Commissioner, if you feel bound by the outcome of the public consultation on the ISDS or if we are talking only about fake transparency. We want total transparency on the mandate and on the actors of this negotiation and decision-making sovereignty for European citizens. But there are also many questions of merit. With this treaty, a single law is established, a single rule, that of the market, and the others are effectively abolished, those in defense of food health, labor rights, the environment, agricultural production, privacy, banks. personal data, of the public nature of the institutions that must guarantee the right to health and education. Legislation on this parliamentary matter is withdrawn from democratically elected parliaments and subordinated to an arbitral tribunal. Popular sovereignty is subordinated to freedom of enterprise. We talk about employment benefits, but what benefits are we talking about? Of precarious work, of work without rights. Here, you defend the frontiers with the FRONTEX against the people and abolish them only to create a single market. We are very determined in wanting to defend not borders but people's rights. This is why we ask that TTIP be stopped immediately.

name: Jill EVANS
text: Mr President, the TTIP was a major issue during the European election campaign. I had hundreds of messages from constituents, trade unions, campaign groups and NGOs in Wales who were gravely concerned about its effects. These effects could be far-reaching and damaging – as we have heard from others – in terms of public services, food quality, the environment, health and much more. Concern is growing, but in contrast to the negotiations, which are being held behind closed doors, my group very much welcomes the European citizens’ initiative launched publicly today by over 140 organisations in 18 Member States, which demands that the negotiation mandate be repealed. One of the reasons for the disconnect between the EU and the people of Wales and elsewhere is the perceived lack of democracy and the secrecy. On TTIP we are being kept in the dark. This citizens’ initiative will enable the people’s voices to be heard, and I will encourage my constituents to support it.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, up to now you have imposed on us treaties which deviate from what was originally the spirit of a united and united citizens' Europe. This is always for the use and consumption of the banks and of you a few privileged bureaucrats. And now, with the excuse of a hypothetical uniformity of regulations, you want to impose on us a new treaty, the TTIP, which will eliminate the precautionary principle that has prevailed so far to protect the health and well-being of us European citizens. We will be imposed on GMO foods inflated with hormones, full of toxic antibiotics and pesticides. The certification of controlled origin will be eliminated, thus destroying the heritage of the agri-food excellence of our countries. With the monopoly and genetic uniformity of seeds by multinationals, the vital biodiversity for sustainable agriculture will be compromised. Mr. President, to what extent do you want to harm us citizens, just to guarantee billionaire profits to a few money-hungry multinationals?

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mister President! At the start of the sixth round of negotiations, the two chief negotiators demonstratively shake hands in front of the press. Questions were - what a surprise! - not allowed. According to the old principle: just don't give too much information to the public. Instead, corporations are involved. A recent report by the EU Trade Directorate shows that 92% of the negotiations were carried out beforehand with lobbyists, but only 4% with representatives of the public interest. If you still believe in scare tactics in the food sector, I recommend a letter from 177 US MPs to the House of Representatives. They are demanding that the geographical protection of European products - such as Italian parmesan or Greek feta - be dropped. Of course, the European manufacturers of quality products would fall by the wayside - if they had no protection. The same goes for the consumer, who then no longer has any idea whether they are getting real Italian Parmesan or American Parmesan from anabolic cows. All I can say, Commissioner, is: cheers, enjoy your meal, Europe!

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I will limit myself to the question of investment protection. Even if I'm not making myself popular with you now, I have to say: Basically, I'm not against it. I don't see the rule of law being undermined here. However, it is about greater legal certainty. It is about uniform rules, it is about order in a tangle of 1,400 different agreements. It is also not about only giving advantages to large corporations. Investment protection applies to all investors, including - and we must pay attention to this - medium-sized companies and smaller companies. Hence my question to the Commission: when will the results of the consultation be published? What conclusions will you draw from this? I am not advocating ISDS as we know it from the previous century. I advocate a modern form that is transparent and that will help us all. Last question: what are we going to do with agreements like CETA? Do we have to renegotiate everything, or will it stay with the status we have now? A year ago we were in favor by a large majority. Let us stay on this path, but with a lot of critical support.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we must in every way prevent the debate on the TTIP from becoming more and more ideological, which unfortunately is happening. If we are motivated by the will to make progress as a society, we have to face the arduous work of constant connection with reality. And for this it is essential that we go in the direction of ever greater transparency and ever greater involvement with citizens. But if at the same time we really want Europe to be characterized from now on by jobs and growth, we cannot think that this can only be guaranteed with policies within the European Union. Commercial freedom is a potential source of greater wealth, more jobs, more growth, and it is clear that this can only happen if politics takes it upon itself to limit the imbalances that uncontrolled freedom could generate. This is our job. We can and must use this opportunity to proudly become exporters of the most precious thing we have built in recent years: a social model that includes social protection and workers' rights, consumer safety and health, sustainable growth. One point remains essential with respect to our role and what we stand for. Here we are the demonstration of how cultural diversity, specificity and excellence are a source of great wealth. This is why we insist that the battle against unfair competition and counterfeiting be our priority for the protection of geographical indications and intellectual property. Today a new phase in European history has opened with the appointment of President Juncker. The TTIP treaty could be a test case. We want an agreement, not at all costs but in compliance with non-negotiable values.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: Mr President, first of all I would bring to your attention that we are here in Strasbourg, when as a matter of fact negotiations will take place this week in Brussels, but maybe that is our fault. I, in principle, am supportive of an agreement. However, negotiators on both sides must recognise the significant and valuable role of the European Parliament. MEPs are the most direct and discreet form of public consultation, our constituents are the ones who are set to experience the benefits or costs of an agreement, so it is extremely important that we as their representatives are meaningfully involved. From an agricultural perspective we must adopt a dual approach which recognises both the opportunities and challenges of greater market access. Our founding principle will be that TTIP must not undermine EU standards or compromise local industries. Fair trade for beef is a prime example of the necessary balance which is required; hormone-fed beef must not become the norm for our farmers, who are already under enormous pressure in the market.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mister President! This debate shows very clearly that we need a strong democratic center in this House. Marine Le Pen ridicules democratically elected politicians, then pretends to speak for the peoples of Europe, gives simple answers to difficult questions. I know exactly this rhetoric from the 1930s in my country. I find that scary. And here, at the GUE, there are communists who, on the one hand, immediately demand transparency, but - regardless of whether transparency comes or not, Mr Le Hyaric said that - the negotiations are immediately broken off, the debate ends. This shows that they are not interested in transparency, they are concerned with shooting the agreement, no matter what it says, no matter what. This shows that this is a campaign that is on the move here, from the far right and from the far left. That is hypocrisy, ladies and gentlemen! We all want new jobs, we all want growth in Europe. How are jobs created in Europe? They arise through research and innovation, through new products, through new services and through the opening of new markets! Airbus has tried to enter the American defense market - in vain! These are new jobs in the aviation industry for us in Europe! The food industry - Tokia Saïfi mentioned it: We are a strong continent when it comes to food. On European cheeses you have tariffs above 100%. No ordinary consumer in America can afford that! Down with the tariffs, up with the jobs in Europe! Shoes: The internet is full of frustrated consumers paying hundreds of dollars in tariffs on shoes in both directions. The shoe industry in Italy, the leather processing industry - new jobs are being created in Europe! Those who are against TTIP should stop pretending that they are for jobs and growth in Europe. Let us not forget one thing: in the end, this Parliament decides with a broad democratic majority, which in this case I expressly include the ECR and the Greens. ”(The speaker agrees to a question about the“ blue card ”procedure under Article 162 Paragraph 8 of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: question "blue card". - Mr Lambsdorff, I am going to defend here the Confederal Group of the European United Left / Nordic Green Left, quite simply because if some, already today, believe that the TTIP project does not need to be, it is not out of fundamentalism, it is quite simply because we know very well what is the objective of this treaty. We are always told about 0.5% more growth. You know, I come from business and my habit is to do a cost / benefit analysis. The benefit we are not even sure that it exists but let us even admit that it does exist, who pays the cost in terms of reducing environmental, social and health standards? Who pays it especially in terms of lowering democratic standards? Because the problem with this European Parliament is not only that it is not consulted, but if we put in place the principle of mutual recognition of standards, we can close this shop. We can close it! And it is the American multinationals that will make the laws for us.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Dear colleague Lamberts! There is no talk of general mutual recognition of standards. But if we recognize mutual test standards, for example in the case of motor vehicles, then that would be an enormous relief for ... (Interjection) But that would be a great help in this context - just as if you cut bureaucracy, lower tariffs, simplify test procedures that ours Companies in Europe don't have to go through all this stuff twice when we open public procurement to each other. We have Microsoft software running on IBM computers or DELL computers in all of our public offices. In America there is “Buy American”. We also have European products to offer. At the very least, that American public authorities would buy European cars would be a big step forward. European cars are definitely better than American ones. And finally, I would like to say one more thing: (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Matt CARTHY
text: Mr President, the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership has the potential to damage our environment and devastate the rights of workers, producers and consumers. One of my primary concerns is for the agricultural sector in countries like Ireland. It is clear at this stage already that the unique standards and production systems that apply on Irish family farms, for example, will be compromised in negotiations. Irish farmers are rightly demanding that their livelihoods and their communities are protected. One of the reasons Sinn Féin rejected the Lisbon Treaty was because of the loss of Ireland’s veto on such matters. So there is a responsibility on the Irish Government and on MEPs who sit in this Chamber and who campaigned in favour of the Lisbon Treaty in Ireland on the promise that it would create jobs to stand with Sinn Féin and progressive voices across the European Union in opposition to the TTIP. The European Commission must hear this message today: We will not allow the sell-out of Irish and European farmers for the sake of something that is a bad deal for everyone else.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mister President! Commissioner De Gucht, when it comes to transparency, I would like, so to speak, to pluck a chicken with you. Up until now, you personally and the Commission have regularly turned down calls for more transparency with complacency and condescension. A little while ago at your introduction you were only talking about irrationality and wrong information that you wanted to correct. Can you even understand that there is legitimate criticism? I would like to point out that the new President of the Commission has promised that there is a new beginning here in terms of transparency. What is there so far is not enough. I am not a member of the INTA committee, I am a member of the US delegation, I am a member of the Transatlantic Legislators Dialogue. I cannot go to room 4C18 in Brussels and look at the documents. I cannot ask my colleague Jadot, who was there, what he saw. That is not enough! We need full access to all key negotiating documents. And for NGOs and civil society, we need the same access that the industrial lobby has had for a long time.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, I wanted to speak on the agricultural aspect of the transatlantic treaty. As the sixth stage of this treaty opens this week, we cannot hide our concern at the turn of the negotiations, in particular on questions of geographical indication. So, the Burgundian that I am - defender of Dijon mustard and the magnificent appellations of Burgundy wines: Vougeot, Meursault, Chablis, Puligny-Montrachet - also wants to show solidarity with his French colleagues who want to keep our Camembert or our liver in particular. gras of appellation contrôlée, but also in solidarity with its European colleagues attached to Parma ham, gouda from the Netherlands, beer brewed from Belgium. May all of my colleagues excuse me for not having time to also mention the twenty-eight good products from our continent. American policy, as we know, denies Europeans the right to protect the terroir by a geographical designation, in the name of a financial logic that draws quality downwards. We have a duty before our peoples to protect the art of living of civilization both in France and in Europe. It is therefore important that the Commission and the Parliament strongly oppose the American diktat.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Dear Commissioner, I too would like to draw your attention once again to the letter from the US Senators to Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack, which really calls for aggressive action to be taken against the protected geographical indications and indicators, which in Europe are very strongly anchored in the regions and of course also bring a very high added value with them that these have been recognized as real barriers to trade and should be abolished. I would also like to point out once again that I - together with my EPP colleagues from 15 Member States - have already urged you to oppose this very vehemently. We are not ready to agree to an agreement that in any way endangers agriculture as we know it in Europe and as we also appreciate it. The area of ​​food safety in particular is a very, very sensitive one. But this is primarily about the manufacturing companies that we have in Europe. On the other hand, there is a very overpowering agricultural industry, and I believe that it is neither in the interests of consumers, nor of consumers, and certainly not of producers, to give up the high European standards in any way.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, listening to the Commission, I sometimes have the impression that all is well in the best of all possible worlds. Sleep peacefully, we are preparing a bright future for you. The problem, Commissioner, is that many elected officials, but also millions of fellow citizens do not share this point of view. They have doubts about the timeliness of this transatlantic agreement, on its merits, and they also have doubts about the fact that generalized free trade necessarily promotes growth and employment. You have estimates that are still very uncertain. You promise us a bright future for 2027, but the gains and advances that you are proposing to us seem very hypothetical. On the other hand, the risks, and this has been stressed on all the benches of this Assembly, the risks are very important: risks for labor law, risks for social standards, risks for environmental standards, risks for health standards and frankly, dear colleagues, when I hear you - and I am new to this Assembly - I tell myself that if we add up all these risks, all these threats and we want to say to ourselves: " that it is worth it? " I am reassured at least on two points of everything I have heard: first, the secrecy of the negotiations for all of you is unacceptable. And that is good, because we have a democratic Parliament and, secondly, it is not possible that we will accept any longer a mechanism which is contrary to European dispute settlement law. I'm talking about ISDS.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: Mr. Chairman! Commissioner! From the point of view of the entire Union, as well as my country - Poland, one of the most important issues that must be negotiated in this agreement should be the lifting of license restrictions and free gas trade between America and the Union, as is the case with countries with which The United States has signed free trade agreements. In a situation where in 2013 the average gas price in the United States was three times lower than in the EU, maintaining this state in the long term means moving energy-intensive factories from the EU to the United States on a massive scale, and this in turn means the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs in Europe. The second issue, extremely important from the point of view of the entire EU and Poland, which will be resolved in this agreement, is the liberalization of trade in food products, including, unfortunately, genetically modified food, as well as meat with growth hormones. This issue probably cannot be excluded from the agreement, and therefore immediate action is needed in the Union to clearly label such food so that consumers in all EU countries have an authentic choice on store shelves. If we do not do this, healthy European food, probably a little more expensive than the American one, will be forced out of the market, which means serious problems for European agriculture. Thank you.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Commissioner, thank you for your work. We all know what's in the game. If we agree with the United States, we will create the largest free trade area in the world. And we will be able to compete with other economic players, especially from Asia. But there is something even more important. Do we happen to be bothered by low economic growth and high unemployment? This agreement, if well negotiated, is a chance to address these issues. Your task, Commissioner, is to negotiate a wording that removes all obstacles for our entrepreneurs, protects their interests and innovations, but at the same time - and this is no less important - does not lower the quality standards and the level of protection for our consumers. Commissioner, one big task is for you. Our citizens do not understand these negotiations, they do not know what these negotiations are about and they are afraid of them. We therefore need to increase transparency and change the communication strategy. Because we can only create an effective transatlantic partnership if we have citizens on our side.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Mr President, after this debate we have here, it seems to me that if the Treaty were really so interesting for European citizens, the Commissioner and the Commission would not hesitate for a moment to make all the documents on the Treaty public.But of course, I think they don't do it because, first of all, they know perfectly well that this Treaty is going to mean more job insecurity;they know perfectly well that this treaty will mean the privatization of basic and essential public services, such as health or education - and not only privatize, but also make this privatization irreversible.Thirdly, they know perfectly well that it will mean the ruin of peasant agriculture, of small and medium peasant farmers in Europe.They know perfectly well that it will mean the end of the precautionary principle and that it will mean handing over the sovereignty of the peoples to transnational corporations.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: This is a free trade agreement between the European Union and the United States, it is a nicely packaged but very harmful commodity.Beautiful packaging means that there is a need to create jobs, even though it has not been proven at all that such a free trade agreement would create a mass of jobs.Moreover, there are examples to the contrary.The real goal is to assert the interests of global companies vis-à-vis national governments.U.S. companies can sue national governments before elected private courts if their decision harms their profit interests.Further liberalization of the food trade, the risk of the introduction of genetically modified products, is particularly dangerous.This partnership agreement infringes the sovereignty of the Member States and even the EU, does not serve the interests of the European people, and should therefore not be concluded.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: Mr. Chairman! Commissioner! I invited to Katowice to the European Economic Congress both main negotiators, from the American side and from the European side. Thank you, Commissioner De Gucht, for supporting this initiative. This resulted in very specific conclusions, I would like to give specific examples of what our small, medium and larger entrepreneurs expect. Firstly, the free movement of raw materials, especially energy resources, is a condition for our competitiveness, innovation, and the creation of new jobs on both sides of the Atlantic. Secondly, if we are talking about reindustrialisation, it must be remembered that a mechanism is needed to compensate for huge differences in CO2 emissions, crucial for energy-intensive industries. On both sides of the Atlantic, we need to do the same. Third - cooperation in the field of research, innovation, standards, regulations, norms. And the fourth last point, we are opening the market to America, we need a good organization of our own market, the construction of a common energy market, a common telecommunications market. These were the conclusions of what European entrepreneurs said on this subject.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I believe that this Agreement - and after listening to all my colleagues - needs a lot of pedagogy and a lot of transparency more than ever. Pedagogy, to influence that Europe needs to grow, and grow more competitive, creating quality jobs, paying decent wages, which are precisely what we defend in the welfare state that we support. And, therefore, I think it is important to support this Agreement, a trade and investment agreement with the United States, in order to have that greater capacity for growth. Now, that agreement cannot be just any agreement, and I believe that many of us have defended the same. I cannot defend, as a socialist that I am, an agreement that implies a reduction in European standards in social, labor, health or environmental terms. Nor can I defend an agreement that does not guarantee a solid protection of personal private data, and the diverse culture of our European Union, nor an agreement that does not include the regulation of financial markets, because we must never forget where we are now as a consequence of the lack of regulation of these markets. But I also told him that transparency is essential. You have said before that negotiators on the part of the United States cannot offer Members of the European Parliament the information that they do not provide American MPs. I do not know what the American parliamentarians are willing to accept. Of course, what is evident is that the Members of the European Parliament are not going to support an agreement if we do not have the necessary information to have a good basis to guarantee us what the conditions of the agreements are. I think you have made progress in this regard and I ask you for more, please.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: Mr President, we should not underestimate what a huge achievement a free pact with the US would be. The benefits to the EU economy are conservatively measured in the billions, and this is a practical step we can take to achieve real economic recovery. Although investor-state dispute resolution and transparency are genuine issues, they are solvable and should not be used as an excuse for protectionism. The best way to get the global economy moving again is via increased capital flows with appropriate financial supervision and regulation that avoids loopholes between jurisdictions. Ninety-five per cent of derivative trades and 80% of all financial transactions happen between the EU and the US. We finally have high-level agreements that our legislation on both sides of the Atlantic should achieve the same outcomes, yet barriers remain. TTIP should provide a framework for both the US and the EU to meet and solve remaining areas of contention, even outside of the formal trade agreement. The political will is already there to work together. It is now up to both American and EU politicians – and regulators – to show that they are able to achieve tangible results that really do break down the barriers to moving capital, as well as goods and services, on both sides.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Mr President, I wish to quickly raise three points. We will have ample opportunity to come back to this agreement and to this debate. I am pleased to note the very firm commitment of the Commissioner. Our health, social and environmental standards are not negotiable, you said, Mr De Gucht. This cracks the necks of many of the fantasies that were conveyed during the campaign by opponents of this agreement. No beef with hormones, no chlorinated chicken, either. We will be vigilant with regard to this commitment, a Sioux vigilance, I would even say. Second, the famous ISDS, the investor-state procedure that has been put on hold because it raises so many questions and questions. It will take time, you said, to learn the lessons. In any case and given the sensitivity, the very explosiveness, of this subject, why not simply trust our common law justice which, it seems to me, works well on both sides of the Atlantic? Finally, an even more fundamental question: the risk of divorce with our opinions. Does the European Commission realize that it is losing this battle of public opinion in some Member States? I note moreover that the ministers concerned are silent in all languages. So there you have it, the first blockage is there, Commissioner. He is not technical, he is a citizen and this duty of explanation is more than a priority, it is an emergency.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Mr President! Over 100 meetings with business lobbyists and only a handful of environmental, trade union and consumer organizations, it shows who is in the driver's seat for these projects and for these negotiations. And TTIP is not about the trade in shoes and bicycles, but it is ultimately about which society we want to live in and which democratic principles should apply. According to current drawings, TTIP threatens the environment, trade union rights, public health and not least democracy. And the right and the big companies sit and cheer and clap in time in this kind of race to the bottom - a harmonization to the lowest possible level. This shows the leaked documents. TTIP contains investment protection that gives large companies even more power to sue states if democratic decisions would reduce their profits. That is unacceptable. It is not just us on the left who will not accept it - the citizens of Europe will never accept such a trade agreement. For democracy, we do not compromise with it.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for the information you provide us on the negotiations of the agreement. Fortunately, through the chief negotiator, Mr. García Bercero, in this Parliament, in the previous legislature, we have been regularly and closely informed about the negotiation process. The Agreement with the United States is ambitious, balanced and mutually beneficial. It will also be very important for the growth and job creation that we all need. Its conclusion, according to all analyzes, will contribute to the economic prosperity of both sides of the Atlantic and, in addition, it will serve to revitalize the relations between two strategic partners when there is so much talk about the Asia-Pacific region. Two additional comments: First, I trust that, in parallel with this agreement, satisfactory solutions will be reached with the United States on data protection and telecommunications privacy - it is a sensitive issue that could have a negative influence if not is resolved in this agreement. Second, the Agreement - and it is a very positive aspect - will open the prospect of a large triangular economic space that would include other Latin American partners with whom, both the European Union and the United States, we have trade agreements.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr. Chairman, I will only repeat to you, Mr. De Gucht, the few guidelines that my group has constantly reminded you of and which will determine whether or not we will actually support this TTIP at the end of the process. First, the transparency - we have talked about it a lot - of the negotiation process, which is not limited to saying that the five thousand pages of the file are in a searchable room but which requires that you, you, make them understandable by all. Second point, the defense of social, environmental and health standards and above all, the guarantee for us, States as Europe, but also as Member States, to be able to continue to adopt regulations in the interest of our fellow citizens. . The third point, which has also been talked about a lot, is the exclusion of the ISDS mechanism. And the fourth point, the defense of our public service and the exclusion of the cultural sector. So Mr Juncker this morning told us to what extent he supported the points I have just spoken of and the points which are the guidelines that the Socialists have given you. I dare to hope, Commissioner, that the three months remaining in this Commission will be used to correct the situation, because, unfortunately today, the Commission has not given us any guarantees on these points.

name: João FERREIRA
text: This European Union-United States free trade agreement is one of those topics capable of separating waters. Separate the waters between the defenders of regulated trade, based on complementarity relations, and the defenders of unregulated trade, based on competition between producing and production countries. Among the defenders of the primacy of the public interest, respect for economic, social and labor rights, and the defenders of the interests and profits of multinationals and monopolies, the race to the bottom in terms of rights and the devaluation of the workforce. Among the defenders of environmental sustainability and the safeguarding of public health, and those who in exchange for new markets yield to principles such as precaution. Among the defenders of public services as an inalienable civilizational achievement and those who defend the advancement of the market, like a steamroller, on the social functions of the States. This is a confrontation between those who defend the right to development and the right to produce, of all peoples and countries, and those who defend the protectionism of the rich and powerful.

name: József SZÁJER
text: I am not among those who are already opposed to something unknown, but neither are those who support it. I will therefore talk about the basic conditions for a possible future grant. The aim of the transatlantic free trade negotiations is to increase competitiveness in order to have more jobs. Small businesses should also benefit from this contract. In order for European businesses to be able to compete with their American counterparts, energy prices in Europe must be reduced. It is an inability for this to be successful at current energy prices. If the market is not able to do this alone, then, as in Hungary's overhead reduction, the regulatory authorities, the state and the Union must intervene. We did the same for roaming charges. The conclusion of the agreement must not endanger human health, the environment or the interests of consumers. Chlorine-washed poultry or GMOs are not. It is also essential for the support that the Member States, the European Parliament, all participants are informed. Make this process not only transatlantic but also transparent from start to finish. Because what we do not know enough, we cannot responsibly support or oppose.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: Mr President, recent Pew Research Centre work on public opinion on TTIP shows that while people on both sides of the Atlantic do not yet fully oppose the trade deals, they generally do not expect to get more jobs, higher wages or lower prices out of them. That being the case, Commissioner De Gucht, what should you be doing to convince them that they will actually benefit from TTIP?  It feels like we have forgotten our history. Working people in my home country only supported and continue to support the European Union’s internal market because it comes attached to a social model, and public services are a key pillar of that social model. Last week the EU chief negotiator wrote to allay the UK public’s fear about the use of TTIP to lock in the current UK Government’s back-door privatisation of our National Health Service. Now we are not naive in the Labour Party or in the UK, we know that the biggest threat to our NHS is the Tories and not TTIP, but the British people do not want to see a narrow exemption only for it to become subject to privatisation creep in the years to come. What more can you do to reassure public sector users and workers that TTIP will prevent further privatisation or liberalisation of our public services? Since ‘trust me’ has not worked so far, will you commit to a public consultation on how we can protect our public services?

name: Franck PROUST
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I do not know what is more serious? Whether rumors guide the debates in this hemicycle or whether they guide them within the population? Commissioner, are you respecting the negotiating mandate you have been given? I would like you to provide proof today that you did not go beyond the negotiating mandate in agriculture, for example, as a persistent rumor tells us. Do you have the confidence of the other European Commissioners on these questions? I want to reiterate that we are the world's leading trading power. So let's stay credible. It is through this power that we must impose our limits. What are the real resources, both human and financial, implemented for this negotiation? Your mandate is coming to an end and above all, do not make the mistake of wanting to open up as many subjects as possible to liberalization, otherwise your name will remain associated with the failure of a historic agreement with the United States. The watchwords are transparency, firmness, as well as the protection of businesses and citizens. They must be anchored in those who are currently negotiating this agreement.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, TTIP is a truly strategic partnership and a great opportunity for the European economy. At stake is not only an ambitious trade agreement between the two largest world economies, but also a powerful movement of regulatory convergence that will mark the world of international trade towards more regulated globalization. If TTIP takes proper care of the interests of the Union and its Member States, it can bring many benefits to our economies. The European Parliament has already declared its support for the development of these negotiations and defended the safeguarding of European values ​​and social, labor and environmental aspects. And it is important that the Commission takes seriously the positions of Parliament, which has the competence for the final approval of this agreement. I leave two notes here: the first, Commissioner, it is necessary to win the support of public opinion and only transparency will be worthy of trust and what has been done is not enough. I therefore ask, what initiatives will the Commission take to increase transparency in the TTIP negotiation? The second issue concerns financial services. We know the resistance of the American side. We want to know if the Commissioner is considering a parallel agreement and if he is in a position to guarantee… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if I were to evaluate at this moment with respect to the interventions that have been made, I would seem to understand that no contribution can be made in the direction of achieving the objective of safeguarding all the issues that have been addressed. It would seem to me a disaster, with a precise objective and strategy to bury Europe, to realize the condition that European democracy no longer has any meaning. On the other hand, I want to hope and I want to believe that this is not the case, Mr. President. I want to hope instead that there is the possibility of working, because our goal is to safeguard that economic, strategic and central framework that is called European small and medium-sized enterprises. I believe that commercial and regulatory barriers give advantage, today to the state and with current rules, only and exclusively to multinationals that can achieve the best conditions of profit and can achieve the best conditions of advantage, without worrying absolutely to inform in terms of transparency, just as today we firmly ask for this to happen.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: The United States is our greatest ally and the second largest economy in the world after the European Union. So, of course, a trade agreement with the United States offers many reciprocal benefits. But we do not want those benefits at any price. The treaty must not only benefit Europe, but also benefit European citizens and not just a few investment companies, fast bankers or large multinationals. Because then we will never regain the trust of all those citizens who stayed at home in the European elections. The profits from a possible trade deal should go to metalworkers whose contracts are under pressure or to the countless young people who are at home because they cannot find work. If this trade agreement is to lead to anything, then it is to more jobs, to work, work, and more work, that's what matters. What we cannot import with this trade agreement are the disposable jobs from the United States. Our European workers earn decent salaries and have good protection against dismissal, so there is no need to take a second or third job to make ends meet. In short, we are happy to participate in a real trade agreement, but not at any price!

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Mr President, the Crimean occupation and continued aggression in eastern Ukraine have more than ever displayed the need for even deeper and more integrated cooperation, not only between European countries but between the EU and the US as well. I am sure all of us would agree that the Free Trade Agreement not only boosts economic growth and the creation of new jobs, but at this time can be regarded as a means for ensuring geopolitical stability and peace in Europe. That is why we have to ensure relevant political attention and that the negotiations with us will not stall and they will move forward. Even more, we can observe how, as if by chance, at every step of the negotiations between the EU and the US some damaging information appears. One could start suspecting that someone is interested in stopping the process as early as possible. That is one more reason why we have to keep pushing forward.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the ongoing negotiations with the United States for the creation of a transatlantic free trade area represent a great opportunity for greater integration and economic growth. Greater liberalization of trade in goods and services as well as a removal of non-tariff barriers and wider regulatory convergence will certainly stimulate productivity and facilitate the exit from the economic crisis by creating new jobs in Europe. However, it is necessary that the negotiations deliver us a final balanced agreement, in which the new opportunities for a European production system in search of new markets are not dissipated by sacrificing the quality that characterizes the made in Europe and the principles of our social model. In particular, the defense of our food safety standards and the full enhancement of the European system of geographical indications, safeguarding European quality production, will represent a fundamental key to determining whether the TTIP will be a real opportunity or an opportunity for the European Union. missed opportunity. In this sense, on the one hand we should guarantee citizens, defending the precautionary principle and the rights of consumers, and on the other hand, support the European production system centered on small and medium-sized enterprises, choosing to take the path of growth and recovery through defense. of quality European agri-food productions.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: Mr President, TTIP represents unquestionable geopolitical benefits. However, it is predominantly a trade agreement and therefore it must be economically beneficial to EU companies. Companies that invest and produce in Europe hire European workers and pay taxes in Europe. The reality is that we have very high regulatory costs (thanks to ETS, REACH and the like), much higher electricity prices, a very high gas price – and now we will remove all duties on imports from the US where the gas is a quarter of our price, and electricity is one half. How are we to compete with this? Just to be clear, I am in favour of this partnership, but we need the Commission to negotiate a beneficial deal that will address the higher costs of regulatory compliance in the EU and does not put in danger EU industries that create hundreds of thousands of jobs and pay millions of euros in taxes every year.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, Commissioner, repetition is the best pedagogy. Yes, transparency on the draft transatlantic agreement must be total and not a reading room transparency. A substantive, democratic and public debate involving citizens, civil society and social partners is essential. That is why I am asking, with the Socialists, for the exhaustive publication of the content of the discussions after each round of negotiations. We also demand scrupulous respect for all legislation and collective preferences on which our European social model is based. Any eventual agreement must promote the highest standards in terms of the environment, public health, food safety, social rights and fundamental rights; also preserve our public services and cultural diversity; and finally, to exclude - but this has been said to you many times - the mechanism for settling disputes between investors and States. The quality of the agreement must take precedence over the schedule! I cannot imagine that our geographical indications are not protected or that the quality and excellence of our products, especially agricultural ones, are called into question. No chlorinated chicken, no hormone beef, no GMOs, no cloning for food.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, most of us strongly defended during the election campaign the importance of boosting growth and job creation. Therefore, I am surprised that those who most vigorously defended these issues in the electoral campaign are today criticizing this Agreement with the United States, which is precisely an instrument to promote growth and job creation. According to some estimates, dear colleagues, the GDP of the European Union could grow appreciably thanks to this Agreement. More than two million jobs could be created in the European Union; 143,000 of them in Spain, in my country. I am therefore surprised that some of you are attacking this Agreement with such virulence, from which, by the way, SMEs will precisely benefit the most. Finally, Commissioner, I would like to remind you of the importance of including financial services in the negotiation of this Agreement.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, honored Commissioner! I believe that the TTIP agreement is of great importance because it strengthens political ties between Europe and America - us great democracies on this earth that combine many values. TTIP is an important matter, for the economy too. That creates jobs, brings more competitiveness. We must counter all protectionists: protectionism has still destroyed jobs, while free trade has created jobs. (Applause) When I see this there - the venerable leftists and communists: you have never met your demands with the standards that you have in any country in which you have ever governed, always achieving the opposite, in terms of the environment and consumer protection and the like. Please don't upset us with this. Here, things are connected to the contract that are not even negotiated! European standards in the social sector, in the consumer sector, in the environmental sector will not be destroyed! This Parliament has appropriated the rights of the legislature on this issue. We're not giving that up to arbitration! It is not intended that this could be accommodated there. On the contrary, with the Americans we can enforce standards worldwide, from the prohibition of child labor to copyright law being respected. We can set industry standards to be more competitive on this basis, to secure our jobs, to survive in this world! That's the way things are! I do not want an alliance of protectionists, anti-Americans and others who invent a lot that has nothing to do with the facts and thus destroy our European interests, the interests of our workers. That is why one should support TTIP. But it also means, Commissioner, if I may make a comment that we should try perhaps not to do this as a mixed agreement, but rather to restrict it as an agreement, at least in part that can be ratified in this House. If it goes into 28 national parliaments, we get a problem. Maybe one should think again. But we should oppose this campaign in the social services that have nothing to do with the negotiations.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Madam President! This is a very important topic that we are talking about today. We have to think very carefully. So I'll see it a little differently than the previous speaker. We have a fundamental principle in our European Union that is particularly important, namely the precautionary principle. The precautionary principle is of the utmost importance in the areas of agriculture and consumer protection. That is one of the questions on which we currently have a dissent with the United States, which is demanding that we do without it. We cannot accept that like that. Yes, we can do business with the US, but not just any trade. And we will take Mr Juncker at his word, who said very clearly today that we do not want to agree to any agreement, but rather to make sure that it is something sensible. If it is not sensible for consumer protection, environmental protection, data protection or other important areas to be called into question, then we cannot agree. And that's why I say very clearly: We have to make sure that what is going to be in these texts is looked at very carefully, and we have to help ensure that the best for our citizens comes out of it. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mrs Gebhardt!I would like to ask you: do you see an advantage in the TTIP agreement, especially as regards workers?What is your attitude here?Can you see an advantage in this agreement, or are there only disadvantages?

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- At the moment I can see neither advantages nor disadvantages because I do not yet know the texts.I cannot say what it says about a text that I do not know and how I should judge it.However, I will say one thing very clearly: I cannot agree to a text that would contain disadvantages for workers' rights, for social rights or something like that, and my group will not agree to either.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, dear colleagues! It is good, as Elmar Brok said, when the US and Europe, as great democracies, work better together. It is imperative that we get rid of useless bureaucracy. But as the coordinator of the EPP in the Environment Committee, I naturally have to make sure that we really enforce our standards. There are some critical discussions, especially in the food sector. I am really disappointed, Commissioner, that contrary to the proposal of the European Parliament and the lead Commissioner in the Commission with the argument TTIP, the demands in the area of ​​cloned meat labeling were rejected. I think that's dangerous. It can weaken acceptance, so you should reconsider it. When we talk about it with those in charge in America, the main thing is that it is a question of information and clarification. But we have to take people's worries seriously. I was not elected - and we were not elected - to teach people that we know better. So you should include this demand. I believe that then we can fight for the agreement more credibly. We have to be sensitive and then we can advertise the benefits with a clear conscience.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: Madam President, while we should certainly look at the TTIP from the point of view of the economic opportunities it will generate, it is also clear that its public perception matters strongly. TTIP will be attracting a growing amount of public attention, and there are legitimate anxieties linked to it which will have to be addressed. But we must not see TTIP as a simple sum of individual stakeholder interests. It is an unprecedented strategic deal between the largest economies and democracies of the world, with robust welfare growth and job consequences for the transatlantic citizen. It is a deal with significant global relevance. While the benefits from the deal will be more mid- to long-term, the confidence of the citizens needs to be earned today. This is also our responsibility in this House. It is up to us in the European Parliament to reflect on how the critical mass of the benefits can be measured and it is also up to us in the European Parliament to contribute, in a constructive way, to the final assessment of its added value.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! During this debate today, I thought several times whether all colleagues had not yet understood that the election campaign was now over. It is as colleagues Rübig and Winkler clearly said earlier: with the decision to start negotiations, for the transatlantic free trade agreement, which the 28 member states of the European Union have supported, we stand against the background of the fact that the Globalization will at some point be even more popular in Europe and we will only remain strong if we position ourselves correctly. That is why we are negotiating, and this goal remains correct - regardless of whether there are points that we like in these negotiations that have become known so far or not. Of course, we have to take citizens' concerns seriously. But we also have to make it clear why we started the negotiations and why we believe we can bring them to a happy conclusion. The world around Europe - this is important to me as a single market politician - is not standing still. If we don't position ourselves properly, it will pass us by. We do this in the interests of the citizens, the employees and, ultimately, the consumers too. If we do it right - and this is of course also about public relations work - then we can win the citizens over to this agreement. That is why I am counting on you, Commissioner, to intensify communication accordingly.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Madam President, this is a work in progress but as you can hear from the range of views in this House we are very vigilant on the possible outcome. Truthfully I would like to have heard a little bit more about another deal, the Canadian deal, which I understand is still being negotiated. Commissioner, perhaps you might give us a short update as to what is happening there. I have a specific issue around beef which I think you are aware of, and it might be helpful to the House to hear an update. But this morning we spoke about growth and jobs and a good TTIP can deliver both growth and jobs for Europe and the European Union. That is why we should stick with the process but also acknowledge that there are concerns around certain sectors that need to be acknowledged. You have given some reassurances on food safety standards and I welcome that, but that must be copper-fastened into any potential agreement. But on the beef sector again, the issues are sensitive, not so much around that particular point, because you have clarified the hormones issue, but around quantities and types of cuts that will be allowed in. If you are not careful there, you will decimate Europe’s beef production capacity and that would be a step too far and a real concern for this House.

name: Milan ZVER
text: The situation in the world has changed considerably since the end of the Cold War. Today, we have already established that the Ukrainian crisis has revived old Russian geostrategic goals, and China has long been re-establishing its military, political and economic supremacy in many parts of the world. Other areas are also growing stronger in economic and demographic terms. The US and the European Union, which are the most culturally related, are losing on a global scale. If we accept a free trade agreement with the US, there will be huge benefits for everyone. More jobs, higher GDP and consequently more prosperity. We will remove systemic barriers and create a new space for a free economy and democracy that will reverse trends and make both the EU and the US more competitive. However, it is important that Europe also incorporates specific interests into the agreement, such as high standards of personal data protection, social solidarity, healthy food and the environment. That is why the EU-US alliance should also become a strong alliance of values. Only in this way will we preserve the culture and our lifestyle for generations to come.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Madam President, I choose to speak in favour of the TTIP this afternoon. The TTIP is not and should not be just another free trade agreement. It is a historic milestone, as it will create a transatlantic market of opportunities for Europe and the US. With the two particular sectors I want to refer to, firstly a common transatlantic approach to the digital economy, ICT and innovation will continue driving enormous productivity in our economy, encouraging investment, while our creative and hyper-connected youth will be creating their own opportunities on the market; and secondly, an extended deal on energy trade within the TTIP will allow cheaper prices for consumers but also for our industry, making it more competitive on world markets while we will ensure security of supply and therefore our independence. In today’s world we cannot afford to miss the opportunity, and as the proverb says: if you want to go fast, go alone; if you want to go far, go together.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Mr President, I have listened to the debate from the outset and I have listened with a certain amount of bemusement. Firstly, most people, while sharing various concerns regarding TTIP, are in favour of the process taking place. Others are against it from the outset. They seem to be against TTIP – I would say perhaps against the USA rather than TTIP per se. Why would you oppose the opportunity to create two million jobs in Europe, 0.5% of GDP and EUR 550 per family per year? Yet this is what they want to do. We all have concerns about TTIP regarding agriculture, data protection, standards, etc. but that is what negotiation is all about. I say let the negotiations continue, then we can make up our minds based on fact not fiction, reality not perception. Let us get on with it.

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, many things have been discussed here today and, above all, small and medium-sized enterprises, but there has been no discussion of a sector that I believe is very important. This is the footwear industry sector, which in Europe employs many small and medium-sized companies, companies that are paying tariffs to sell in the United States - in the case of textile footwear, 12%, and leather, 8%. %, even reaching, in some cases, up to 48% tariff— while our competitors, who are in Morocco or Mexico, are not paying anything. I ask you some questions: our competitors, Morocco and Mexico, no longer pay, but what has been the offer from the Americans towards our productions? Has the European Commission proposed the complete removal of tariffs for the European footwear sector in this Agreement? What position will the Commission maintain on textiles, and particularly on footwear, in the negotiating rounds that are opening from now on?

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: Madam President, a comprehensive agreement on trade liberalisation between the EU and the US is urgently needed, given the growing competitive pressures coming from emerging new powers such as China and India. The planned opening of markets offers important economic benefits. The TTIP would increase the GDP of both partners by between about 0.5% and 1% if implemented fully. The agreement would also make sense for political reasons as it would consolidate the long-term strategic alliance between the EU and the US which is necessary to confront new risks and challenges in the era of globalisation and international conflicts. We must not miss this unique opportunity; removal of trade barriers is necessary to increase the competitiveness of European firms and to create new jobs in Europe. Of course there are also risks involved. The level of protection in areas such as personal data protection or health and veterinary standards should not be reduced. Also transition periods should apply in sectors where US firms enjoy a large competitive advantage, but on balance this agreement deserves our support.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: Hon. European Commission representative, Hon. Representative of the Presidency of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, regarding the terms of the Atlantic Pact, let us not be innocent, nor be under any illusions: there will be gains but there will also be losses and risks. I know that potential gains are being announced, but I am particularly concerned about the losses that are being announced in the agricultural sector. I appeal here for European farmers not to be taken hostage to a potential agreement. There are clear risks, for example, in the meat and dairy sector where the United States is highly competitive in terms of price. The risk is even greater for small-scale agricultural economies, as is the case for example in the Azores and exactly in relation to these sectors. Still, in my country, among others, the tomato sector may suffer such an impact as to lead to the abandonment of production.
