I therefore reinforce the call to the European Commission to pay particular attention to the interests of European farmers in negotiating the terms of the agreement with the United States and to establish the necessary balances for the preservation and dynamization of agricultural practice in Europe, especially where agricultural activity acquires a special preponderance that is hardly substitutable as an economic activity.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: Madam President, there are many positive and negative aspects to TTIP but in my one minute I shall just deal with just one issue, and that is the inclusion of investor-state dispute settlements (ISDS) in the agreement. ISDS are viewed with extreme concern by many citizens including myself. In 2012, 62 cases were investigated and in 2013 the figure was 57. This clearly indicates that the concerns of citizens and governments are well founded. In your response to a recent question which I submitted to you, Commissioner, you replied that genuine regulatory action cannot be successfully challenged. Surely, Commissioner, our competition and internal market rules should ensure genuine regulatory action by Member States. I believe that ISDS are not needed by two functioning and predictable legal systems. You also replied that any regulation passed in the public interest cannot be successfully challenged, but who is to decide what is in the public interest – an arbitration tribunal? Surely that is not acceptable. Concerns ranging from GMOs to fracking have been legitimately raised in the context of ISDS, and if the Commission ignores them you run the risk of failure. The possibilities of TTIP are too important for that.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for your appearance. We get the impression that the Transatlantic Treaty is yet another turn of the screw on a series of failed policies. As we are unable to define a serious growth strategy, within the framework of the European Union and the euro area itself, now it seems that we want to give a twist to liberalization, as if that were to be the solution to all problems. That seems to us a totally wrong and wrong approach. Furthermore, I must tell you that throughout this debate you are seeking, through the TTIP, the liberalization of many sectors within the European Union that you should tackle through a public debate, if that is what some of you want. If you want to enter the liberalization of many of our sectors, do not do so through the negotiation of a trade agreement behind the back of the public, but open the debate. Therefore, simply reiterating that this type of agreement does not seem to us the solution for the future of the European economy and, in any case, we are going to define a future strategy that helps citizens to move forward and not failed international treaties. free trade that we will have to pay for in the coming years.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: Transatlantic relations are currently on a very thin ice.The TTIP agreement is one of our biggest international challenges.Both Parliament and the Commission actually have a new mandate, and we have a unique opportunity to move forward.Our role is to approach the United States as a partner and ally.It will be important to negotiate an agreement that reflects the benefits for both parties.Negotiations must be transparent and clearly communicated to our citizens.The European Parliament will have the final say in the adoption of this agreement.However, this agreement must respect our requirements and will not be finalized at any cost.We will stand for a balanced and fair free trade agreement.When it comes to protecting the personal data of Europeans or the security of our food, we need to think about our citizens, from whom we have a mandate, and therefore we must protect their interests.

name: Karel DE GUCHT
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, what shall I begin with after this very long debate – a very rich one also? It seems to me that several debates are mixed up: the debate on whether or not you are in favour of trade; the debate on whether or not you consider the United States to be a fair partner; and the debate on whether or not negotiations are sufficiently transparent. Let me start with the first one: for or against trade. I realise after this debate – and I have to say also before the debate – there are a number of Members in this Parliament that I will never persuade that trade makes sense. I will never convince them because they are against trade so what can I change about that? I could reply with a question: can you give me an example, be it by the Far Left or the Far Right (which by the way has disappeared – they are not there any more, they have left in peace) of a country, of a society that has been able to develop without trade? If you give me some of those examples then I am ready to discuss further with you. Secondly, the United States: I already mentioned in my introduction that this looks a little bit to me like a Kulturkampf, for or against the United States. I find this a rather strange debate, because obviously we differ on a number of issues with the United States – as I do myself as well, and I largely prefer the European way of life to the American way of life – but is that what it is about? I thought it was about trying to work together so that we can create jobs and growth in our own countries. I thought that was what it was about. I do not want to be the same as the United States’ citizens, and most of them do not want to be like Europeans either, or at least like some of us. It is about finding solutions together, to grow, to have more impetus in our economy. That is what it is about; it is not about changing American society, it is not about changing our society. We are different and we want to be different, but does it mean we cannot work together? If we cannot work together with the United States, with whom then can we work together? They are different from us but are all the rest then closer to us? The agreement with Canada has also been mentioned today, which is in fact ready apart from a couple of lines, maybe not even that. That agreement too is now called into question. We have made an agreement with Singapore. Are we going to relinquish it? Last week we initialled the economic partnership agreement with ECOWAS, with the West of Africa. Can we still speak with them? Today the EPA agreement with SADC has been initialled. Do we refuse to even discuss that because they are not the same as we are? What is the sense of that? It is about working together; it is not about being identical. Please! Then there is the discussion on transparency. There has never been a trade agreement conducted in as much transparency as this one – never! For a number of reasons: it is only since the Treaty of Lisbon that this Parliament has the competence to ratify agreements. As long as you did not have that competence obviously that was different, and now we have to adapt to that new situation, but I would claim that we have been doing this with a lot of diligence. Our positions, the positions of the Commission, you can read them on our website. If you read them all you are going to spoil your summer holidays you can be sure of that, because there are thousands and thousands of pages there. At the start of this Commission we agreed that all the documents that we give to the Member States and to the European Council, we would also give to the European Parliament. That has never happened before, you know, and again with TTIP negotiations we have been doing that in a very diligent way. Now there are of course a number of difficult problems in this. For example the Council – and I am pleased that they are finally are present – refused to make the mandate public. I asked – no, let me start a little bit earlier. Madame Bricq, the former French Minister of Trade, wrote me a letter some time ago saying: why don't you make the mandate public? It was their mandate, it is not mine. It is a Council document. It is not a parliamentary document. And again in May we had the discussion at my request with the Council, a very long discussion by the way, to make the mandate public. Again there was no majority for doing that. Now it seems that finally they have come to the conclusion that maybe it is not such a bad idea to make it public. By the way, everybody has it. It is on the Internet. So what are you talking about? It is on the Internet. You are questioning me on the basis of texts that you have, but that obviously you have not read, because if you had read those texts you will see that we are not going to change the phytosanitary norms, the norms for the protection of the environment, for labour rights and whatever. It is explicitly in the mandate that you all have, or at least you should have read before starting this debate. On the problem of the reading rooms: I am against reading rooms. I do not like them. What is the problem with this? The problem with this is that the United States – which is also a big economy, they are also negotiating a lot of trade agreements, for example the trans-Pacific partnership with a lot of countries in Asia – the way that they inform their Members of Parliament is by inviting them to a reading room, having the documents at their disposal. They can read them, they get information about it, they can ask questions about it, they cannot take copies and hopefully they leave happy. That is the practice on the Hill in Washington. You should understand from me that it is rather difficult to convince the Americans to give to us more than they give to their own Members of Parliament about their text. Because our texts are known, our positions are known. It is about their positions. If they give us a document saying: ‘You can only make it available to your parliamentarians the way we make it available to our parliamentarians’, I cannot change much about that. But can you call that secrecy? Really, anybody who wants to follow what happens – I hope he or she does not get bored, that is something else – can amuse themselves every day with it. Every day there is something new about this. It must be fascinating, because so many people are interested in knowing something that does not yet exist. Because everybody is against this agreement to my knowledge – and I should know – but there is no agreement yet. We started the negotiations a year ago; we have six rounds of negotiations, the sixth one is ongoing at the moment. We have had two political stock-takes. We are making progress on a number of issues but we still have an enormous number of difficulties: with respect to market taxes for example, where we say that we need much more market access for public procurement, much more; where we say that not all tariffs will disappear, that there will be a number of sensitive agricultural products where the tariffs as such will not disappear. Probably there will be a system of what they call TRQs, tariff rated quotas, but we are not going to give that up. We are not negotiating about lowering standards in these negotiations. For example, we are negotiating how we could make a number of regulations more compatible by sticking to the levels of protection that we presently have in the European Union. That is what we are doing, with a lot of time and effort, with dozens of people continuously working on it. And yes, making progress, but also realising that this will be a very difficult agreement, because we have a lot of offensive interests in this agreement, on everything: on market taxes, on tariffs, on services, on public procurement, on investment, on regulations. But we have also defensives on almost everything, and you can imagine that this is not the most comfortable position when you are a negotiator. So these are difficult negotiations and we are working hard on it but please, as a lot of Members have been saying at the end of the intervention, judge on the result. Do not forecast a result that I do not have the faintest idea about myself, because we are in this process of negotiation. There has been a specific question and maybe I should say something about it, about national parliaments. Will the national parliaments have to pronounce on this? I think so, for the very simple reason that this will be a mixed agreement. If it comes about it will be a mixed agreement, and if it is a mixed agreement then national parliaments also have to pronounce. But we are not making those rules, read the Lisbon Treaty and you will see that for a pure trade agreement you only need the agreement, the ratification by the European Parliament. If it is mixed, it is also the national parliaments, and we comply with the rules that exist and that we respect. Yes, we will continue to make initiatives to get more transparency into the process. I can tell you that over the last months I have spoken, I do not know how many times exactly but certainly more than 100 times, about TTIP in all kinds of places that I had never been before. On ISDS, please give me a little bit of time to respond to about 50 interventions that have been made, because if not, they will say afterwards that I have not been transparent. We received 150 000 replies to our consultation on ISDS: 150 000, that is a lot. But tens of thousands of these replies are identical because it is obvious that there are people in Europe that are very good at working with all these tools and obviously they have found a way of entering a reply without getting into the system. Normally you have to get into the system and then you have to read 12 questions and you have to answer 12 questions and then you have to send your reply. A way has been found to circumvent this and give replies without getting into the system, with the result that tens of thousands of these replies are identical. So we will now analyse all this very scrupulously, qualitatively and quantitatively, and we will see what is in it. Once we have that we will make a report on it, and once that report is ready it will be at everybody’s disposal, yours first of all, and then we will discuss this with Member States in the Council of Ministers and with the European Parliament, and then the Commission – probably the next one – will make up its mind about what they will do with ISDS with the rest of the negotiation. That is the process that we will follow. It will take time. It will take a lot of time and I think some officials in the Commission can forget about their summer holidays. Let me just tackle one more issue that has been mentioned – it is very interesting for the climate in which all this is happening – and that is geographical indications (GIs). We get attacked because maybe GIs will not be protected, and this would be terrible. By the way, this European Commission has been doing more than anybody else to protect GIs. In all the agreements that we have been concluding – with Canada, with Singapore – there is now a full protection of GIs in the EPAs, so we have really fostered that idea. Whatever we get in this agreement with the United States on GIs, it will be more than we presently have. Do not start from the assumption that at present GIs are protected in the United States. What we will try to do is protect them in the United States and we will make sure that it happens, but presently this is not the case, so you should rather be in favour of TTIP if you are for the protection of GIs. Let me finish, Madam President, because I see that you are going to interrupt me very soon and I have a lot of understanding for that. Let us try to be a little bit more rational in this whole discussion. I have participated in the European elections not in an active way but in a passive way, and I am very happy to say that today, finally, I can also participate in an active election campaign meeting. But that is what a Parliament is for. What Parliament is also for is looking at the arguments, listening to the arguments and discussing on the basis of arguments, and then of course in all freedom, in full sovereignty, voting on what the Commission finally, sooner or later, will propose to you.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership is a rapprochement of two economic superpowers that can boost growth, development and employment on both sides of the Atlantic.No reasonable person can a priori be against negotiations and the potential they carry.What we must not allow ourselves is to sacrifice freedom of choice for the sake of a freer market and to give up the right to say NO to things we do not want.NO to GMOs, NO to meat treated with chlorine and hormones, NO to vegetables full of pesticides, NO to new ACTAs.We cannot expect the European Union to get everything it wants at the negotiating table.Nevertheless, European standards of consumer protection and food safety must be a line that must not be crossed, a conditio sine qua non.It is our obligation and responsibility to European consumers, producers and farmers.Yes to overseas trade, economic growth and employment, not under-the-table trade, uncontrolled imports and the deepening of the EU's democratic deficit.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: signed up.- The conclusion of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership will create the world's largest economic market, while benefiting the Union by creating a free trade area that stimulates growth, employment and removes excessive regulation and barriers to trade and investment.We must ensure that this political cooperation aimed at promoting the transatlantic free trade market will guarantee fair competition in trade between the two parties and ensure a high level of protection for European consumers.I believe that such an agreement must first and foremost ensure that EU social, health and environmental standards are respected, introduce synchronization and simplification of customs procedures and reduce bureaucratic costs.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. –  This agreement is not just any agreement and the stakes are high. The TTIP will establish the worldʼs largest free trade zone. But it is only up to us to use it as an opportunity to promote fair standards, growth and jobs on both sides of the Atlantic and to avoid a risky race to the bottom. The potential benefits of such an agreement are clear to all of us. But there will be sectors in the EU that lose out with output decreasing due to the competitive advantages of US industry. The TTIP addresses the existing limitations in bilateral trade between the EU and the US which are hindering its full potential. I agree that we should go ahead. But being in favour is not enough. We have to acknowledge the adjustment costs of such an agreement for certain segments of European industry and labour.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. - Free trade negotiations between the European Union and the United States are welcome. Such an agreement will boost the European economy, promoting exports, economic growth and employment, all of which are particularly important for countries that, being subject to austerity measures, such as Portugal, cannot incur economic stimuli that represent public expenditure additional. It is therefore essential to ensure that the benefits of this agreement fall on all individual Member States, and not just on the EU as a whole. Can the European Commission assure us that it will be able to reach a comprehensive agreement in this regard? On the other hand, it is from the elimination of tariff peaks and non-tariff barriers that the largest share of the economic benefits of this trade agreement is expected. The abolition of such barriers is essential, but must be taken with due care, avoiding at all costs a degradation of environmental and consumer protection standards in force in the European Union. I will end by asking the European Commission: How is this being defended in the context of the negotiations regarding, for example, the agri-food sector and American standards, which are less demanding in terms of the environment and animal feed?

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. - The implementation of the TTIP agreement will allow the establishment of the largest trade area in the world, which is undoubtedly a tempting argument for its adoption as soon as possible. At the same time, however, it should not be forgotten that the agreement will cover not only market access, but also provisions on investment protection, services, public procurement, NTBs and trade-related rules. The EU industry is also likely to benefit from the agreement - the estimated revenue for the EU is around 120 billion a year. For consumers, the contract means cheaper products, especially electronic equipment, which are still so eagerly imported from the USA. However, the opening of markets carries the risk of lowering EU standards in terms of consumer safety and employment conditions. TTIP is also often compared to ACTA, due to the high risk of insufficient protection of personal data for EU citizens. The mechanism known as "investor-state dispute settlement" (ISDS) raises the most doubts, i.e. a provision contained in international trade agreements, which gives the investor the right to initiate proceedings against the state in which he conducts business. Negotiations over the TTIP are not facilitated by the traces of the scandal over the US spy programs run by the NSA in the EU. In view of the above concerns, it is important to establish the conditions without which the contract will not be accepted (personal data protection, employee rights, transparency of the negotiation process).

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: in writing. - As the European Parliament, within our competences, we should strongly support the negotiation process for the conclusion of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership between the EU and the US and monitor its course on an ongoing basis to ensure tangible benefits for citizens. The lifting of barriers to trade and investment will undoubtedly translate into economic growth both in Europe and America. It will also have a positive effect on the global economy. The agreement should be structured in such a way that its provisions in the future contribute to the increase of jobs, improvement of investment conditions and reduction of administrative burdens. TTIP has the potential to bring many tangible benefits to ordinary citizens and European businesses: lowering prices for online purchases, easier access for SMEs to the US market, and increasing exports to the US. The agreement may also have a positive impact on the improvement of Europe's energy security - gas prices from the United States may decrease, and access to innovative energy technologies will also improve. In order for the agreement to bring all these benefits, it is necessary to properly take into account the differences between the EU and the US in terms of production costs, legislation, production processes and the economic and social situation. Undoubtedly, the EU and the US have a great chance to improve economic growth and the situation on the labor market. I hope we will use it properly.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing. - The expected gains from the transatlantic trade and investment partnership (TTIP) are significant: 119 billion euros per year compared to the European economy, i.e. 545 euros per European household, the internationalization of European companies on the American market ( especially SMEs), job creation in Europe and above all, greater normative influence by participating, with the United States, in the redefinition of global trade standards, thereby thwarting China. This last point is the central element which justifies support for TTIP. Instead of dogmatically opposing it, we need to take a constructive approach and get the United States to drop its technical standards preventing European companies from accessing their markets. Let us therefore continue to negotiate, without denying our right to regulate, our body of rules and our specificities, and put particular emphasis on the aeronautical, automotive and agrifood sectors (by protecting our indications of origin and our health and quality standards) , telecoms and e-commerce, or even access to public contracts for sub-federal entities. It is also fundamental to have an informed and peaceful public debate on the TTIP, denying the untruths and based on objective elements, in order to reassure the citizens.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – EU-US economic relations include enormous unused potential. Together they make up half of global GDP and 30 % of world trade (2012). The transatlantic economy is responsible for 15 million jobs and EUR 497 billion in trade flows. If the TTIP comes into force it will bring the EU overall annual GDP gains of 0.5 % extra (EUR 119 billion, EUR 545 per EU household). It is forecast that it would not only benefit directly the EU and US, but would also contribute EUR 100 billion to global GDP. It would boost the labour market on both sides of the ocean and create extra opportunities for small- and medium-sized enterprises. The main importance lies in the fact that the TTIP would not only boost economies but would provide significant new momentum for political relations. The EU and the USA are the backbones of international democracy and leading forces in a free and liberal global arena. Certain controversial issues like data protection need to be addressed in a responsible way. However, they should not be used as pretexts to slow down overall progress and turn attention away from the crucial economic and strategic benefits successful conclusion of the TTIP will provide.

name: Jan KELLER
text: in writing. - The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Agreement (TTIP) is fraught with uncertainty. We are assured that the effects of the agreement will be generally positive: it will increase the economic growth rate of both contractual partners, create a high number of new jobs. However, it is not clear why it is being discussed in a regime of such strict secrecy from citizens whose lives are said to be clearly improved. We are assured that the contract will not lead to a lowering of the current standards in the field of food quality and safety, staff status, environmental, etc. However, no one has given a guarantee that this will be the case until the in their functions. Virtually no one is responsible for any harmful effects of the contract. The agreement is intended to include an arbitration clause between large multinationals and states, without anyone explaining why the existing rule of law institutions available to all EU Member States are insufficient. The negotiators' relationship with critics of all these ambiguities is also strange. They tend to be accused of an irrational approach and considered too overwhelmed by emotions, all because they have chosen to exercise their civil right to information, which should be taken for granted in an open society. Unfortunately, the way in which the supposedly most important trade agreement in modern history is negotiated thus undermines the promises to reduce the democratic deficit of the European institutions.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: , in writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, the debate cannot be about whether business makes sense. Because there was trade, any company could grow. It was true hundreds of years ago, it is true today and it will be true in the future. When we fully implement the US-EU agreement, the added value for the European economy, according to the more optimistic scenario of the European Commission's estimates, will be EUR 120 billion a year, which means 0.5% of the European Union's GDP. For every household in Europe, this will bring in EUR 545 a year. This growth will be helped mainly by the removal of tariff and non-tariff barriers to goods and services. Even with the least favorable scenario in the EU, GDP will increase by more than € 68 billion a year and the United States by almost € 50 billion. This will bring together a total of 1.5 million new skilled jobs for the EU and the US. For European SMEs, this will bring new opportunities in trade and services and improve opportunities for new investment. Ladies and gentlemen, the Treaty of Lisbon has given the European Parliament the power to ratify such treaties. I believe that we will use this opportunity to send a positive signal to the national parliaments as well.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – At a time when many European economies face significant economic and social challenges and are still at the forefront of their recovery, I believe that it is vitally important to explore the potential of every opportunity that would stimulate growth, create jobs and could also help Europe in its long-term recovery from the economic crisis. I believe that this agreement, if negotiated properly, could be of great benefit to our economies and will open up new opportunities for European companies, especially small and medium-sized ones. Current impact assessments suggest that an ambitious and comprehensive trans-Atlantic trade and investment partnership could bring EUR 119 billion per year to the European economy and boost EU GDP by 0.5 %, which would translate into an extra EUR 545 a year for each a family of four in the EU. However, having said so, I would call on the Commission to be extra cautious and to ensure that European values are properly defended in the talks and in the final agreement. Such values include well-established precautionary principles with regard to consumer protection and consumer product safety, as well as safeguarding the EUʼs labour and environmental standards.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. Ongoing negotiations for the US - EU Transatlantic Trade and Investment Agreement (TTIP) are taking place amid intensifying EU intra-imperialist antagonisms with the other imperialist centers and within it. The bargains and controversies of bourgeois governments, both within the EU and with the US, aim to secure more benefits from each side for the monopolies they represent. What is certain is that the big losers from this agreement will be the people in both the EU Member States and the USA. The further opening of markets on both sides will intensify, in the name of competitiveness, the exploitation of the working class. Remaining labor rights are seen by monopolies as an obstacle to the profitable placement of their capital. The blow for the small craftsmen and the self-employed, for the poor and middle peasantry, will also be great. All living conditions of workers will deteriorate, increasing the risks to public health and the environment. It is in the interest of the working people in all the EU Member States and the US to intensify their common struggle against capitalist exploitation, against the common enemy: monopolies and their power.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The five rounds of negotiations so far have opened at least as many questions as they have answered. The reason for this, in addition to the inconsistency of the positions of the two sides, is the lack of available information on the content of the negotiation process. It is therefore not serious to accept or reject the agreement that is still being negotiated, even though we know very little about it. What is known is that with each new round it becomes clearer that the goal of concluding negotiations is less likely, all the more so as we in the EU are in the middle of the process of constituting a new mandate of institutions, and the US elections are approaching in the fall. I believe that European negotiators should not be burdened with deadlines. It is necessary to recognize and accept the opportunities that this agreement unquestionably provides, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises and European industry, but also to respond to potential dangers that are contrary to European values ​​and the interests of the citizens of the Union. At the same time, the precondition for the free trade of goods should certainly be the free movement of citizens on both sides of the Atlantic, which is not the case for the citizens of the 5 member states of the Union. Expected values ​​can only be achieved through quality agreements that will preserve European social and cultural values, environmental standards, geographical origin, the right to oppose genetically modified organisms, cloned and hormone-treated food and the protection of private data.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: written. - The free trade agreement between the EU and the US covers many complex areas. I am more than critical of the ISDS procedure. With the special right of action, large corporations are protected, but not obliged to! With the ISDS mechanism in the free trade agreements with developed constitutional states, a new arbitration procedure is being introduced that discriminates against domestic investors and grants multinational investors worth billions of dollars in special lawsuits, although the supposed justifications for this do not apply. We need to be clear about arbitration costs and compensation payments that directly affect European taxpayers. The population will also have to pay the intangible costs such as a restriction of the political room for maneuver and the loss of European and national sovereignty with future welfare losses. We as the European Parliament ultimately have the power to reject or approve the free trade agreement, and we social democrats will look at this very closely and work for a high level of protection for public services. High quality jobs are to be created and European consumers must benefit from the agreement. The currently applicable labor and social standards must in no way be undermined. We will take active action against social dumping by large corporations and campaign for binding compliance with the ILO conventions - it must be clearly stated that there must be sanctions in the event of violations of social and labor standards!

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: in writing. - A year has passed since the representatives of the EU and the US began negotiations on the conclusion of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). Currently, the enthusiasm for this agreement is much lower than it was a year ago. On both sides of the Atlantic, resistance from some social groups is growing. Growing resistance to TTIP in both Europe and the US is largely due to the disappointment of part of the population with the process of globalization, the benefits of which have been felt mainly by large corporations and both economies have experienced de-industrialization. In Europe, there are additional concerns about the differences in labor costs in favor of Americans using cheap labor from Latin America and more than twice cheaper energy in the USA. We also have serious concerns in the EU about upholding our world's highest standards of food production and animal welfare. We firmly say no to import of hormone-laden meat, chlorine-washed poultry or GM food invasions. In addition, in the area of ​​intellectual property rights, we advocate the maintenance of European geographical indications, which ensure that our producers' interests are protected. Undoubtedly, the trade and investment agreement is needed by both parties facing increasing economic pressure from new powers such as China, India and Brazil. The creation of a Transatlantic Free Trade Area could bring about a further expansion of trade and investment on both sides of the Atlantic.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - If the Commission remains deaf to the signals sent by the European Parliament and the citizens it represents, the only voice could be a rejection of the final text. The Belgian Socialists have from the start set a number of guidelines, namely: the transparency of negotiations; maintaining social, environmental and health standards; the exclusion of the mechanism which prevents a State from regulating under pain of being attacked by an investor in a private jurisdiction (ISDS); prior European regulation on data protection which must be respected by the agreement; the protection of public services and the exclusion from the agreement of sectors such as health or culture, etc. We don't want a new ACTA. The treaty must be drawn up with the general interest as an absolute priority and not that of a few multinationals. Today, even if the Commission says it is extending the guidelines, it does not provide sufficient guarantees to remove doubts. She therefore takes the risk of negotiating for nothing! We will be adamant about the limits we set over a year ago. It is out of the question to sell off the rights of European citizens.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements - Repeal of the maternity leave directive (2014/2715 (RSP))

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Council considers that the directive we are talking about, the 1992 directive on pregnant workers, is an integral part of the legislation on safety and health at work and we also believe that it is a very important directive which certainly needs updating in many respects. That is why the Council has made this one of its priorities since 2008, when the European Commission presented its proposal. The European Parliament, given the importance of this issue, has also done a very important job. The negotiations in the Council were an important negotiation, a negotiation that was also very difficult. It is very difficult because of the distance of positions within the Council and the considerable distance between the Council of Ministers and the European Parliament. What are the biggest points of difficulty? Differences in substance have emerged between the different national social systems in this area. Very significant differences in substance which reflect a considerable diversity between social systems at national level in the various Member States. Cost difficulties have arisen, difficulties which should not be underestimated in general terms but which should not be underestimated, especially in times of considerable pressure on public budgets. Finally, difficulties applied to subsidiarity have arisen because of the very different traditions and practices between the different Member States. With regard to differences in substance, I would like to cite, for example, the issue of the duration and timetable of the compulsory period of leave, on which there are strong differences and also strong differences of view between the various Member States in the Council. As far as costs are concerned, no agreement has certainly been possible and I think it is very difficult even in a possible subsequent negotiation on the European Parliament's request for a minimum of twenty weeks with regard to leave. This is a request on which there has been no advanced and in-depth discussion and certainly no agreement in the Council.  In terms of subsidiarity, Let me give other examples. Some Member States have raised the fact that some of the rules covered by the legislative proposal are already included in national legislation. I am thinking of free time for breastfeeding, special working arrangements for parents of disabled children or additional maternity leave in certain cases. The Council considered that the detailed provisions, including those implementing the minimum standards, were therefore a more a matter for the Member States. More generally, however, the Member States have reaffirmed their commitment to the safety and health of pregnant workers and those who have given birth or are breastfeeding, and there is strong recognition in the Council of the importance of reconciling work and private life. However, on the question of improving the current rules on the protection of pregnant workers and promoting a better work-life balance, we must find the appropriate instruments in the right policy area. It would be difficult for the Council to accept these proposals from the European Parliament in the context of health and safety legislation. However, this in no way restores the valuable contribution made by this Parliament to the debate on this issue. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the discussions that I have simply summarised in my speech have therefore revealed very concrete and substantial differences between the views in the Council and the position of the European Parliament at first reading, and it is in the light of these strong contrasts and major differences that the Commission has concluded that it must consider withdrawing its proposal. This is certainly a prerogative which the Treaties grant the Commission. The Commission certainly has the opportunity at all times to present and withdraw its legislative proposals. It is therefore institutional assessments which are the responsibility of the Commission and which only the Commission can make. These are assessments related to the proper functioning of legislative activity and the implementation of the Refit rules, which are also entrusted to the evaluation of the European Commission. And then there are assessments of political opportunity and of these, in particular, I would like to talk to you in the conclusion. We believe as the rotating Presidency that the issue of the protection of pregnant workers at European level is of the utmost importance and of the utmost importance in view of the wider social dimension that we must develop in the internal market and is also of the utmost importance as a subject of social rights. So as far as it concerns the presidency-in-office, we can try again, it is worth trying again, and we are also ready, if we start from a new political basis and start from a new beginning, to look again at the proposal in the Council and in Parliament. We are prepared to see if the conditions are in place, working with the new rapporteur, to restart, to try to prevent the proposal from reaching a dead track. It is clear that if we want to make progress and really want to reopen the issue, we need to make progress on both sides. Therefore, it is certainly necessary to see whether the political conditions are in place, starting with relations between Parliament and the Council, to restart legislative negotiations by listening to each other's reasons. The Presidency is prepared, if it is equally willing to make a fresh start on different political bases, to consider whether this debate can be reopened in the Council of Ministers, given the importance we attach to this dossier, but without concealing all the difficulties and obstacles that I have on time with examples given in my introduction.

name: Siim Kallas
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Madam President, the Commission is committed to helping EU citizens, men and women, to better combine work and family life. The fact that the maternity leave proposal has been identified in the REFIT communication of June 2014 as a candidate for withdrawal does not change that. Since 2008, when the proposal was presented, the Commission has sought its adoption. The Commission has acted as an honest broker between Parliament and the Council to find common ground. This has proven to be difficult. The Commission’s proposal on the Maternity Leave Directive has not been discussed for more than two and a half years despite numerous attempts by the Commission to reinvigorate negotiations between co-legislators. The proposal has been effectively blocked in the legislative process for too long, with no progress at all for almost three years. In spite of considerable efforts it has been impossible to break this stalemate and engage in any serious negotiations. As you know, one of the intentions of the REFIT exercise is to withdraw proposals where no negotiations have taken place for a significant period of time and which lack any prospects for adoption. It does not mean that the Commission does not believe anymore in its initial objectives. On the contrary it could allow for a fresh, new start on the subject to the greater benefit of EU citizens with a more modern text that would notably include in its scope paternity leave, as requested by Parliament. The Commission remains committed through its Europe 2020 Strategy to helping women to stay in the labour market rather than being excluded from it because they chose to have children. In this respect it issued country specific recommendations to several Member States to stress the importance of creating the conditions for reconciliation of private and professional life.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: for the PPE Group. - Madam President! Women and men should have the same right and opportunity to work. Having children should not be an obstacle for women in working life. Stronger protection must be given to working parents, but the solution going forward is not to legislate from Brussels. That is why I welcome the Commission's withdrawal of the Maternity Leave Directive. Family policy should be decided at national level. There are big differences in Europe and I understand the challenges in some countries, but we cannot have a solution that suits everyone in the EU. In Sweden, for example. we have come a long way. Of a total of 1.5 years per child, at least 2 months must be taken out by each parent, and the mother and father can receive a bonus if they share more equally. Therefore, the directive would be a real step backwards for the entire Nordic region. It is incomprehensible that the Swedish Social Democrats, who are EU skeptics, are now pushing to force Swedish women to stay at home - whatever they want. Implementing a work ban for women giving birth from Brussels is not the way forward for gender equality. Maternity leave, Madam President, should be parental leave. The proposal gives the wrong signal by only mentioning women as parents and thus solely responsible for the children. It is shared parental leave that is real equality. We will encourage both parents to take care of their children and spend time with them. It is a decision that must be made by the parents themselves and not top-down by politicians. Of course, women should not have to give up their career ambitions, and it is important that employers give women the opportunity to return to working life without discrimination. It's about changing attitudes and fighting stereotypes. I would like to end, Madam President, by saying that the PPE Group must continue to be committed to ensuring that women who have children are not discriminated against in working life. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question under Rule 162 (8)).

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Question "blue card".- I am sorry to disagree with my colleague Corazza Bildt on one point, but I would like to remind you that Europe has already had a long tradition of legislating on this matter.Suffice it to say that the current Parental Leave Directive has existed since 1992. The problem is to update it with respect to data that have been outdated.Suffice it to say that in the 1992 directive the period provided for as a minimum threshold - nothing is imposed - is 14 weeks.Do we still want to remain firm at this absolutely unacceptable and so low limit of protection?

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Answer to a “blue card” question.- Silvia the problem here is that we have completely different systems, completely different traditions.You know that I am Italian elected in Sweden, so I know the differences well.At the European level, it cannot be forced, because the mothers' directive says that for 15 days before giving birth and for 6 weeks after giving birth you are obliged not to work.In Sweden and in other Nordic countries there are many women who work before giving birth and even immediately after giving birth because maybe it's the fathers who take the situation in hand.So it's not fair to oblige and I'm talking about the word to oblige women.It is okay that we can add the minimum but not the obligation at European level, when we are finally talking about subsidiarity, to start doing better at European level.This is a good start from the Commission which is very welcome.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened attentively to the words of Undersecretary Sandro Gozi and, as rapporteur of this provision on maternity leave, I feel I can express convinced satisfaction following the clear commitment on the part of the Italian Presidency to carry out seriously discussing this fundamental provision. The legislature that has just started gives us a great chance, that of making these five years the years in which Europe gets back on its feet and once again becomes a beacon of civilization and growth. We have a great responsibility: to restore hope to European citizens, not by virtue of a Europe to be saved but of a new Europe to be built. To do this, however, to build a Europe of hope, capable of looking to the future with optimism, women must be given the opportunity to have a profound impact on our economies, without having to choose between having a job or having a child, between building present or imagine the future, and there must be a sign of great discontinuity with the past, that of having succeeded in having here in the Chamber a clear commitment on our part to the directive on maternity leave. After all, how could we explain, how would we explain to European citizens that after years of discussion, after six years of organizing workshops, seminars, conferences and debates on this directive, the best solution we had found was to postpone everything once again to date to be decided? We cannot wait any longer. Europe must also change direction in response times to social and economic emergencies, such as that of female employment and the gender pay gap, emergencies directly connected to the reconciliation of times between motherhood and work. The Europe that invests in women and their work is a Europe that grows economically. There is no change if in Europe women, for the same job, are still paid 25% less than men. But there will also be no developed Europe as long as the typical manager of a public or private company is a man of over fifty. A country where women undertake, invest and create wealth is a country destined to grow and renew itself continuously, because when women work it is the entire economy that smiles with them. I am a woman and like many women I care much more about concrete results than ideological foreclosures. I am happy that the new Commission President Juncker has explicitly declared his commitment to the Maternity Leave Directive and I am proud that this legislature has opened with the Presidency of the Council chaired by the Italian government, which has made gender balance the priority of its political and pedagogical action. So let's get around a table and get the discussion going as quickly as possible because it is the citizens of Europe who ask us. As rapporteur on this topic, together with the FEMM commission and together with all of you, I will do a careful work of listening and mediation because it is clear that in the European context the sensitivities, traditions and starting positions of the individual countries are very different, but I deeply believe that the time is ripe for a cultural revolution that will translate into points of GDP, all those that women will produce when they are no longer forced to choose between work and children. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Julie GIRLING
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, I welcome hearing that the honourable Member wants Europe to grow economically, but I would like to ask her exactly how she thinks the Maternity Leave Directive – and the extra burden of its cost to industry – is going to help that to happen.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: Answer to a “blue card” question.- Because I believe that investing in work and investing above all in services for women and families, invest in a time in which even today all the care, growth and assistance activities are loaded on the shoulders of women, who for themreasons undergo slowdowns and renunciations also from the point of view of work, professional and affirmation, and above all a cultural growth and dignity.Certainly, however, this will also make states grow from an economic point of view, because it is proven that when the gross domestic product of individual states is invested in female work ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! I very much welcome the fact that the EU Commission is withdrawing the Maternity Protection Directive. I would like to say three brief reasons for this. First: the less the EU regulates, the better, in principle. Let us not forget that every member state has a democratically elected parliament and a democratically legitimized government. Let them take care of it. The head of government of the EU, Jean-Claude Juncker, said here today in Parliament that the EU is not such a democracy. He explicitly said that he would not serve Parliament, and he said that Parliament has a right to ask questions - a right to ask questions! - and this right to ask questions will not be curtailed for now. We are of course very grateful to Mr Juncker for that, but that is not democratic in that sense. Second, maternity protection is not a competence of the European Union. The European Union claims responsibility for labor rights and labor market policy, the European Union is expressly not responsible for family policy. That is not even claimed by the EU. But let's look at the Maternity Protection Policy. The basic question arises: what is this directive about? Is a pregnant woman about the protection of an employee or an expectant mother? A pregnant woman must be protected - yes, of course. An expectant mother is the core of a new family. And that is why the protection of an expectant mother is the special protection of a family and thus family policy, for which the member states are responsible and not EU labor market policy. This brings me to my third point: Because the protection of mothers is so important, we should send a signal from this Parliament to the national parliaments: You, the national parliaments, protect mothers, raise your voice for it! With the mothers you protect the children, and with the children you protect the future!

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE group. – Madam President, as we start a new term with Parliament and the Commission we are faced with an impasse from the last Parliament and we have a responsibility to find a solution. We simply must find compromise with the Council and, equally, the Council must find compromise with Parliament otherwise we have a dysfunctional system. Furthermore just as we Members of the European Parliament nailed our colours to the mast when we voted either for or against this directive, I believe Member States who are part of the blocking minority need to explain to their citizens, both women and men, why they are blocking a Maternity Leave Directive that would help guarantee equality of treatment for mothers and babies across the EU. I totally oppose the withdrawal of this directive and I am pleased that the Council will work to ensure its adoption. Personally I support the proposal for 20 weeks’ paid leave. After all, that is the norm in this Parliament. Are we saying that other women deserve less? Indeed this directive will support many women who are lower paid and not in permanent and pensionable jobs. This directive also protects pregnant women against discrimination and helps to ensure the health and safety of mothers and newborns. It also makes a huge contribution to achieving a core principle of EU policy: that is the achievement of gender equality and the elimination of the gender pay gap. But as I said earlier, we need to find compromises. Perhaps there could be some flexibility in the 20-week period of leave, only in that there could be some interchange between maternity and paternity leave to cater for national preferences, and perhaps some flexibility as to the time taken before and after birth. Also, perhaps some lead time towards a 20-week fully paid maternity leave. But there should be no question that this directive would lower standards in Member States that already have higher standards.  It is crucial that we achieve compromises on these issues, otherwise it languishes in a sort of limbo and many pregnant women in the EU will not have the possibility of a reasonable time frame of paid maternity leave and strong protection in their jobs when pregnant or breastfeeding.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, it is curious that today, in a Portuguese newspaper, there was a news on the front page: more and more pregnant women or mothers who have recently arrived in the emergency room of hungry hospitals, including women who are workers and who live in poverty, although they have a job. And it is also curious that it is precisely now, at this time when women need it most, that the European Commission is in a hurry to make the possibility of guaranteeing the 20 weeks of maternity leave and 2 weeks of paternity paid in full disappear. It is significant that the European Council is always on the same page about cuts in wages and workers' rights - that is no longer a problem - but it cannot find a consensus to strengthen the rights of working families and mothers. If there was a real concern about the problems of demographic aging and the promotion of increased birth rates, if there was a real concern about discrimination in the workplace in relation to workers who are pregnant or who were mothers, then it would be very easy to decide. Here, the dominant political forces always speak of their social concerns. So now explain to us why the governments that make up the same political forces as the majority in this Parliament are unable to decide on raising women's rights.

name: Monika VANA
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! For us Greens, the maternity protection directive is of great importance for various reasons, on the one hand from a women's policy point of view, because it promotes the participation of women in the labor market, on the other hand, also from a socio-political point of view, because it sets important minimum social standards in the area of ​​health and safety at work, but also for reasons of gender equality. For example, I welcome the statements made by the Commission to include paternity leave in a new formulation of the directive, but I wonder why the Commission has not given any signals in this direction so far. But I now take that as a positive sign. But we also consider the directive to be important in terms of economic policy. I cannot at all share the arguments that are often used against the directive that the costs are too high. There is a study carried out by the Commission itself which states that a one percent increase in the labor force participation of women alone would have covered the costs of the directive for a long time. In other words, it would be extremely important to continue negotiations with the European Parliament on more health and safety at work.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: Madam President, today everyone knows that the countries of the European Union are experiencing a dramatic and suicidal rate of birth. This directive intended to increase maternity leave from fourteen to twenty weeks paid in full, could be a necessary but not sufficient means of solving the problem of demographic collapse and the aging of European populations. It is also an element of professional protection of women. It is an important right. Overwhelmed by austerity policies, the Member States under budgetary supervision to save the single currency no longer have the means to finance family policies which are subject to unacceptable restrictions. We must therefore try other means but not those which Brussels prefers: not massive immigration, not the great replacement of the peoples of Europe. This choice is a scandal. Civilization and the survival of our peoples will only be guaranteed if the rights of women are protected and if women themselves are supported in their best role, that of mother. Social matters must be at the heart of European action, Mr Juncker told us this morning. The abandonment of this directive in this context would be a very bad sign but also a proof that this speech is a lie.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: I was the shadow rapporteur for the proposal for an amendment to the directive on ensuring the safety and health of pregnant workers and workers who have given birth and are breastfeeding. The original wording of the 2008 text was limited to improving the working conditions of pregnant and breastfeeding women in paid work. But in this House, the text has begun to change in a substantial way. The requirement for gender mainstreaming put in place by the Commission has led to the extension of the scope of the directive to paternity leave, adopted children and other requirements. Finally, Parliament approved a position that went well beyond the original scope of the amendment, despite the fact that it was clear that Member States would never support such a text. For example, also because women's income during maternity leave is defined differently in each Member State and can come from different sources: the insurance company, the employer or directly from the state. The amount of this income also varies and it is basically impossible to find a working European compromise. The significant extension of this directive in the European Parliament has ultimately failed to raise the existing European standard for the protection of pregnant and breastfeeding women in the labor market. For this reason, I will support it if the Commission decides to withdraw the proposal and recast it. Let this be a lesson for us in the future that the documents we receive should remain true to their title. I am in favor of introducing a compulsory maternity leave of 6 weeks in the European Union, as recommended by the World Health Organization. During this period, the woman should receive full pay, and for a further 12 to 14 weeks, Member States should, as far as possible for their economies, financially secure all women who decide to continue caring for the child. The principle of subsidiarity should be strictly observed.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Madam President! The maternity protection directive has been blocked for four years now. This is a terrifying signal to all expectant mothers in Europe who are on the job market. I thank the Italian Presidency for reaching out to us. Because instead of giving security, we leave the mothers out in the rain for far too long, before and after the birth. That is why we are in favor of an agreement in the interests of the mothers and that everything is not put on the back burner. But what Parliament has reached agreement here in discussions and compromise negotiations must also form part of this basis for further agreement in the future. Because if all of this is simply brushed aside, then that is negligent, because we also lose credibility in Europe if we negotiate for a long time, negotiate and really no result can be achieved. For me and for us, maternity leave is an important building block of a social Europe. Even employed women want and must be able to have children. We must do everything we can to protect and support them. The International Labor Organization and the World Health Organization show us the necessary standards. This ensures the health of children and mothers in Europe. For example, children can be breastfed longer. In this way, many secondary diseases are avoided, and the risk of mothers developing secondary diseases is also reduced. If some people here and outside talk about costs: These are also costs that will no longer be incurred in the future if sickness periods are avoided, if health costs are avoided. The expansion of maternity leave in Europe is real social and health progress. We must not fall back into old role models, but we must think into the future and support women, families and also fathers.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: Madam President!The European Union, including Poland, is suffering from a serious demographic crisis.The fertility rate in Poland is one of the lowest in the world and amounts to 1.3, placing my country on 212 out of 224 places.For Law and Justice, the party I represent, pro-family policy is a fundamental pillar of social policy.We believe that family policy should be a common concern through funding from the European Social Fund, while actions to strengthen families, their sustainability and economic independence should be the responsibility of nation states.The directive on the minimum duration of maternity leave promotes many good practices.Efforts should be made to ensure that motherhood and fatherhood are effectively supported.It is time for Europe to tackle the demographic crisis - not by talking but by real action.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President, I want a European regulation of minimums for maternity and paternity leave, because it is fair.Maternity should not be a handicap for women's professional careers, and the regulation of leave favors equality, improves work-life balance and helps men to also enjoy their fatherhood.Furthermore, this regulation is necessary.The low birth rate affects Europe's competitiveness and, without these permits, we will continue to age, hopelessly, as a continent.We all know what that means.I therefore encourage Mr Renzi to turn his words into action at the last plenary session on the European social model.He has in this matter a challenge and an opportunity to change the opinion of the Council, which, once again, blocks the construction of a shared European social space.The excuse used this time - the application of the REFIT program - is an offense to all European women.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Madam President, we all know that, despite the fact that there is currently legislation that protects pregnant and working women, they are increasingly facing more discrimination in their work because they are pregnant or have given birth. That is why the protection of working women and the defense of their rights is urgent. The withdrawal of this Directive is going to affect thousands of working women and, furthermore, it is going to condition - and it must be said this way - the illusion of many young couples. What is being done today is also contradictory to the rhetoric of the European Union, which in theory defends the equality of men and women. Today we heard from Mr Juncker, and we also heard from him that the economy should be at the service of the people and not the other way around. And here this directive is being withdrawn in part because of its cost. In this context of crisis, moreover, women would once again find themselves unprotected in their right to reconcile their family life with their professional life. We all remember the cuts in public services, nurseries, schools, and so on. Just to finish, to say that no woman, regardless of her ideology, should allow our rights to be denied, whether for financial or other reasons. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Madam President, the European institutions cannot afford to take steps back in the fight for equality and citizens' rights. In this sense, the Directive on maternity leave is an essential instrument to guarantee legal and effective support from Europe to conciliation. We must strengthen European standards to legally defend maternity leave - also paternity leave - protecting wages and avoiding discrimination. In that sense, my group and many parliamentarians are alarmed by the possible withdrawal, announced by the Commission, of this directive. I want to appeal directly to the current Italian Presidency: it would not seem to me, frankly, the best way to start the Presidency with the withdrawal of a directive that responds to the fundamental rights of citizenship. That is why I would like to ask the Italian Presidency to work hard to move it forward. Parliament is ready and prepared to take this directive forward: please unblock it in Council and bring it to us for second reading.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Madam President, honorable Commissioner, honorable President-in-Office of the Council, dear colleagues! I think the European Commission has made a wise decision in proposing that the maternity protection directive should be withdrawn. I have also been here for many years and have accompanied the debates and discussions about the maternity protection directive since 2008/2009. You just have to take note - the President-in-Office of the Council described it in detail: There are different regulations on maternity protection in 28 Member States. That relates to the length of maternity leave, that relates to the financing systems, that relates to the various social partners that are involved in this maternity protection issue. In short, it just doesn't work to believe that one model can solve all problems. In my country, in Germany, we have a combination of maternity and parental leave models - wonderful, but that didn't work with the approach proposed by the Commission. I am happy that the Commission is now taking note of the facts: if there are no majorities in the European Council and together with Parliament, then one must also draw the conclusions and withdraw a directive that has been submitted. Each of us is for maternity protection, each of us is for maternity protection. In my country, I've done that for many years. But I think sticking to one dossier and clinging to the fact that the Member States and their regulations are forced into a corset that does not fit in 27 Member States is simply not possible. Therefore I am grateful for the withdrawal.

name: Olle LUDVIGSSON
text: Madam President!Unfortunately, the Commission has gone astray with regard to the Maternity Leave Directive.Withdrawing the proposal is the wrong way to go.The obvious thing must instead be to ensure that the process is conducted in port.Firstly, it should be entirely possible to reach a compromise between Parliament and the Council on how to improve the directive.If the Commission and the Presidency prioritize the issue, a solution should be within reach.Secondly, strengthening the regulatory framework is more important than ever.Increased gender equality is not only important in itself but also a key to accelerating growth and job creation in Europe.I therefore call on the Commission and the Presidency to resolutely pursue this important issue of gender equality.Do not throw in the towel!Show instead that you take gender equality seriously!

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Madam President! Let me be honest: I do not think this proposal is good enough. There are some things in particular that I do not like, such as the fact that you have to stay at home for six weeks. It is also a proposal that speaks unilaterally about the role of mothers. A policy in step with its time had talked about two mothers, two fathers, a mother and a father or why not several parents. But the fact that the Commission now wants to take back the whole proposal in one go, a proposal that does not ask for more than the minimum, can only be interpreted in one way: a slap in the face on women's rights and on gender equality. The fact that the Commission would come back with a better proposal is simply not credible in this situation. We have heard Juncker: not a word about gender equality, not a word. He has no ideas and he has no program. Inequalities are growing between women and men, and women's vulnerability in the labor market is increasing. To then also withdraw the Maternity Leave Directive is nothing more than an expression of the arrogance of patriarchy.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Madam President, I understood the withdrawal of this directive as the beginning of a new conversation and the basis for a new directive. So, I support the withdrawal of the directive because it obviously did not take effect after 5 years. 5 years was a sufficient period to reach a common solution. Since that did not happen, I think it is up to us to answer what subsidiarity is, and when you mention Mr Juncker, to answer you, he said that he would give as much power as possible to national parliaments and that he would deal with big projects. So we have to decide what we are going to decide here in the European Parliament and what we are going to decide at home in the national parliaments. Of course it would be nice to reach a compromise, a minimum of agreement, but our countries, our peoples, our stages of development are so different, our demographic picture of individual countries is different that it is really very difficult to reach a common solution that will satisfy us all. I will tell you the example of Croatia, where I come from. You have 6 months, meaning 24 weeks of mandatory paid leave and the next 24 weeks, or 6 months of half salary. It is almost impossible when we have to implement these structural reforms to stay on such a model, but of course we all stand for mothers, for the protection of mothers, women and, of course, the protection of workers.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: I understand that the 28 countries of the European Union are different: they have their own traditions, they have their own family support policies and systems, but we are also united by certain common values ​​and achievements. These are, first and foremost, the free movement of persons and the free movement of workers in a free single market. So in this case, completely regardless of where the mother gives birth, works, raises children: be it Italy, Sweden, Germany or my native Lithuania, but that mother and that father must have minimum social standards, minimum guarantees and for maternity leave. That is what we are trying to achieve with this directive. And that is why I strongly believe and look at the Italian Presidency that there is no need to give up, and it is a bad sign to start the new European Parliament from such a step - a step backwards - and to show its helplessness to both the Commission and the Council and distrust of the European Parliament. I’m sure we can find solutions by sitting at a common table. And I wish that.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Madam President! In October 2013, Commission President Barroso promised to only propose new laws if they make sense at European level. Not everything that can be done in the Member States should be solved on a European basis. Now REFIT is here, 53 legislative proposals have been withdrawn, including the unsuccessful revision of the maternity protection directive, which has been on hold since 2011. 13 member states have vetoed, for example Germany. We have regulations on maternity leave, the result of numerous compromises over many decades. It is not possible to extend maternity leave from 14 to 18 weeks with the stroke of a pen. I fought for the German combination model of maternity leave and parental leave and achieved a large majority for amendments. Due to our type of parental leave, fathers and mothers have a legal right to employers up to the age of three. This makes Germany the European baby protection champion, there is no need for regulation from Brussels. An excessive extension of maternity leave would have led to regression. There would have been an additional obstacle to recruiting young women into the job. By withdrawing the directive, the Commission is proving that it has learned from mistakes. I hope for more evidence of smarter and leaner EU legislation. The European election campaign has shown that this is exactly what our citizens care about.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: Madam President, it is absolutely disgraceful that there has been such a strong blocking minority in the Council on this vitally important Maternity Leave Directive. We all know that adequate maternity leave, and also reasonable leave for fathers, is crucial for women to work and for men and women to achieve a reasonable balance between work and family life. Over the past few weeks, we have heard a lot about gender equality and how Members of this Parliament and of the Commission and the Council are all in favour of gender equality. Well, the Council should now put its money where its mouth is and actually work hard to get this directive through. I do not believe that it has not been possible to agree a compromise. Other speakers have said that this is within our reach, and I believe it absolutely is. That is what we should be seeking to achieve now. It would be quite wrong to withdraw this directive now. The Council should go back and work harder and achieve this compromise, which I believe is within our grasp.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank Mr Gozi for his presentation and his realistic approach to how this situation is in the Council, but I wanted to explain one point to you. In 2010, in this Parliament, with very different positions, very conflicting between countries and between political groups, we were able to reach an agreement, to take a common position, because we understood that we were talking about the defense of health, of security working mothers and protection in the workplace. Here we have talked about the response of the public in these last European elections; And what European citizens have told us is that they do not understand how while in Europe we are being able to agree on economic policies, how much suffering they are generating, we are not able to agree on policies that speak of labor rights , of social protection, of equality between men and women. Therefore, I ask the Italian Presidency to make the effort that it has put forward in this plenary session to open the debate and to make it possible for there to be a movement in order to be able to negotiate a common position that, then, makes possible the debate with the European Parliament, because we are talking about policies that benefit the health of working women, but we are also talking about other important issues, such as labor rights. The European Parliament proposed in this Directive that it be prohibited to dismiss pregnant women or women who have given birth in the last six months, issues of labor rights that are necessary today more than ever, because we have gone back light years in what is the defense of workers' rights in the European Union. Therefore, we talk about labor rights, mothers' health, reconciliation between family and work life, and also the need to advance this paternity leave so that men can assume responsibility for the care of their children. children, in order to favor that conciliation. Much remains to be done: we cannot remain impassive. We cannot convey to European citizens that we are not capable of advancing in this social Europe of rights and citizens. Therefore, I ask the Council to assume the very important role that it has at the moment, to generate a debate within it because, from the European Parliament, we will be ready to debate on these issues, what is our responsibility and our obligation.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President!
