In his speech here in the plenary session of the European Parliament, Prime Minister Renzi said: "If the European Union took a selfie, we would see a very tired, strained face." I think that the Italian Council Presidency is now showing a lot of momentum, that this face does not look tired, but maybe young and happy and a contribution to equality policy and especially to revitalization, to revitalize the maternity protection directive can make a valuable contribution here. One thing is very clear: we have - Ms. Niebler mentioned it - different concepts for parental leave, different concepts for maternity protection in the European Union. But maternity protection - namely proper conditions for maternity protection, good minimum standards for maternity protection - these are really the absolute basics, the little multiplication tables that we have for the European welfare state. We should therefore continue this commitment now and not bury our heads in the sand. Crisis or not - it's about protecting women workers, who are of course particularly vulnerable. Pregnant women, as many have said before me, should be protected. The health of the child and mother should be respected. Not in spite of, but especially in the crisis, we need particularly high standards, because the pressure on the labor market is increasing and affects women particularly hard. I would like to refer to the REFIT communication, because here a particularly large number of areas that are important from the employee's point of view are called into question for cost reasons. And once again: we cannot always allow the protection of internal workers to be cost reasons that have the last word, but here it is important to send an absolute signal. In this respect, I am absolutely confident that the Italian Presidency of the Council, and we as the newly elected European Parliament, will tackle this issue with particular care over the next few months.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the need for a new directive is even more urgent than six years ago because there are too many inequalities in Europe between pregnant women, but also between newborns and working mothers, for health reasons. security, forms of conciliation, also due to the economic crisis. I would like to remind you that a directive serves precisely to define minimum standards that national legislations can certainly, as happens, integrate and improve, but also to ensure that situations that instead see women under a standard of dignity of their condition can be better protected in Europe. I think we know perfectly well that this type of approach, which sees the conciliation and support of maternity health and also the possibility of conceiving a right to paternity and maternity more serenely, is also an element of social growth and not only of person. I therefore believe that at this stage, with this crisis and within a new course that Europe must have, dear Commissioner, withdrawing this text has a double negative value and that it is a politically inappropriate gesture, as Mr Gozi rightly said, but also a gesture that seems to go in the opposite direction to the attempt to create a Europe that is more social and more attentive to the value of the person. I therefore ask the Italian Presidency to fully take the initiative that I seemed to grasp from his words because Parliament is willing to find a ground for mediation.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the Italian Presidency for wanting to debate this priority as regards the protection of women. Let us not forget that not moving forward on this directive is not a status quo, it is going back to a situation which dates back to 1992. What is there today, in terms of social protection? , laws, situations dating back to 1992 on which we cannot move forward? Being able to move forward on this directive is fundamental. Withdrawing this directive is damaging. This is damaging for the message that the Commission would give to these thousands of women who expect more protection, but above all, it is depriving itself of a tool which would allow the Commission to achieve its objective in terms of employment. Let us not forget the objective of an employment rate of 75% by 2020. Let us not forget also that today the pregnant woman or the young mother are both the most vulnerable workers and the crisis has not. only worsens the situation of these workers. We need measures that do not penalize mothers. We need measures that guarantee them the possibility of reconciling private and professional life. We need measures that allow them to live in dignity with a decent salary. We need measures that protect them when they return to work to guarantee their careers as well. We talk a lot about the glass ceiling. This ceiling is also due to the issue of maternity which, once again, is detrimental to the performance of a function for women. If Europe wants to regain the confidence of its fellow citizens, it must demonstrate its capacity to guarantee rights, equality and justice. This is what this directive is all about.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: Madam President, I just wanted to say that this directive is more than 20 years old, which means that it is obsolete and needs to be updated and harmonized for the sake of fairness and justice. The withdrawal of the directive on maternity leave by the Council and the Commission, blocked since 2010, shows disrespect for Parliament, and I recall that the Council has never commented on this matter. From this we could deduce that there was no interest in negotiating the proposal with this Parliament. In other words, the real intentions of the Council and the Commission in withdrawing this proposal are not understood. Do you have a new proposal? Is this proposal sufficiently ambitious? And if there is a new proposal, who was it negotiated with? Who serves? What does it consist of? How will it be carried out? Or will we keep an outdated directive that is more than two decades old? On the one hand, the European institutions are concerned with the aging of Europe and, when it is intended in practice to help the growth of birth rates and parents, what is done is to block proposals aimed at addressing the real concerns of European citizens.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Madam President, the Maternity Leave Directive was supposed to guarantee mothers in the European Union a minimum duration of maternity leave with adequate financial compensation, guided by good practices, which was not the case. Motherhood has different benefits in EU member states and can be said to be generally more flexible and dynamic, albeit with significantly shorter maternity leave than in Croatia. Unfortunately, in some countries maternity leave is so short that it does not allow mothers to be with the child at the stage when the child needs it most, and in some countries women return to work very soon after giving birth because otherwise they do not have their job or amounts fees are significantly lower than their salary so they cannot cover expenses. I am in favor of ensuring an adequate duration of maternity leave for women, of receiving full pay during maternity leave, of ensuring their return to their old job. But I want to point out that bad demographic trends in the European Union cannot be stopped and reversed in a positive direction with these measures alone. Thoughtful systematic long-term interventions are needed, from the local community to central state institutions. (The President cut off the floor to the speakers.)

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if the Commission wants to continue to degrade the image of the European institution, it will withdraw this draft directive. However, she will not. Why? Because today, after a few years of procrastination, the elements have come together for us to succeed. The Italian presidency is proactive on the subject. Parliament has just appointed a new rapporteur, in the person of Mrs Alessandra Moretti and with the shadow rapporteurs from all political groups, we can succeed; succeed where we have failed in the past because there have been two clear cut positions. One maybe too proactive with twenty weeks fully paid and the other, perhaps too timid with fourteen weeks. There is a way to find a middle way of compromise. This is the art that we must exercise today in Parliament in the interest of all European women, in any case, of a majority of them in order to advance their rights. And, as a man, I would also like to advocate for paternity leave which allows with maybe two weeks, as is the case in several countries, to ensure that the man is also a parent and that 'he can become aware of his role as a parent as soon as the child arrives in the family, from the start, at the level of motherhood.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Madam President, thanks to Siim Kallas, who acted many, many years ago as Prime Minister of Estonia, we have in our country quite a good maternity allowance system under which our young mothers and fathers get their average salary for one and a half years. I welcome the Commission’s decision, which respects the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. I firmly believe that every Member State can itself best decide which system is best to serve its needs. Member States face different demographic, economic and social conditions. Even if the EU’s actions could be justified in some aspects, the need to respect those differences remains. Our legislative action should focus on completing the digital single market and energy union.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: Madam President, demography and population growth have been one of the topics of great concern in the European Parliament, and I believe that one of the solutions we need to give to this issue is to reconcile work and family life.The European directive on pregnant workers allows for the extension of maternity leave to twenty weeks, with an allowance equivalent to the last salary or the guarantee of job retention, which are essential for gender equality, but also for the protection of women's rights.I believe that the withdrawal of this directive is not a solution based on existing realities at European level, even if the conditions differ from one Member State to another.I believe that the solution that European citizens are waiting for is to resume negotiations between the Council and the Commission on an improved directive.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: Madam President! For years, we have been participating in the European Union's struggle to ensure equal treatment of men and women with a number of right, but often forced solutions. However, we should realize that there is one biological dependency through which women should obtain greater legal protection - and that is motherhood. In light of the great demographic problems faced by many regions of Europe today, shouldn't we see motherhood as one of the social investments whose costs are spread over the whole of society, in the form of more nurseries, kindergartens or schools and activities for children supplemented with protection legal rights of women in matters of labor law? In the conclusions of the Council meeting of June this year on women and the economy, there are provisions on equality between women and men precisely in the light of the equal division of responsibility for children and domestic work with an emphasis on paternity leave and flexible childcare services. These are not topics that we can delay, especially in the face of the employment crisis among young people, including women, for whom the current situation translates into increasingly late motherhood, and sometimes complete abandonment. I hope that the declaration made by the Commissioner today to prepare new solutions will ensure their rationality and common sense.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: Madam President, I would like to ask how you arrived at five out of seven and how you chose the five, as I requested catch the eye before the beginning of this debate. Why have I been excluded? I understand there were seven so why have you excluded two when you have consistently let people overrun their speaking time and there would have been plenty of time for all of us to have been able to speak? Can you please confirm that we were allowed to speak only in the order in which we requested the time?

name: Corina CREȚU
text: I asked from the beginning of the debate that the speaking time be respected.It is up to the President to speak in the 'catch-the-eye' procedure.

name: Siim Kallas
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Madam President, we are not here to discuss the content of possible policies to support maternity leave. I can only say concerning the procedure and the whole process that blocked legislation does not help anybody. It creates wrong expectations: we have something in the air and in fact nothing happens. So withdrawal of the blocked legislation does not affect anybody.  In its REFIT communication in June, which was also greatly welcomed by the Members of the European Parliament and the wider public as well, the Commission stated that on the grounds of better law-making a proposal which is blocked for more than two and a half years should be withdrawn. The effective withdrawal decision would have to be taken in the context of adoption of the Commission work programme 2015. I would like to repeat that withdrawal does not mean that the Commission does not want to pursue the objectives of the proposal. Today the newly elected President will discuss with the new college how the policy objective behind the proposal could be taken up in a different form, taking account of societal developments since 2008 as well as the social and economic effects of any EU initiative in this field.

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened very carefully and I will spend a little more time in my reply than Vice-President Kallas, because the role of the rotating Presidency has been raised on several points, first and foremost on the subject of subsidiarity. Mrs Mann, Mrs Šuica, Mrs Ansip and Mrs Corazza Bildt raised the danger of working, if necessary, or reopening a debate, reopening work on one-size-scale solutions. Of course, no one wants one-size-size-will solutions and, in my speech, I raised one of the issues that was the subject of negotiations in the Council, which is the issue of subsidiarity. However, it is clear that we are based on a 1992 directive and it is therefore clear that the European Union has competence in this matter. It will be a question of seeing the degree of legislative intervention, but not of whether or not the European Union has competence in this area. Of course, this is a very important subject, on which there are very strong national sensitivities, and so it is certainly necessary to find, if work is reopened, a balance between the different traditions and we also need to reconcile social values, sometimes the different social values which, as has emerged in the debate in the Council but also today, are linked to the family. Mr Moretti gave a very interesting indication to the Presidency, because he has shown as a new rapporteur a clear commitment to moving the debate forward if we start – and I will cite it – from new political bases on which we need – I would add – a commitment that the rotating Presidency confirms, but which is also necessary on the part of the new European Parliament. I agree with Mrs Harkin on the need to find a compromise. As Vice-President Kallas said, a compromise is certainly much better than a blockade, because blocking legislation is of no use to anyone. However, a compromise requires flexibility, a magic word at this beginning of the parliamentary term, and we need flexibility. And flexibility and flexibility, when there are two authorities that have to decide, must be demonstrated by both sides. It must be shown that there is a commitment to see the possibilities on the part of the rotating Presidency, but it must also be demonstrated by the new European Parliament. I would therefore also like to reassure Mr Zuber that we would like to work towards a consensus on the substance, because we share social concerns on the substance. There is certainly a will on the substance, during the work of our Presidency and in any case as our position, to work also on possible minimum standards that are acceptable to all. We therefore also want to acknowledge the important work that this institution has done during the last parliamentary term and also the efforts that previous presidencies have made on this issue. However, it is clear that, given the different positions still far between our two institutions, the only possibility that we are prepared to make, on which we are prepared to work to make further progress, is that these positions on both sides, on both sides, evolve considerably in substance. Therefore, as I said in my introductory remarks, if there were a concrete political sign from both legislators of significant movements, the Italian Presidency would be more than happy to take the opportunity to see if further progress could be made. I would like to make this quite clear to Mr Steinruch, Mrs Vallina, Mr Urtasun, Mrs Ludvigsonn and Mrs Honeyball, who have referred differently to the fact that this directive has been blocked for four years. If they know and have followed four years of negotiations, they are also aware of the obstacles in these negotiations. There is not four years left by chance, there are four years left because there are very strong obstacles in the Council. So, without modification it is difficult to advance after four years of deadlock. I would like to thank Mr Costa, Mr Arena, Mr Regner, Mr García Pérez and Mrs Bilbao on their confidence in the Italian Presidency. I confirm our commitment to developing a social dimension and I confirm our commitment to them too, to starting well with cooperation between the two institutions in legislative matters, perhaps seeing if it is possible to open this dossier again. Serious work has been done by the European Parliament and has been done by the Council of Ministers. Despite the seriousness of the work done by the Council of Ministers and Parliament, the positions are a long way off. Mr Rodrigues, no disrespect to your institution but, as Mr Tarabella rightly pointed out, can we work on a median way of compromise? If there is the political will of the European Parliament and the Council to work on a median compromise route, the Presidency is at your side in working on this path. And this would, in my view, be the best way, in our view, to have that fresh new start, that new beginning which I was pleased to hear vice-president Kallas mention and which, as you know, is the motto of the Italian Presidency-in-Office of the Council of the European Union.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: The debate is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Corina CREȚU
text: signed up. - Mr President, in 2010, the European Parliament gave a very clear signal of the need for a European Directive on pregnant workers. Our position is an important step towards equality between women and men, social progress and economic sustainability. This directive is a tool to increase the birth rate, but especially to protect women during pregnancy and maternity, which are essential for achieving gender equality and protecting women's rights. Extending the duration of maternity leave to 20 weeks with an allowance equivalent to the last salary or guaranteeing the retention of employment are rights that every woman living in a European country should enjoy. I call on both the Commission and the Council to resume negotiations immediately so that, at the end of the Italian Presidency, we have an improved proposal for a directive.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - I find it very unfortunate that the EC is considering stopping the legislative process in the area of ​​introducing extended maternity leave, which it intends to abolish as part of the REFIT regulatory suitability and effectiveness program. This practice is regressive and threatens women's rights and gender equality. It is very sad that even in the 21st century, women are punished for childbirth by their employers, instead of creating the right conditions for them. I am clearly in favor of extending maternity leave from the current 14 weeks to 20, and I also think that employers should guarantee mothers a return to their previous job. I do not understand the EC procedure, because the vast majority of large multinationals are not opposed to this increase in maternity leave. I strongly reject the further disintegration of social rights as a result of the economic crisis, because, for example, only in Slovenia has the amount used by mothers to take parental leave have been reduced by 90% in recent years. I firmly believe that the European Commission will not succumb to the growing conservative, religious and far-right lobby and will seek to further reduce the gender gap and protect women's rights as it has committed itself to doing so. The fact that mothers cannot work full time during parental leave does not mean that they cannot benefit the employer.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing. - The debate on amending the directive on maternity leave has been going on for 6 years. This shows how different the positions of individual Member States and the European Parliament are in this matter. Despite this difficult process, I believe it would be a mistake to withdraw the draft directive. I understand the arguments of the Member States that have problems with accepting the proposed directive, but I know, based on the example of my country - Poland - that there are effective ways of reconciling social and economic issues when it comes to maternity leave. In Poland, we have been trying to extend the rights of working parents for several years, not only by extending maternity leaves, but also by introducing flexible forms of using them. I realize this is a budgetary effort, but I think that given today's demographic challenges, it should be treated as an investment. The abandonment of this type of action is, in my opinion, a short-sighted action, transferring today's savings onto the burden of our children's pension systems.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: written. - It is unfortunate that no agreement was reached on the maternity leave directive last season and that the Commission is withdrawing the directive. This was an important directive that would have improved the minimum duration and level of compensation for maternity leave in the EU. The directive would have been a minimum harmonization and would not have prevented Member States from providing for a better level of maternity leave. The directive would have been important for the internal market. It would have created a more level playing field for European business. A mere 1% increase in the female employment rate would have been enough to cover the costs of the directive. Higher birth rates improve economic growth in high-income countries. Birth rates are highest in countries where good family leave and childcare services offset the burden on children. The same countries have the highest female employment rates. The proposal for a directive required maternity leave to be regarded as a period of employment for the purposes of calculating pensions. The directive would have narrowed the income gap between women and men.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - Due to the economic crisis, the birth rate within the European Union has started to decline again, as has the level of female employment: data that were, unfortunately, already worrying even before this difficult moment. It is therefore imperative that the Commission and the Council reconsider the decision to apply REFIT to this draft directive. Now more than ever we need to strengthen rights relating not only to maternity but to parenthood in general, an innovation that this text brings with the introduction of two weeks of mandatory paternity leave. The European Union is much more than a series of economic agreements and must be founded on the protection and extension of fundamental rights and freedoms. This is an opportunity to give concrete application to these statements and demonstrate the seriousness of our intentions. We must find non-ideological but pragmatic solutions that allow us to take a step forward. All European citizens look at us and we cannot afford to disappoint them.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: written.- The Commission has decided to withdraw the proposal for a long-negotiated directive on contraception.The proposal, which had already been approved by Parliament, remained on the table when many Member States did not want to take the initiative forward for fear of cost.The Commission's decision is very unfortunate and, for its part, denies that women's rights are often seen as secondary.The directive would have created a minimum length and a better level of compensation for European maternity leave - a minimum of two weeks was also proposed for paternity leave.In many Member States, parental leave is still short and poorly compensated, which affects women's lower income levels and subsequent pension accumulation.The failure of the negotiations is also unfortunate in the sense that Parliament's proposal is in line with the WHO's recommendations on maternity leave.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - I support the swift negotiation of the matter, as it incorporates measures that fall within the principle of equal opportunities and treatment between men and women in matters of work and employment, a competence assigned to the European Parliament and the Council by Article 157 TFEU. More than determining the extension of maternity leave, this proposal incorporates issues of wage equity, prohibition of dismissal and protection in the overtime of pregnant or postpartum workers, the conditions of their return to work, the right to use the leave by special protection for disabled children, among others, which require immediate intervention. I advocate the establishment of minimum conditions with regard to parenting, which do not undermine or jeopardize other parental leave schemes in the Member States, and in respect for the couple's right of free choice, of the joint leave they wish to take.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - Commissioner, dear colleagues, I can only agree with you on the importance of facilitating the reconciliation between private and professional life, especially for pregnant women and young mothers. And allow me to add urgency. This is why the announcement of the withdrawal by the European Commission of the directive on the extension of maternity leave is regrettable. This protective measure received the consent of the European Parliament in 2010 and is now being undermined by the executive. This decision is nothing more or less a regression. We must quickly relaunch the discussion by giving new impetus to the interinstitutional dialogue, in line with recent statements by the new President of the Commission, Mr Jean-Claude Juncker, and the Italian Presidency of the Council. It is this renewal of the dialogue that I hope for. It is necessary to update positions and bring them together so that they best respond to the realities of the various Member States. In terms of social protection, of which maternity leave is certainly part, progress is necessary and standstill is no longer allowed! I will pay particular attention to the evolution of this file.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: in writing. - The debate that has opened at EU level on the so-called maternity leave and closes with the withdrawal of the proposal for a directive by the European Commission reveals that motherhood in the EU and in the capitalist path of development is not only unprotected but persecuted. Even what was proposed in the plan in the name of formal maternity protection was rejected by EU staff and bourgeois governments. They cynically declared that the protection of motherhood entails costs for the capitalists. The crocodile tears of the political representatives of the monopolies in the European Parliament throughout the debate do not convince anyone. After all, the reality of savage exploitation in the workplace, employer terrorism that is opposed and the thought of only working children, let alone protect motherhood, is harsh. The KKE fights for the explicit prohibition of dismissal of women during pregnancy and after that by employers, the introduction of full-time maternity and paternity leave, for all the time that is scientifically necessary for the needs of its mental health mother and child, proper upbringing and development during the first months of life. Claim full and free medical coverage, with free all examinations before and after childbirth.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the destruction of Syria's chemical weapons in the Mediterranean area, between Greece and Italy.[2014/2752 (RSP)]

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as you said, The High Representative and Vice-President Ashton are committed to negotiations on Iran in Vienna, so I am pleased to speak on behalf of the Council on this issue. The operation to destroy chemical weapons in the Syrian arsenal has already produced results. Results that resulted in the removal of chemical weapons components from Syria. We as the Rotating Presidency of the European Union are speaking for information purposes, because the Union has contributed to the budget, but it is an operation that has been carried out by 28 European States, which are also members of the European Union, and not, as far as most of the decisions on operations are concerned, by the European Union as such. However, it is certainly very important to discuss and inform you this evening of this issue. It is certainly also important because it is a fundamental objective to ensure security in our neighbourhood as the European Union. The plan for the destruction of Syrian chemical weapons that we are talking about has been drawn up, wanted, outlined under the control of the Oganisation for the prohibition of chemical weapons and the United Nations, and the World Health Organisation and the United Nations Environment Programme have also contributed to the operation. Of course, the 28 Member States of the European Union have been actively involved in the decisions of the operations. Joint planning by the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons and the United Nations concluded that hydrolysis of chemical weapons on board the American ship Cape Ray was the best solution under the circumstances. The American ship is simply used as a platform, where hydrolysis operations must take place. It's a process that basically consists of dissolving chemical components through various salts, and it's a method that has been used by the United States for many years to destroy its chemical weapons stockpile. The planning was made public, as were the decisions of the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons through the Executive Committee. A mission between the Organisation and the United Nations has also organised two major information events, including on board the ship Cape Ray, to explain to major environmental non-governmental organisations and international media how operations to remove Syrian chemical weapons first from Syria and then destroy Syrian chemical weapons were carried out in full compliance with national laws and international regulations. It is a process that has also been successfully used previously in the case of Libya. All the measures taken by the two organisations to ensure the safety of operations and to ensure environmental safety have also been indicated. The European Union, for its part, is aware of the international importance of this effort. It was at the forefront of this operation from the outset, however much it could contribute, and it did so in the initial stages through a contribution of EUR 5 million to start the activities of the joint mission and subsequently also contributed to the Special Trust Fund of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons with a further EUR 12 million, precisely intended to finance the destruction of weapons. These are the only legal contributions made by the European Union as such. Of course, many other Member States of the European Union have also made important financial contributions and also important contributions in kind, which I would like to mention. A particular appreciation of the Presidency of the Council goes to Denmark, which, together with Norway, has contributed commercial vessels to the operations and also to Denmark and the United Kingdom for having also given the military supplies necessary for arms removal operations.  Italy, for its part, has made available the port of Gioia Tauro to carry a part, the most important and most important part of these chemicals, the so-called "priority 1", on board the American ship Cape Ray. This has been an essential part of the process of destruction. Three other Member States – Finland, Germany and the United Kingdom – have also confirmed that they are willing to contribute and can contribute to the destruction of further chemical weapons by making their civilian facilities available. We would also like to express our thanks and appreciation to the Director-General of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons and to the United Nations Special Coordinator and their teams for the truly outstanding work and commitment they have shown throughout this operation.  We think it was only natural that the Organization for the Prohibition of Arms In 2013, he received the Nobel Peace Prize for his contribution to world security and peace. The operations will soon be completed and so the Member States of the Union and also, at least in part, the Union itself will have made an important and practical contribution to reducing some of the suffering in Syria and to contributing to a potential peace on which we certainly still have a great deal to do in the days and weeks ahead.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I support Undersecretary Gozi's request that he goes in the direction of obtaining that clarification, that transparency to which the communities of the member countries are entitled in terms of information. In addition to the useful words of clarification that have just been provided by Undersecretary Gozi, I personally had the opportunity to have further technical clarifications from Minister Galletti, who personally followed many of these operations, especially in relation to the technical-scientific methods with which the hydrolysis mentioned on board the American ship is carried out. However, there is strong concern, especially on the part of the Italian and Greek populations. I am thinking, as regards my country, Italy, of the populations of Calabria and Sicily, with regard to the guarantee of that right that the international system guarantees to the populations involved in disarmament and operations such as this, with regard to information and transparency. Some news, some comments, have not escaped, which have, perhaps in a provocative way, questioned the actual pacifying nature of the operation in progress and we wondered if it was not a question of a position in the field of Atlantic alliance between the United States and the Russian Federation. The question therefore concerns what was the effective political role of the government in this operation and my willingness to join, together with my country, the concerns of the communities involved and therefore the need for the Member States to be guaranteed the entire right to information. , to the safety and transparency that the legal system recognizes them.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, first of all we would like to welcome this House's decision to discuss this issue. You are well aware that last Wednesday we submitted a written question on the subject and we now believe that the important political initiative we took first of all justifies the struggle of the Cretan people, the struggle of the Mediterranean peoples, so that there is information on this issue. We clarify that this issue has been raised in Greece for a very long time. In January 2014 I submitted it to the Greek Parliament and later to the Council of Europe. You did not give us any answers, Mr Gozi. Probably more concerns with what you said. Let's look at things from the beginning. What is the security that exists for the project? Question one: why should Syria's chemicals be destroyed by the method of hydrolysis at sea? This is a method that is applied for the first time in this case, and this activity is evolving. Secondly, why not wreak havoc outside the closed Mediterranean basin, in a remote, remote and uninhabited area? Thirdly, the project is being carried out, as you say and you know - and the European Union is involved and you have a huge responsibility in this matter - on the Cape Ray, which has proven to be unsuitable for these procedures. This process cannot be done. It is dangerous. So you have all this data in front of you and you did not give us a specific answer. First of all, it is not an international venture. Neither China nor Russia is participating anymore, and a German frigate has left. It's a United States project. How do you know it is outside the closed basin and is in international waters? Tell us what the stigma is. Obviously the hydrolysis is happening right now and we want you to tell us where. What are the measures that exist for the security of the citizens themselves? There is enormous concern on this issue. You did not give us answers about what will happen if there is an accident - unattainable! What will be the alternative plan? So no answer to this question.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, today we are discussing - not because we chose it, but as a matter of urgency - the destruction of Syria's chemicals. And it makes sense, at the same time, when we allow certain people to make a fortune at the expense of the peoples from the manufacture and trade of such weapons; , Iraq, Syria and today Palestine; when we now tolerate the use of chemical weapons by the Ukrainian government; when we even tolerate the cost of destroying them economically, socially and environmentally, not by manufacturers, operators and traffickers, but only the peoples. It is therefore hypocritical to claim that we are defending world peace and security by destroying Syria's chemical weapons when we do not intervene in advance and resolutely to neutralize and destroy them in countries known to possess such weapons and when we do not blame total responsibilities for the consequences of their use on their manufacturers and distributors. And the culmination of the hypocrisy is that in the case we are discussing, the European Union does not want and can not take any guarantees from the US that they are responsible for the imminent threat of damage, since they are not bound by the law of the sea that they have not signed.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! The world does not agree much on the situation in Syria, but the destruction of chemical weapons is an exception. These weapons have been used in densely populated areas and there are no guarantees that they will not happen again - at the initiative of various parties to the conflict. We Greens fully support both the production and destruction of all chemical weapons in the area - on the road to a Middle East completely free of chemical weapons. That in itself is a goal that all states in the Non-Proliferation Treaty are behind. But destroying them is not easy and it is not risk-free and it must be done under the greatest possible safety. Transporting weapons long distances by air is not an option. Since no country in the immediate area has offered to deal with the destruction within its territory, the least bad model has been chosen. This means that they are first destroyed on board the Cape Ray on the high seas and then transported to a number of countries with special capacity to incinerate the toxic waste. For maximum safety, the boat should be in a place where it is protected from severe weather and wind conditions, but no state has agreed to that. As Green, both I and my colleagues fully understand both the fear and the protests in Greece and we believe that it is of the utmost importance that the handling of weapons takes place with full transparency both in terms of information to authorities and to citizens of the countries concerned. Weapons must be destroyed, as must waste, without destroying the Mediterranean.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to point out to everyone that the disposal of chemical weapons with the process of hydrolysis at sea, not on land, is a completely innovative practice, which does not present any previous experience as a reference. Scientific experience, but also every common experience of lived life, teaches us that at the beginning of every practice there is the greatest risk of failure. So where are the procedures in case of an accident? What are the evacuation plans in the event of an environmental emergency? Why hasn't the population been made aware of all this? I say this because, in this case, the Greek people and the people of Southern Italy are running the above risks - as usual - with particular reference to Calabria, Puglia and Sicily. All these peoples are already united by a common state of extreme poverty. All these people are also united by exposure to a myriad of other risk factors deriving from the legal and illegal disposal of toxic waste, from the dissemination of landfills of various types on the territory, from all forms of licit and illicit incineration, from extraction practices of oil and methane gas both offshore and on land. So we would never want a model to emerge in which the poorest regions of this Europe are therefore destined to act as guinea pigs, running the greatest risks for their own health and for the health of their children. In conclusion, I say that these people are watching you. These people learn more and more and become more and more aware of what is happening around them. So don't be surprised if this model of Europe begins to falter. These people sooner or later will ask you for the account of all this and will do it in front of history.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the destruction of Syrian chemicals in the Mediterranean, off Crete, is a dangerous act with incalculable consequences for the people and the environment of the region. The United States and the European Union, after the bloodshed in Syria to serve the interests of the monopolies, endanger the very health and lives of the peoples throughout the Mediterranean. Both the European Union and the Greek Government and the other governments of the European Union are provocatively ignoring the protests and the resolutions and the complaints of the people. They hide the truth. The KKE with its initiatives and questions in the Greek Parliament, in the European Parliament, in the High Representative Catherine Ashton has expressed its categorical opposition. Also, at the initiative of the Communist Party, ten communist and workers' parties in the Mediterranean denounce this operation. The KKE will continue its efforts to strengthen the anti-monopoly anti-capitalist popular struggle to prevent the environmental catastrophe of the region of Crete and the Mediterranean in general, in order to defend the life and rights of the people.

name: Giorgos GRAMMATIKAKIS
text: Madam President, I come from Crete and I am a professor of Physics at the University there. I am therefore in a position to appreciate more the dangers of chemical hydrolysis that has been chosen as the method of destroying Syria 's chemical weapons. In a closed sea such as the Mediterranean may lead to irreversible environmental and social disaster. I therefore feel obliged to protest strongly against this development and I was not relieved by the assurances of the honorable Mr Gozi. Hydrolysis processes that have already begun take place in an obscure part of the sea near Crete or Libya in the absence of official information or monitoring by reputable scientists. Thus, the questions that arise about the safety of the method and the choice of the Mediterranean have led the people of Greece to anxiety and anger but also to large rallies, especially in Crete. The Mediterranean is a sea of ​​crossroads of cultures, but it has suffered a great deal of environmental burden from a variety of sources. It is a request of the coastal peoples and a request must be made from all of Europe for this historic sea to return slowly but steadily to its original destination. So it would be tragic if he now came to the opposite conclusion. Thus, even at this last moment, a change of course is required.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! The destruction of chemical weapons is serious business. And because it is serious business, I believe that it can only be done under the strictest security precautions. It would be interesting to know which security precautions have been taken so far and which will be taken in the future. Because it is undisputed that both the environment and the citizens of the islands there must be protected. I also think that it is important and part of the acceptance that the public is involved, that the public is aware of what is ultimately going on off the coasts of the European Union. Ultimately, full transparency is also part of it. It is of great importance for the regions where tourism is an important, if not the largest, main economic source of income. That is why it is important and imperative that the way in which chemical weapons are destroyed must be presented transparently. You have to explain to the citizens how many chemical weapons are destroyed, when and where. I believe that it is right that we support the destruction of chemical weapons, and that is the path we should take, but in this case as described. One must not forget that support for a democratic, peaceful Syria must also be guaranteed at the same time. I ask the Council and the Commission to heed that too.

name: Sandro GOZI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Madam President, honorable Members, I thank all the Members who have spoken. Certainly the debate was an important and welcome debate because there is a need to inform. There is a need to inform the honorable parliamentarians, there is a need to inform, through this debate and the action that individual governments must also take, the communities involved and also explain all the important security measures that have been taken and inform also of operations during the whole duration of the dismantling process. So, from this point of view, it is certainly good that there is this debate, it is good that there is this dialogue between the current Presidency, representing the High Representative, and Parliament. There were some specific points that deserve a more specific answer. First of all, I confirm that this is an operation that operates within the framework of a UN resolution and also under the supervision of the UN. Secondly, why couldn't these operations be carried out in Syria? Because due to the conflict, due to the situation of insecurity, it was absolutely impossible to undertake such an important initiative in the midst of the Syrian conflict. Because hydrolysis in the sea was asking, it seems to me, Mr Pedicini, also invoking history - I would not invoke recent history, because it could lead to results different from those you were referring to. Because there was no possibility of doing it on earth. There was no possibility of doing it on land because no country in the region agreed to land its operation due to the negative reactions of public opinion. It is about Syrian chemical weapons. In the first phase of the Syrian conflict, the whole world was asking to intervene to stop the use of chemical weapons and to work for an action to destroy chemical weapons. I believe that the fact that this operation is now underway should be widely appreciated, because at the time international, European and Italian public opinion asked all governments to intervene precisely to prevent the terrible suffering of the Syrian people from being added to the inadmissible and hateful use of chemical weapons. And this is the operation that is responding to that request of citizens, to that request of public opinion. It has been said that hydrolysis is experimental. It has been in use, according to the information I have been given, in the United States for many years for the destruction of their chemical weapons stocks. As regards the questions of material related to chemical weapons, the object of these operations will be stowed in the Cape Ray ship and will be transferred, as was also mentioned by one of the honorable Members, to Germany and Finland to burn it. Therefore, during this operation, they will not be missions either at sea or in the air. Again in reply to Mr Grammatikakis and Mr Pedicini, I inform that all measures have been taken by the staff of the Cape Ray vessel who have been trained to respond to any problems that may arise during this process. Lastly, there was talk of hypocrisy with regard to what I said about the European Union. But this is not hypocrisy - Mr Sakorafa is no longer there but I will answer you anyway. The European Union is simply not a party to the Chemical Weapons Convention, it is not a member of it, it is not even an observer member, and therefore the European Union as such does not participate in the executive council that takes the decisions of this organization. As I said, 28 European states participate, which are also European Union member states. In conclusion, Madam President, we are convinced that the Syrian chemical weapons destruction program has been a success and must continue because it is a very important commitment that the international community has made and that must continue and it is essential to also prevent the reuse of these illegal weapons. against the Syrian people to whom we must not add further suffering to what it is already suffering. We have received, as I said, specific information, which I have shared with you in this debate, regarding the reasons why this operation takes place on the American ship and also the modalities. In conclusion, I can confirm the pacifying nature of this operation to Mr Salini. I have no doubt that this operation is a contribution to peace, which has been preceded and which will have to be followed by many other contributions, because we are talking about a situation in which a real humanitarian tragedy is taking place. Madam President, once again I thank all the parliamentarians for the contribution they have made to this debate.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: The debate is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: signed up. - In the previous legislature, our Parliament closely followed the issue of the use of chemical weapons by Bashar Al-Assad's regime against its own citizens. Also in the previous term, I supported the transfer and then the destruction of the Syrian chemical arsenal under the auspices of the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, by virtue of United Nations Security Council Resolution 2118 (2013). I think we must continue to support the process of destroying Syrian chemical weapons. It is run by an international organization whose efforts to control chemical weapons were rewarded in 2013 with the Nobel Peace Prize. I would also like to welcome the involvement of the United States, Great Britain and Germany in this process, which have taken on the main responsibility. I am convinced that all necessary precautions will be taken to avoid negative consequences for the environment, as well as for local communities in the Mediterranean.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: The next item is the report by Mr Werner Langen on the proposal for a Council decision on the adoption by Lithuania of the euro on 1 January 2015 (COM (2014) 0324 - 2014/0170 (NLE)) (A8-0001 / 2014).

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! Lithuania becomes 19th member of the euro zone. This is good news for Lithuania, for the Baltic States, for the stability of the euro, for Europe as a whole and for financial markets around the world. Parliament gives the green light for this accession: yesterday in the ECON committee with a large majority, tomorrow in plenary and on 23 July in the Council. Welcome, Lithuania, to the euro zone! The government and parliament in Lithuania have worked hard since 2006 and met all the criteria: a stable exchange rate, low inflation despite increased energy dependency due to the shutdown of two nuclear power plants in Ignalina in 2006 and 2009, low interest rates on national debt, low national debt, a limited deficit. All of this has been achieved in spite of the huge financial market crisis, the economic downturn and a tendency among young people to move outside, even a wave of emigration, if you will. The signs now point to economic recovery, solid finances and a reliable political framework. We welcome Lithuania as the nineteenth member of the euro area, and I hope others will follow - perhaps sooner than expected when I think of the discussion in Poland. The euro itself is stable internally and externally with low inflation rates, a high exchange rate against the dollar - the world's most important currency - and has established itself as the second world reserve currency. But to those who see the euro only as an economic project, as a unit of account, one has to say: the euro is a political project. That is why judgments that overlook the political dimension and blame only econometric models for the success or failure of the euro are wrong and short-sighted. Despite many attacks, the euro has held its own against speculators and financial market turbulence, especially against individual members. I am thinking of those who have been in trouble and in some cases still are, such as Greece, Portugal, Ireland or Cyprus. The Stability and Growth Pact is of course correct, but it was violated ten years ago by the two largest Member States, Germany and France. In the meantime we have made the regulations more flexible, strengthened them, and given the pact new teeth. The Commission and the Member States are called upon to keep their promises that we made in the two-pack, six-pack and the budget semester. Politicians have struck the right balance between reforms and solidarity, with guarantees and without major demands on taxpayers for the stabilization of the euro zone. That is the truth, ladies and gentlemen, and it is the responsibility of the European Central Bank, which has made full use of its monetary policy space within the framework of its mandate. Welcome Lithuania! The euro is our common success story, as is the internal market, peacekeeping, our prosperity and our social system, European unification in peace and freedom. I ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to vote in favor of the report tomorrow and to vote for Lithuania to join on January 1, 2015.

name: Siim Kallas
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Madam President, I am very pleased to be here today to discuss the euro adoption prospects for Lithuania. I am sure that Parliament can play its full part in the euro area enlargement procedure. On 4 June the Commission concluded in its convergence report that Lithuania has achieved a high degree of sustainable economic convergence and is ready to adopt the euro on 1 January 2015. The Commission has therefore made a proposal to the Council to this effect. We have examined Lithuania thoroughly but fairly and fully respecting the principle of equal treatment. The sustainability of convergence has been an integral part of the assessment. Regarding the procedural steps so far: following the Commission proposal, euro area Member States in the Council adopted a recommendation on adoption of the euro by Lithuania and the European Council congratulated Lithuania on fulfilling the convergence criteria in the Treaty. I now invite Parliament to signal its political support for adoption of the euro by Lithuania on 1 January 2015. After the vote in this Parliament, it is envisaged that the Council will adopt final legislative proposals on adoption of the euro in Lithuania on 23 July to give Lithuania sufficient time to prepare for the 1 January 2015 changeover.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! First of all, I would like to thank our rapporteur Werner Langen and his shadow rapporteurs very warmly for their work. Under enormous time pressure, also due to the start of the new legislative period, you submitted a very good, balanced report. This leaves no doubt that Lithuania is ready to adopt the euro. Lithuania, like its Baltic neighbors Estonia and Latvia, has made remarkable economic progress. I was personally impressed that the Lithuanian government, despite a failed attempt in 2006, did not allow itself to be dissuaded from its path. Comprehensive reforms and austerity measures have paid off. The numbers speak for themselves. Both the Commission recommendation and the ECB recommendation and the ECON report make it clear that the Maastricht criteria are clearly met. It is now important to maintain the efforts made so far in order to guarantee a sustainable positive development of the economy, also with regard to the convergence criteria. The committee voted clearly yesterday: 46 to 8 with one abstention. The positive result of the vote of the ECON members of the seventh legislative period on April 7, 2014 was thus impressively confirmed. I would therefore like to take the opportunity to speak out very clearly in favor of Lithuania joining the euro. Like Latvia's accession this year, it is another strong signal for the euro zone. The euro remains attractive as a currency. I am convinced that in Lithuania we will have another important and even reliable partner in the euro zone. Finally, I should like to say that, as rapporteur for Latvia’s introduction of the euro, I was very annoyed that we were not allowed to have a debate here. I am therefore all the more pleased that we can now hold this debate here in Parliament on such an important issue as Lithuania's accession to the euro.

name: Paul TANG
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to warmly congratulate the Lithuanian Government for the commitment it has shown to integrating into the eurozone, and its government for fulfilling all the criteria for entering into the eurozone. The entry of Lithuania is yet another historic landmark, since the three Baltic countries will now become fully integrated into the European structures, and the S&D Group fully supports that. While Lithuania fulfils the criteria for entering the eurozone without any problems, there is one problem I would like to draw attention to and that is its high unemployment. I would like to call on the Lithuanian Government to take every possible step towards lowering this unemployment rate and raising employment. In summary, the S&D Group looks forward to welcoming Lithuania into the eurozone, hopefully by January 2015, and I hope that we can agree by a large majority on this position in this Parliament.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. - I would like to start by congratulating Mr Langen, the rapporteur, and also all those involved here as shadow rapporteurs, as well as my Lithuanian colleagues here in the European Parliament. The European Conservatives and Reformists Group, of course, have very different views on membership of the euro: there are representatives of the Member States who do not even consider membership of the euro, there are countries that have joined the eurozone even during the crisis. And I want to say that the ECR always respects the choice of the Member States, because it consists of so many aspects of why one country or another joined or did not join the eurozone. I myself am pleased that the three Baltic States are the only countries to have joined the eurozone during the crisis. And this, in my opinion, is an extremely important step with Lithuania's membership in the eurozone from the beginning of next year. Moreover, this year, it seems to me that the eurozone also includes a geopolitical aspect, at least in countries such as the Baltic States, because the national currency in a small country with an aggressive initiator is a certain threat. So I congratulate my Lithuanian colleagues and I would like to say that all the criteria of the convergence report are met, but I would like to say in two words about the gods aspects, which are also mentioned in the rapporteur's explanations. Firstly, on the financial sector. I am pleased that the Lithuanian financial sector is still less dependent on the cash flows of non-residents from third countries, as is unfortunately the case in some other countries, such as my own, Latvia. And the second position is on the energy sector in Lithuania, where I would also like to pay tribute to the last Lithuanian governments, which have made it possible to diversify gas supplies to the Lithuanian energy sector in the near future, which I believe is an extremely important achievement for the future. Because congratulations to my Lithuanian colleagues again! And - the Baltic states are in the eurozone. Thanks!

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: for the GUE / NGL Group. - Sir. Chairman! The May 25 election resulted in a major defeat for the established euro parties and their austerity policies. Today, Parliament will welcome Lithuania into the euro. And it is clear: every country has the right to decide for itself whether it wants to join the euro. But in this case, there are a few major problems: firstly, Lithuania has not had a referendum. It is a major problem that the Lithuanian people have not been allowed to decide whether they want to join the euro. A survey also shows that there is a majority against the euro in Lithuania. Secondly, the road to the euro has been tough for the population. Extreme cuts have been made to their welfare and greater inequality has been created in society. That is why it is not strange that the people do not want the euro, and that is why it is also a huge problem that you are not listening. After all, that is exactly what makes the people vote for the far right. It is not okay! We must stand on the side of the people, and we must fight against the outrageous cuts.

name: Michel REIMON
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group.- Madam President!My group is pleased to vote in favor of the report and to welcome Lithuania to the euro area.Lithuania is already in the exchange rate mechanism and needs to understand the monetary policy.We cannot understand how one can deny them a say in politics and vote against it when they have to support this policy.However, the financial crisis, the economic crisis and the Union’s austerity policy have also left their mark on Lithuania: one sixth of the population is unemployed.Something has to be done, this economic course has to change, also in the interests of the Lithuanians.That is why we will be proposing amendments to call for a departure from the austerity course and we want to draw attention to this issue.But we will vote in favor of the report and we will be happy to welcome Lithuania.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: On behalf of the EFDD Group. - 2004 Lithuania joined a different European Union. It has changed beyond recognition in those ten years: unfortunately, I have to say that we have not created a European community that citizens can trust, which will become part of more than half a billion Europeans. Most Lithuanians are less optimistic about their future than they were 10 years ago: I mean social exclusion, unemployment and people's frustration. Today we are discussing the introduction of the euro in Lithuania. I believe that it is not just a simple formality for the Lithuanian nation, which established its state many centuries ago, based its legal foundations on statutes and constitutions, persistently defended its freedom and independence for centuries, preserved its spirit, mother tongue, writing and customs. It is a renunciation of part of statehood. More than half of 2013 A survey of Lithuanians conducted in the spring of 2006 had negative opinions about the introduction of the euro in Lithuania. Ladies and gentlemen, most Lithuanians do not want the euro. And we simply have no right to ignore it. I heard Jean-Claude Juncker speak today. I quote: 'I want the EU to get closer to the people'. Mr President, by introducing the euro against the will of the majority of people, will we bring the EU closer to the people? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: blue-card question. – I would ask like to ask Mr Paksas who he is really working for, because I do not think he has even checked the latest ratings of euro popularity. He has not thought about the young people of Lithuania who are the future of Lithuania, who are going to pay the pensions. He is being very populist – and he was a President who was removed from office. He was expelled. That is why he has an opinion. He is a populist. I am ashamed to hear such a speech from him. I would like to ask: who are you representing?

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: the answer to the question posed after the blue card was raised.- Thank you very much for the opportunity to speak to whom the Member of the European Parliament from the Lithuanian state represents: from now on, until now, today and always - only for the Lithuanian state.If the representation of the opinion of the citizens of Lithuania, I repeat once again - the opinion of the citizens - who by the vast majority today do not support the change of currency, is populism, then I respectfully accept this word.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is quite a symbol to see that one of the first issues of this legislature is Lithuania's accession to this ailing euro zone. The opinion of our new Parliament does not matter since the decision has already been taken. To hell with the majority of Lithuanians who were against joining the euro. It is the logic of this ultraliberal Europe which hastens to wrest from the nations their supreme sovereignty, the right to coin money and thus to self-finance outside the capital markets. The Troika's steamroller is advancing but now more than 150 realistic deputies, guardians of peoples' freedom, are watching. Should we recall the overwhelming record of the euro, expensive for twelve years, the exclusion of mass unemployment, the fall in living standards, social downgrading, the drop in growth and competitiveness, public over-indebtedness unsustainable, sinking industrial production and chronic Eurodivergence in rates. All accompanied by an insane bill for four years borne by citizens to save the euro and the private banking system. These public aid and financial guarantees disconnected from the GDP represent only 525 billion euros for France. We Eurorealists know that your economic adjustment variable is unemployment and wage devaluation. Also, in solidarity with our Lithuanian friends, can we in good conscience make them suffer the same ineffective austerity and social devastation that were imposed on the Greeks? Your single euro currency is the crisis and the European economic war. Peace is the common euro currency coupled with national currencies like all the great economic powers.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Madam President, I should like to thank my colleagues for all the nice words that we have heard about my country. Today we heard the new President of the Commission saying that the euro is saving Europe and in Lithuania we definitely agree with that. Just yesterday it was announced that according to the latest surveys Lithuanians are back on the list of the biggest euro optimists. We are looking forward to joining the euro area from 1 January next year. Joining means two things for us. Firstly, that the path of prudent financial planning and austerity measures and structural reforms really works. It is a great acknowledgement of the difficult process that took place in Lithuania. Austerity was not easy, it never is, but now we are the ones to say that it was worth it. Another reason why euro-optimism is rising is that against the background of the aggression against Ukraine, people want more security and it is clear today that Europe and the euro area are a geopolitical haven that people seek. So once again the upcoming joining by Lithuania of the euro area is a great recognition and a strong message of a united Europe.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: First of all, I would like to wholeheartedly congratulate my country, Lithuania, which has worked very hard and successfully implemented the necessary convergence criteria and has the opportunity from 1 January next year. join the euro area family. Dear colleagues, Lithuania is a small country, therefore participation in the euro area will certainly help our country to expand trade and financial relations with other euro area countries, create better conditions for foreign investment, which will also promote income growth and quality employment and jobs for Lithuanians. In addition, the population will feel the positive impact of the introduction of the euro due to the reduced interest burden, the disappearance of the litas and the cost of exchanging the euro, finally exports will grow faster in my country, and our country's much-needed investments will come to Lithuania faster. In conclusion, I would like to say that the referendum in Lithuania was held before the accession to the European Union. Then the Lithuanian people agreed to be in this family and, under the conditions, to adopt the euro. Therefore, I would like to wish that the introduction of the euro in Lithuania would promote economic growth, job creation and the social well-being of the people.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr. Balz pointed out that this decision was made under time pressure - a decision that is irrevocable. The question is: why is there time pressure? We have the stress tests of the European banking system ahead of us; the results are not yet available. We have four years behind us in which the financial crisis was particularly severe because banks were unable to withstand a stressful situation. What is the reason for creating time pressure? Why not wait until the results of the stress test are also available for the Lithuanian banking system? There was a convergence test, a convergence report by the European Central Bank, in which the European Central Bank pointed out that the criterion of price stability was not met. The inflation rate in Lithuania is very volatile, recently it was double digits, it is now almost on the verge of deflation. Prices are threatening to fall. Prices that are not stable indicate severe macroeconomic imbalances. And these macroeconomic imbalances have to be balanced out through real adjustments, through unemployment, through loss of income, through tax increases or whatever, when there is no longer any exchange rate flexibility, when there is no longer any autonomous monetary policy. These burdens are borne by the population. And then you ask yourself: why is the population not being asked? I have heard speeches here from people who believe they know what the Lithuanian people want - based on opinion polls. But, ladies and gentlemen, if you are so sure, then you could also let the population vote. It is illegitimate to admit Lithuanians into the euro without first asking them whether they are prepared to bear the burdens that may result from joining the euro.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: Lithuania's accession to the Economic and Monetary Union is a fair, logical and decisive step for further integration into the European Union. Faced with the challenges of the economic crisis, Lithuania has taken the necessary decisions in a timely manner, limiting budget expenditures and accelerating the necessary social and economic reforms. This has allowed economic competitiveness to be maintained, new jobs to be created and economic growth to be restored. For the fifth year in a row, the Lithuanian economy is growing, which is the best assessment of reforms, which is also confirmed by international markets. XX a. In the 1990s, when Lithuania was guided by the Soviet occupation, we heard a lot of encouragement from the Kremlin: don't do it, stay where you are. However, dear colleagues, the Lithuanian people are rational, looking to the future. They know what decisions to make, they don’t need advisors in the field. Dear colleagues, in January the euro will already speak Lithuanian, and euro coins will already fill the pockets of Europeans. I expect a solid and necessary solution from this Parliament.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: I contribute and congratulate Lithuania on taking this very important step.The government has worked hard to meet the criteria and be able to adopt the euro.But, unfortunately, it is also being introduced at the expense of the poorest people: retirees working for the minimum wage, and so on.Therefore, today more people in Lithuania do not support than support the hasty introduction of the euro.In order to meet the criteria for the introduction of the euro, low and medium-sized wages have been reduced during the crisis, have not yet returned to previous levels and the difference has not been compensated.This is unfair.As the Lithuanian economy is growing and the pre-crisis level has already been reached, I call on the Lithuanian government to solve these problems before the end of this year, and I hope that public opinion will change.I think it will be everyone’s win.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not allow myself to express myself, as my colleagues have done, for or against Lithuania’s adoption of the euro. I don't think it's a choice that is up to me as an Italian citizen. Rather, I am really concerned that Lithuanian citizens have not been given a choice whether or not they want to join the single currency. As indicated by the report discussed in committee, the polls show clear opposition from Lithuanians towards the introduction of the euro. However, the political leaders wanted to deliberately ignore popular opinion once again. The Five Star Movement is for direct democracy and considers it essential that for such important decisions the word should be given to the people. In democracy, the people are sovereign. I wonder why there was no referendum to ask Lithuanian citizens what they thought of joining the euro. Why once again do the European institutions fail to take into account the will of the citizens they claim to represent? We cannot ignore the will of the people for such important choices. There is an instrument that gives a voice to citizens and their will: it is the popular referendum, let's use it and make it institutional. I end by reminding you all that if you are aware of the strength and value of your proposals and ideas, you should not fear popular judgment. Otherwise, it means being afraid, even worse having something to hide.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, Mr Rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen! Lithuania has thus met the convergence criteria. These convergence criteria are impressive in the case of Lithuania. That is an inflation rate of 0.6% - as has already been said today: close to deflation. If I may make a comparison: The inflation rate in my home country Austria in 2014 was 1.7%. The budget deficit in Lithuania: 2.1% - this value too, if I may compare it with Austria: 2.7% for 2014. The gross debt ratio is particularly impressive: 39.4% in Lithuania. Again, I can quote the Austrian value: 79.2%. That means that the national debt in Austria is almost twice as high as in Lithuania. I would like to congratulate my Lithuanian colleagues on these efforts, but at the same time I would like to say that the positive message of these efforts has apparently not yet reached the people of Lithuania. We have a survey from May 2013, according to which 52% of the population of Lithuania vote against the introduction of the euro. Possibly there would be similar bad poll results in other euro countries; but there are no such surveys. For this reason, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask the member states because of the lack of compliance with the convergence criteria: comply with the stability criteria, consolidate your budgets and finally carry out the necessary structural reforms! (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mrs Kappel, you described the convergence figures as impressive.You also referred to the inflation rate of 0.6% or actually 0.3% in the meantime.But what's impressive about being close to deflation, where the European Central Bank's stated goal is to have an inflation rate of 2% so that you don't slip into deflation?Isn't it rather the case that this is an alarm signal that Lithuania also has massive economic problems?

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Two things: I find it impressive when a country manages to get from a double-digit inflation rate to 0.6% within a few years.Of course, it's unsettling in some ways.You are absolutely right: according to the ECB, price stability has not yet been achieved in this case.Since - you are absolutely right - one must continue to be careful.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Mr. Lucke turns the arguments as he needs them. At first it gave the impression that Lithuania did not meet the criteria at all. I have to be very clear: the Commission's report clearly states that Lithuania is now meeting all legal and economic requirements, including compliance with the Treaty, price stability, sound and sustainable public finances, sustainability of convergence and exchange rate stability. The Commission is also analyzing the factors and you have acted as if the ECB was saying the opposite. It doesn't. She comes to the same conclusions. It only indicates that keeping the inflation rate low in Lithuania will be a major challenge. We have countries where inflation is too low and we have countries where it is too high. That is why we have Economic and Monetary Union, the Stability and Growth Pact, so that we can achieve convergence in the internal market, in the euro zone, which creates growth and employment. And if we have heard the new Commission President today: We are in a situation in which we extinguished a burning plane in flight. And we have an economic and monetary union that is not yet complete.
