We are happy that on the day we democratically elect a new Commission President for the first time, we can also show that this community is getting stronger, that we are continuing to pursue our goals, that during the crisis we can join two new Member States in the euro Zone and a new member state have joined the European Union. Hopefully we all have the goal of turning the monetary union into an economic, fiscal and political union. Welcome to the euro zone!

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: When I got my driver's license, the instructor warned me: don't think you can actually drive now. Vigilance is still required! I think that this warning also applies today to Lithuania, which, after a curious restructuring policy, meets the convergence criteria. Still, there are a few comments to be made about the sustainability of that convergence. I will mention two things: first and foremost inflation, and especially the volatility of that inflation from 10% to nearly 0% in a few years. Second, I would like to mention unemployment, which remains high despite strong economic growth. The eurozone is a project that is supported by solidarity, but which also necessarily appeals to a sense of responsibility. That is why I find it very regrettable that more and more appeals are being made to more flexible interpretation of the conditions of the Stability Pact. If we want to avoid the disintegration of the eurozone, we need good drivers and strict traffic rules that are strictly enforced.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: Madam President, there is a Lithuanian proverb that says ‘all that glitters is not gold, and all that is sticky is not tar’. The Lithuanian people have taken heed of their proverb, with 55% under a recent Eurobarometer poll stating that their country should not join the euro. But in the time-honoured EU tradition of ignoring the will of the people, the Lithuanians were not offered a referendum. Instead, the government decided to join on its own. Furthermore, at yesterday’s economic and monetary dialogue meeting, Mr Draghi stated that the ECB was aware that the Lithuanian economy has extreme variabilities. However, he said it is important to note that it had complied with all the ECB conditions on joining. Well have we not heard that before? Those assurances were given for Greece, Spain and Portugal, and now it is plain for all to see what damage the euro has done to those great countries and what a terrible legacy has been left for the millions of unemployed people across those countries. We should support those Lithuanians who want a referendum and who oppose joining the euro because they know that for those who champion the euro it glitters but for millions of ordinary people in Europe the euro is certainly not golden.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Madam President, Lithuania tried to join the euro area in 2006 but it will achieve this in January 2015. This delay has proved very productive for Lithuania and the European Union. The country has had adequate time to prepare itself in a better way to face the challenge and the European Union has found new ways of managing the systemic risks.  In my view, Lithuania’s successful participation in the euro area will depend on five factors. Firstly, on the quality of its preparation. Lithuania is much better prepared than Greece was 14 years ago. To give you an example, Lithuania’s public debt is less than 40% of GDP, whereas in Greece, my country, it was more than 100 %.  Secondly, Lithuania seems to be in a position to use the period following the adoption of the euro to solve its particular economic problems and catch up with the most advanced members of the euro area in terms of competitiveness. Thirdly, the euro area has developed a sophisticated control system and therefore the systemic risk has been greatly reduced. Fourthly, Lithuania has put its finances and its economy in order. It now needs more development opportunities and a better financed banking system. Finally, Lithuania has to cope with a somewhat unstable international environment but the most probable scenario is that there will not be a major crisis which could deny the country its successful participation in the euro area. I would just like to congratulate our Lithuanian friends and assure them that the comparison with Greece lacks any substance. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Diane JAMES
text: blue-card question. – I have sat here for perhaps twenty minutes now and I have heard a number of speakers. The point I would like to make is that despite the reassurance of the last speaker, I sense a car crash waiting to happen. Only a few minutes ago one of the speakers highlighted that you need good drivers, but equally you have to have your passengers on board. If, as we have heard in the last few minutes, the passengers in Lithuania were not actually on board, it is very interesting that they still wish to pursue what they have set out upon.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: I would like to remind you that this procedure actually involves a question to the speaker.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, we welcome Lithuania to the euro, although we should say that we would have preferred Lithuanian citizens to have been given the right to decide in a referendum whether or not their country should join the Economic and Monetary Union. But I take this opportunity to point out that the European Central Bank should stop supporting austerity and socializing policies for bank losses. Instead, it should boost liquidity and cut money in order to revive the economy and create jobs for the millions of our unemployed fellow citizens in the European South. Finally, I would like to point out once again that the European Central Bank should stop speculating against the Greek people, since it has bought bonds worth at least 54 billion euros with a 40% discount and demands that each time these bonds be paid in the nominal their value, ie 100%, thus impoverishing even more the impoverished Greek society.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Madam President, I think it is important to look at the forest and not just the trees because Lithuaniaʼs entry into the euro area now is a sign of achievements, of reforms and changes, of Lithuania having left behind the deep economic crisis. But it is also a sign that there is change going on in the Baltic region where some of the most modern, competitive and stable economies are emerging, not only in the Baltic area but also around the Baltic Sea, with the German economy, Finland, the three Baltic states. I know that some colleagues are suspicious of everything here but let us look at the big picture – Lithuania now firmly rooted in the European economy. But it is also a sign that you can make the changes. I think that those of you over there should worry much more about those countries which are not carrying out reforms, not making changes; not those that are showing that you can achieve a fundamental stability by the policies you need. I think you should be much more critical of those which are not trying to be in. From my point of view, from my Swedish perspective, what we now see is a new sign in the Nordic and Baltic region where I think it is even more important for Sweden to enter.  I congratulate Lithuania but I think we can also congratulate Europeans because now we know that you can make a change. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr. Hökmark!All of you - including the previous speakers - rely very heavily on figures, on statistics that have been collected, although it is clear that the figures that are currently being collected are not very reliable.It is not for nothing that the European accounting standards are being redesigned for the states.This happens against the background that you know that the numbers are currently not sufficiently reliable.Then how can you be so sure now that these things have been sustainably proven?

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for that philosophical question. The answer is very easy and is that nothing is certain in reality or in life, but sometimes you need to make a judgement. What interests me is how you can be so sure that everything is wrong in a region where one has seen competitiveness and stability merging? How can you be so sure that it is wrong to have an open economy which is giving prosperity and development? How can you be so sure that it is wrong for Lithuania to enter the stable framework of the European economy? How can you be so sure?

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: Madam President, congratulations for the first time in this position on leading the work of the European Parliament. I congratulate Lithuania on its performance as the nineteenth euro area Member State. Lithuania has made a remarkable effort, met the convergence criteria and demonstrated once again that a country, regardless of its level of development, can be competitive as long as revenues and expenditures remain in line with productivity developments. Lithuania is an example for all other Member States which, when they joined the European Union, undertook to take all necessary measures to meet the convergence criteria and adopt the euro. Unfortunately, these commitments are left to the Member States alone. I believe that both the Council and the European Commission and the European Parliament should be more insistent on speeding up this process in all Member States that have a duty to meet the convergence criteria.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: First of all, I congratulate Lithuania on the work it has done to ensure financial stability and sustainable economic growth. This is clearly illustrated by the fact that Lithuania fulfills all the Maastricht criteria and is ready to adopt the euro on 1 January 2015. The introduction of the euro in Lithuania, similarly to Latvia, will promote economic growth and increase prosperity. First, it will ensure lower interest rates on public and private borrowing, as the exchange rate risk between the litas and the euro will disappear. Financial markets and the membership of the international credit rating agency in the euro area are also perceived as positive news about the country's financial stability. Secondly, the currency conversion costs between the litas and the euro will disappear. In small and open economies such as the Baltic States, this is a significant cost factor. Third, the introduction of the euro will make the country more attractive to foreign direct investment, as it will be safer and more understandable for investors to work with the euro than with various small national currencies. The introduction of the euro in Lithuania is positive news for all the Baltic States. It reaffirms the achievements of the Baltic States in ensuring financial stability and economic growth, as well as demonstrates the region's attractiveness for attracting investment. With Lithuania's accession to the eurozone, the last currency barrier between the Baltic states will disappear, which will undoubtedly facilitate trade in the region. This is especially important for Latvia, as Lithuania is Latvia's largest trading partner. The introduction of the euro Lithuania is also positive news for the euro area as a whole. Contrary to recent concerns about the eurozone's problems and even its possible collapse, we are seeing the opposite: the eurozone continues to expand and strengthen. Welcome to the euro area, Lithuania.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for the good news that will be conveyed to the Lithuanian people from this Chamber today. Lithuania will have the opportunity to join the euro area next year and start using all the opportunities offered by economic and monetary union. The euro will provide an additional impetus to the Lithuanian economy and the well-being of the country's population, exchange rate risk will disappear, there will be strong preconditions for lower interest rates, and there will be a greater opportunity to raise people's living standards faster. This is what we all wanted in Lithuania - and I personally - back in 2006. The fact that the conditions for the introduction of the euro have been met shows that Lithuania is once again able to pursue a responsible economic policy. As a result, Lithuania's attractiveness among job-creating investors is increasing. Deeper economic integration of Lithuania in the European Union creates a more favorable environment for international trade. I believe that the introduction of the euro in the last Baltic State will make the region more integrated and attractive to investors and those who see it as ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President!Commission President Juncker used a wonderful picture this morning to describe the euro.We should definitely not forget that.Mr Juncker said that he made mistakes about the euro.But the task was difficult.The task was to "repair a burning aircraft in flight".He describes the euro as an airplane on fire and he's trying to fix it in flight!We shouldn't forget this picture.I recommend Mr Juncker and everyone who supports him to think about the possibility of making an emergency landing on a burning aircraft rather than repairing it.Make an emergency landing and then extinguish it and not try to repair it in flight.We should hold on to this picture.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Madam President, I think that Lithuania joining the euro is a huge achievement. It is an achievement that the whole country is proud of. They actually showed this in the current elections where the pro-European parties dominated. The Liberals had a very successful election, as did the Social Democrats and the Conservatives. All these three parties are pro-euro.  It is also very interesting to note that Lithuania was formerly pegged to the US dollar, and we moved over to trusting the euro a long time ago. We were there. We missed it in 2006 by 0.01%. That is how honest Lithuania is. We should be proud of it. We did not fix our figures to qualify in 2006. We took the pain, we worked hard and we suffered a lot. The people of Lithuania suffered a great deal and we have to live with that. We need the support of Europe. We need investment in Lithuania. We can grow. We are pro-European and Europe should be proud of Lithuania, as I am.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: Madam President, I want to really congratulate our Lithuanian friends because this is a major achievement, not of the government, but of the Lithuanian people. I am especially glad that this has happened now when, next month, we will be celebrating 25 years of the Baltic Chain. I am happy that the Baltic Chain is again united and we are now united in a new way, in a new Europe, and that we are all ready to go further, together, in the common Baltic and Nordic economic, political and value space. So congratulations from me and from all Estonian Socialists and Democrats.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen,Mr Balz from the CDU today congratulated the Lithuanian government on joining the euro, especially under the sign that an unsuccessful attempt had already been made in 2006 and the Lithuanian government continued on its way undeterred.Well, the history of the euro is full of such unsuccessful attempts and the fact that you just move on and keep going on this path.It's been going on for over a decade.I pity the Lithuanian population, the majority of whom do not want to go along this path.As the great Mr Juncker might say: Welcome to the burning plane!

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: Madam President, I would also like to congratulate Lithuania on adopting the euro. In contrast to those who believed that the euro would disappear, Lithuania shows that European citizens want a common European currency. We, Romanians, also want a common European currency, we want to be part of the euro area and we hope that, in 2018, we will be part of this area that represents an elite of Europe. The euro is the single European currency and we must defend this right of European citizens to economic and financial mobility. The euro scares only those who hope that financial and accounting tricks can solve economic problems and replace good budgetary and financial management. The European currency is a right of European citizens, but also a symbol of European unity and power. We need a single monetary policy, this is the only way we can defend ourselves against economic and monetary attacks launched by large corporations or other states with hidden interests. We see what is happening now in Argentina or Bulgaria, we know what has happened in the past and we need the euro.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Madam President, Lithuania’s euro adoption is a remarkable achievement, both for this beautiful country and for our Union. It shows that the foundations of our currency union are solid, that the work done by all the actors during the crisis has borne fruit. It shows that membership of the euro area is seen as a prerequisite for growth and economic prosperity. Again, I wish to extend my warmest welcome to the euro area to Lithuania.

name: Siim Kallas
text: Vice-president of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members, this has been a lively discussion where we could hear all the arguments for and against. I must make some remarks concerning the debate. First of all the Euro Group and Ecofin have both discussed the Lithuanian accession to the euro area and adoption of the euro and unanimously welcomed the results achieved by the Lithuanian people – and this was with the participation of the European Central Bank – so there was no doubt about the performance of the Republic of Lithuania. So it is very clear that the convergence evidence is very solid. It has been taken very seriously by all institutions including the European Commission and the European Central Bank. The inflation rate today is more or less coherent with the inflation rate all over the European Union. If you compare it with the inflation rate of 2008, that was a completely different time; you cannot say that this was a volatile time and make some kind of conclusion based on the evidence of 2008. Some Members of the European Parliament have advocated an autonomous monetary policy which can help to solve some social and economic problems, but I must say that Lithuania has abandoned its autonomous monetary policy – since 2002, if I am correct – so from that year there has been a fixed exchange rate. Lithuania joined the exchange rate mechanism a couple of years later, so it has already been in the system of the European monetary policy, and in this sense there is no change.  What I would also like to say is that people who cannot see the virtues, the positive signs of exchange rate stability should look back at the history of the European Union. From the beginning – 1957, throughout the 1960s – the economic policy of the European Union was poisoned by the constant quarrelling about exchange rates between the Member States. Some Member States changed their exchange rates without warning and this created a real feeling of urgency that if we want to have single functioning market we must also have a functioning and harmonised monetary environment, which means a single currency.  I would, of course, like to say as well that from the Commission’s viewpoint all the necessary procedures have been followed, and the Commission has no doubts about the democratic nature of the decision. As a Member from Lithuania said, all Member States who joined the European Union from 1 May 2004 have actually had referendums which contained this question. So it was already decided then; we had referendums in the Baltic countries and this was a part of our accession negotiations and our agreement on how to develop our economic policies further.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! I wonder: all these critics who have spoken here, from the right and left, have disappeared. Not a single one listened to the arguments. This is not serious work! It's forgotten about history and irresponsible! The speeches here today did not reflect the election result of the European elections, nor did the opinion-making in the European Parliament. Let me start with one point: it is a legitimate choice. The Lithuanian government unanimously decided to join the euro. Parliament approved the law in April with 81 percent - 87 for, 7 against and 13 abstentions. That is a clear democratic majority. Anyone who now claims that this is not legitimate, that a referendum must be made, also does not want to acknowledge that after the most recent polls - all of which are quoted here from May 2013 - opinion has changed. The majority are now in favor of the euro and the number will continue to grow. When I hear politicians here who say that you have to surrender sovereignty - of course, joining the European Union is a surrender of sovereignty, of course! And the Lithuanian government, the parliament, have made efforts that are not only honorable, but from which the critics can learn a bit here. That is why we are convinced that Lithuania will join as soon as possible. More will follow: Sweden, Poland and more. I am absolutely convinced that the statements made by Mr Landsbergis and Mr Dombrovskis and by the former Romanian Prime Minister are true, that it is a successful project and that we support it with all our might. In any case, I am looking forward to Lithuania as the 19th member and hope that we will vote on the 20th and 21st next year. There was no question of time pressure. The only reason the report is made like this is that it has always been like this. I have been on the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee in this Parliament for 20 years. It has always been decided on the basis of the latest figures from June. What Mr. Lucke said about time pressure - he just has no idea, like many a professor.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: The debate was closed.The vote will take place tomorrow morning at 11.00.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - Mr President, the situation in the euro area is very volatile at the moment and will continue to be so for quite some time to come. In such a situation, Lithuania's accession to the single currency area would be a mistake. Its own currency provides a good enough protection against the negative effects of the economic and financial crisis. In turn, the rapid introduction of the euro will immediately cause our country the problems currently facing the countries involved in monetary union, including the requirement to allocate large sums to bail out failing states. The euro does not unite, but deepens divisions, even between those countries that have adopted the single currency. The euro does not strengthen, but exhausts the European Union as the only region in the world that has fallen so badly into recession. Today, Lithuania should ask itself whether the euro is a reliable currency and whether it would not be better to keep its currency, at least until the situation in the euro area is clear and predictable. In the current situation, postponing the introduction of the euro seems to be the best solution. And, most importantly, it would be safe for the Lithuanian population, as it would protect them from a drastic increase in the prices of goods and services after a possible accession to the euro area, as was the case in almost all countries adopting the euro. We cannot allow the burden of the introduction of the euro to fall on ordinary Lithuanians, who have been struggling with the crisis for several years already. Lithuania must preserve its currency, because only an independent monetary policy will allow it to react flexibly to the economic situation in Europe and the world.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - Lithuania's preparation process for joining the euro is a painful exercise in forced austerity through which the people of Lithuania have been subjected to drastic measures with high social and economic costs. Contrary to what is said in the report that supports this accession, this process was far from being a success. It is no coincidence that this accession was rejected by the majority of the population in a referendum in May 2013. Indeed, Lithuania has in recent years gone through a period of great recession, with a strong contraction of the national economy, loss of power to purchase of workers, very high unemployment rates and forced emigration of a significant part of their youth. We continue to believe that the process of joining the euro represents an intolerable interference in national sovereignties, which thus lose an important instrument of economic policy and are subject to a single monetary policy at the service of the great powers of central Europe, an interference that is even more evident when it comes to a decision that ignored the will of the Lithuanian people.
